nd of november that travelling carriage stopped on way to london to change horse at principal hotel in little town of staines inmate of vehicle be two ladiesan elderly domestic in livery female attendant occupied box night be clear fine frosty moon shone brightly carriage lamp threw strong glare to considerable distance in front of vehicle active ostler speedily unharnessed four wearied steed substituted a many fresh one in place two postboys leapt into saddle landlord cried rightand carriage rolled rapidly away from inn horse shoe striking fire against stone if there be thing particularly calculated to raise spirit said one lady to other few minute after chariot have left peaceful town behind be travelling upon beauteous night a be delighted to observe that be in good spirit evening dear lady hatfield be reply after passing four long month at sir ralph walsingham country seat london will present fresh attraction for ladyship dear miss mordaunt returned lady hatfield in serious tone be aware that be indifferent to formal party ceremonial assembly be reckoned amongst pleasure of fashionable world can assure have not uncle purported to return to london in few day own inclination must have urged to prolong stay at walsingham manor for part said miss mordaunt be quite delighted with idea of hastening back to great metropolis summer in country be only tolerable because day brings one nearer to enjoyment of winter in town really dear lady hatfield be not reasonable rich young beautiful a areyour own mistressand with handsomest man in england dying to lay coronet at foot will never marry julia hastily interrupted lady hatfield pray let change conversation few minute ago be in excellent spirit now pausedand deep sigh escaped bosom did not say that be quite unreasonable exclaimed companion here be ifive year older than yourselffor mind telling dear friend that will never see thirty againand yet have not renounced idea of changing condition know that be so good looking so wealthy a youstill have little ambition sir christopher blunt must deem honoured be to smile graciously upon brother lieutenantwho by by expects captaincy in few day thanks to interest of kind uncle sir ralphdeclares that if ever marry mere knight will never speak to again lady hatfield have fallen into profound reverie paid not slightest regard to confidential outpouring of garrulous companion miss mordaunt who laboured under pleasing impression that lady hatfield silence be occasioned by deep interest took in present topic continued to rattle away with tongue a fast a carriage did with wheel be sure be very great act of kindness in to ask to spend winter with in london for a papa be compelled to reside in ireland in consequence of unsettled state of tenantry must have be under necessity of returning to emerald isle after four month visit with to walsingham manor have not taken compassion on let speak of dear lady hatfield without soul in world to control actionswith mean of procuring enjoymentand with lord ellingham going mad on account julia said lady hatfield with startagain beseech to drop subject a will be companion for month to come let now once for enjoin to abstain from such topic a can not read secret of heart pray bear in mind fact that many light word uttered thoughtlessly with malicious intent may touch chord will thrill added calmly bitterly to inmost recess of soul oh dear lady hatfield exclaimed miss mordaunt who in spite of loquacity be very good natured person be rejoiced that have given warning how foolish of not to have observedwhat indeed now rememberthat topic of love never be agreeable to to be sure be during sermon upon felicity of wedded state that fainted be taken into vestry lady hatfield writhed in mental agony bitterly at moment did repent invitation have given thoughtless companion to pas winter with in london carriage have now reached little town of bedfont traversed without stopping continued rapid way towards hounslow of sudden course of chariot be checkedas if by unexpected impediment in way horse began to plunge frightfully at same time lady maid on box uttered dreadful scream lady hatfield drew down window nearest to chaise moment came to full stop stern evidently disguised voice exclaimed keep horse quiet damned foolsand mind if stir till give leave will blow out brain of of robber shrieked miss mordaunt in despairing tone oh what will become of lady hatfield looked from window at same instant man mounted on horseback with black mask over countenance pistol in hand be by side of vehicle villain cried livery servant on box will swing for perhaps may said highwayman coolly though still speaking in feigned tone a be custom with individual of profession upon such occasion a one be describing if attempt to move old fellow from where be ounce of lead will tumble down from perch beg pardon ma'be continued robber turning towards lady hatfield who have shrunk back into corner of carriage moment desperado appeared at window sorry to inconvenience butyour purse lady hatfield handed highwayman reticule good said perceiving by weight certain jingling sound sent forth that contained gold have companion ma'amher purse miss mordaunt complied with demand implored good gentleman not to murder highwayman gave reply vouchsafed most satisfactory proof of intended forbearance in respect by putting spur to steed darting off like arrow in direction of hounslow cowardly villain that be ejaculated livery servant hurling reproach against postboys what be old fool cried postillion who rode wheel horse will be nabbed yet drive ondrive on exclaimed lady hatfield from window be frightenedand not hurt indeed dear said miss mordaunt a carriage started off rapidly once more be seriously hurtgrievously wounded julia cried ladyship in unfeigned surprise yesin pocket be answer implying deep vexation remainder of quarter allowance oh compose on head interrupted lady hatfield will not be compelled to acquaint mr mordaunt with loss assurance conveying promise of pecuniary assistance materially tended to tranquillise mind of miss mordaunt event have just occurredapart from mere robbery of reticuleawoke most painful reflection in mind of lady hatfield by by said miss mordaunt after short pausefor never remained long silentthis audacious outrage reminds of something uncle sir ralph walsingham be telling one day when interrupted in middle think informed that about six seven year agowhen be only eighteen nineteenyou be staying at dear lamented father country house where be quite alonefor of course one doe not call servant anybody when mansion be broken into by robber during night julia exclaimed lady hatfield whole frame fearfully convulsed by powerful though useless effort made to subdue agitation never implore again allude to dreadful event welli never will said miss mordaunt yet if one must not speak of lovenor yet of marriagenor yet of midnight burglary be wrong to cut short thus abruptly remarked lady hatfield now endeavouring to rob prayer of importance with solemn earnestness of manner have invested only do choose more enlivening friend discharge old mason exclaimed lady hatfield impossible how must have protected be unarmedwhereas highwayman flourished two large pistol doubtless loaded here be safe at carriage drew up at door how be fellow dressed asked officer black coat said first postboy noit be cried second then what be demanded mr dyke knowbut be sure be black 'un be highly satisfactory answer describe horse said dyke carriage light come see be only losing time cried officer way did go galloped off in direction be reply remained uncontradicted then will be in london to night whichever road took said mr dyke if lady will give cast a far a town will be after villain perhaps turned off to left towards hatton so over by hanwell then shepherd bush else made straight for richmond so over into surrey one way be sure to be in london by midnight ten to one if pounce on business be done down here may just a well toddle back to night a to morrow morning substance of remark be communicated to lady hatfield who must not well do otherwise than accord seat on box to mr dyke charlotte lady maid removing to interior of carriage arrangement having be effected vehicle pursued way shortly after eleven o'clock drew up at door of mansion on piccadilly hill mr dyke having asked lady few question promised to communicate result of effort to capture highwayman then took departure lady hatfield miss mordaunt shortly retired to respective bed chamber latter to dream of delight of londonthe former to moisten pillow with tear for recent adventure have awakened in mind feeling of most agonising description chapter ii tom rain old death be about half past eight on following morning when two individual entered public house in white hart street drury lane one be man of about thirty year of age with florid complexion light hair red whiskersyet possessing countenance viewed a whole be very far from disagreeable eye be of deep blue indicated not only good humour certain generosity of disposition be not impaired by association with many le amiable qualitiessuch a wild recklessness of character undaunted bravery love of perilous adventure sad deficiency of principle on particular point nature of will hereafter transpire be evidently proud of very fine set of teeth brilliancy of compensated for somewhat coarse thickness of lip delicate whiteness of hand showed that did not earn livelihood by arduous labour in person be about middle heightby mean inclined to corpulencyand yet possessing well knit frame with muscular power indicative of great physical strength dress partook of half sporting half rakish characterconsisting of high chimney pot kind of hat with very narrow brim checked blue silk neckerchief fine linen buff waistcoat cut away newmarket style of green coat drab breech top boot proper name of flash gentleman be thomas rainford friend have taken liberty of docking word of syllable be invariably known a tom rain other individual be old man of at least sixty with white hair eye of fire glaring from beneath pair of thick shaggy grey brow be upwards of six foot in height little bowed by weight of year bore having lost teeth mouth have fallen in so a to form complete angle depth of be rendered more remarkable by extreme prominence of hooked nose projecting chin be a thin a be possible to be without having bone actually protruding through skin hung upon like tanned leather casing be dressed in long grey surtout coat reaching below knee pair of shabby black trouser very short black cloth gaiter fitting loosely over description of shoe generally denominated high low on head wore greasy cap with large front linen be by mean of cleanest appearance altogether be excessively unprepossessingif not absolutely revolting what real name be very few of even most intimate acquaintance be aware for dreadful emaciation of form have procured for frightful pseudonym of old death tom rain hideous companion entered public house in white hart street nodded familiarly to landlord a passed by bar ascended stair to private room on first floor having seated at table tom rain began conversation well have considered proposal asked have replied old man in deep sepulchral tone be cautiousvery cautious good friend so told when saw three day ago for first time observed rain impatiently tullock landlord of place be pal of yours know well too have satisfied about wellwell ca say that have answered old death still cautious man like never say yes in hurry tullock knew eight nine year ago down in country there be doubt that be then right sort of blade so be now cried tom rain striking table angrily with clenched fist softly softly good friend said old death will agree better afterwards if have good understanding at first be going to observe for year tullock loses sight of come up to town take public doe even remember that there be such fellow in existence a until make appearance here few day back when received with open arm introduced to added tom rain go on what next ah what next replied old death with horrible chuckle issued from throat a if come from depth of tomb whyyou frankly candidly told intention view admitbut ca do without meyou ca do without dear boyand know again hideous old man chuckled in cavern like tone never denied what say answered tom rain on contrary be well aware that one in line can think of doing business about london making london head quarter without assistance to be sure not said old man evidently pleased by compliment have have monopoly of for thirty year never once got into trouble then do business with cautionsuch caution have dealing with be worth having dealing with not one of know even where live only let find sure ready money market for good exclaimed tom rain will do more business with than chap speak of put together well suppose must come to term said old death after short pause tullock assures that be straight forward when knew in country though time change men mind a well a face will take for granted that be right remember condition not word uttered three day ago have escaped memory answered rain good when will commence business opened shop last night replied tom with hearty laugh nonsense cried old man fixing glance of delight upon new friend mean to say thatin word be yours a spoke old death drew from pocket morning newspaper pointed to particular advertisement held journal towards companion tom rain countenance be overclouded for moment almost immediately afterwards expanded into expression of mingled surprise satisfaction snapping finger joyfully exclaimed be possible must have be oh business be speedily settled rising from seat rang bell violently pot boy answered summons pen ink paper messenger to carry letter said tom rain with extraordinary rapidity of utterance boy disappeared old death recovering partially from astonishment into companion ejaculation manner on reading advertisement have thrown exclaimed what devil be after now will see in moment be reply promise explanation of what will see added with hearty laugh boy returned bringing writing material intimating that be willing to be bearer of letter tom rain told to wait then having hastily written few line upon sheet of paper tossed note over to old death who read a follows remember night of th of october stop inquiry instituted in respect to little business referred to by advertisement in morning time be past comprehension exclaimed old man still keeping eye fixed upon paper note have not even signature doe not require one coolly observed tom rain a snatched letter from companion proceeded to fold up do hope to crush business by mean of scrap of writing asked old death evidently perplexed what to think merely hopei be certain of accomplishing object be reply now mind ai deceiving tom said old death man who have taken up affair be persevering a beaver crafty a fox may see that be in earnest by expedition must have made to get advertisement into morning paper must have hardly thought possible to be done however done isand though give description of person yet offer good reward for apprehension one know what trivial circumstance may afford trace enough of old friend cried tom handing letter now duly folded wafered directed to boy said take to address written upon see if there be answer will wait here till come back look aliveand will earn crown by job boy of deep blue soul sate enthroned on pale lofty foreheadher smile though always plaintively mournful denoted amiability kindness in stature be of middle height though in least degree inclining to comprehend observed arthur with exceeding bitterness of tone happiness be at stake what can do have explained motive of refusal be that motive strong onedid reveal cause must render union candle placed upon chest of drawer dr lascelles beheld young female of great beauty with other garment on than night dress writhing in excruciating agony upon bed from reply given by servant girl to pursued in such case in course of hour patient be pronounced to be out of danger tom rain who have in meantime manifested utmost anxiety uneasiness now exhibited proportionate liveliness of joy will recover sir oh tell mewill recover asked young woman in strange thrilling piteous tone a fixed large dark eye upon countenance of physician be in fair way to survive madthis wicked attempt upon life drove off to visit patient footnote first great object must keep in view be to promote speedy evacuation of stomach if poison have not produced vomiting from ten to twenty grain of sulphate of zinc must be given if can be readily procured generally act a powerful emetic if however can not be obtained mustard emetic must be administered vomiting promoted by drinking large quantity of barley water linseed tea milk tepid water two first being of mucilaginous nature be to be preferred tickling back of throat with feather will often cause stomach to reject content frequently happens that treatment alone be sufficient for relief in accident of nature after stomach have be cleansed by emetic c a described above lime water chalk diffused in water if can be procured may be given in large quantity hahnemann have recommended soap to be dissolved in water in proportion of pound to four pint tea cupful to be given five six minute undoubtedly be best treatment if lime water be not at hand powdered charcoal may also be administered with advantage if other remedy be not immediately attainable above remedy may be used with degree of confidence although good effect be not sufficiently certain to establish a antidotesready remedy in case of poisoning c by james johnson mrcs chapter viii seven dial there be not in london more extraordinary locality than bear denomination of seven dial situate in midst of one of lowest worst neighbourhood throughout metropolis forming focus where seven street converging towards point meet like a many stream flowing into common reservoir open spot of ground called seven dial be lounge for idle vagabond ill looking person men woman who occupy cellar garret in vicinity from centre of open space alluded to eye may plunge glance down into circumjacent thoroughfaresnarrow dark filthy formed by dwelling of appearance so miserable so repulsive that equally pain heart shock sight if wanderer amidst maze of vast city be desired to point out chosen abode of poverty crime taking a guide physical aspect of worst neighbourhood must probably indicate seven dial branching street shop be of lowest dirtiest description nauseous odour impregnate atmosphere in winter street be knee deep in mud save when hardened by frost in summer be strewed with putrefying remnant of vegetable offal filth of description half naked child paddle about in mire wallow on heap of decomposing substance just alluded togreedily devouring paring of turnip carrot sucking marrow out of rotting bone rejoicing when happen to find mouldy crust morsel of putrid meat maggot eaten head of fish neglected being too be theyknowing nothing save blow curse hunger at home learning naught save corrupt habit ruinous vice abroad how can be surprised if such infancy becomes imbued with evil principle gaol treadmill only tend afterwards to confirm give ample promise of occupation for turnkey penal settlement hangman established church be maintained at annual expense of several million sterling clergy belonging to church claim right of educating instructing peopleand yet in country in civilised world be there such appalling amount of juvenile depravity a in england for declarewe repeat that government legislature clergy great landowner be guilty of blackest turpitude in permitting hundred of thousandsaye million of child to be neglected in so horrible manner if child be seized with malignant infectious dangerous disease what must be said of father who looked on indifferentlywho omitted to call in medical adviceand who beheld with equal calmness furious malady spreading amongst rest of offspring must not denounceshould not execrate such man a monster deserving of penalty statute must inflict yesa thousand time yes by parity of reasoning then do hold up to abhorrence men who seize upon rein of power merely to gratify own selfish ambition also men who accept seat in legislative assembly fritter away time of great nation in own party squabblesthose men too who put on black gown preach sermon a duty rendered in return for enjoyment of enormous revenue then declaim against wickedness of million whom attempt to reformand lastly men who wring sweat from poor man brow to distil pearl for who care not for welfare of poor man offspring hundred of thousand of pound be annually subscribed to further object of foreign mission scene of whose labour be in far off land scarcely known to by name amongst race with whom sympathy can not existbut beneath very eyescrossing pathsconstantly displaying loathsome rag to view be small child innumerable whose only training be for prison hulk gallows talk not to of christianizing barbarian in remote island of south sea when child of so many of own fellow countryman country woman be barbarous christian at home portion of narrative will understand when state that almost immediately behind elephant castle tavern there be considerable district totally unexplored by thousand thousand of person dwelling in other part of english capital district be now bounded on north by new kent road on east by kent greenwich road on south by walworth on west by walworth road built upon low damp unhealthy soil dwelling of poor there throng in frightful abundanceforming narrow street half choked up with dirt miserable alley where very air be stagnant dark court to enter seems like going into ftid vault of church many of street appear to have be huddled together without architectural plan merely upon studied system of crowding together a many hovel a possible have back window looking upon ditch black mire standing water of exhale vapour sufficiently noxious to breed pestilence when sun shine upon noisome ditch surface display thousand prismatic hue thrown out by decomposing offal putrid vegetable have be emptied into open sewer sewer can not be calledfor instead of carrying off filth of neighbourhood ditch preserve stagnant considerable portion of district be describing be known by name of lock field horrible condition of locality can only be properly understood by visit pen can not convey adequate idea of loathsome squalor of povertythe heart rending proof of wretchednessand revolting example of utter demoralization characterise section of metropolis house for most part contain four room room serving a domicile of separate family perhaps one of member of such family may be afflicted with infectious malady there must lie upon flock mattress bundle of rag heap of straw until become through neglect so offensive a to render one minute with intolerable yet relativesfour five even six in numberare compelled to sleep in same apartment with inhaling stench from mass of putrefaction hearing groan breathing steam from corrupted lung swarming with myriad of loathsome animalcule engendered by filth of place in room perhaps will find old man living by himselfstarving upon miserable pittance obtained by picking up bone rag doing odd job now then for neighbour filling up interval of such pursuit by begginghis entire furniture consisting of cup kettle knifeno chair tablebut with heap of rubbish in one corner for bed on sleep with clothes on in third room there be most likely family consisting of man wife who at night occupy one mattress grown up son daughter who pig together upon shame decency exist not amongst thembecause must never have known either have be accustomed from infancy to other nakedness a feeling be brutalised by such mode of existence suffer scruple to oppose fearful intercourse sensuality suggests thusfor must speak plainly a speak truththe very wretchedness of poor compels family commingling in one room a be in one bed lead to incesthorrible revolting incest fourth room in house take for example of dwelling in lock field be occupied by landlord landlady there be perhaps more morality cleanliness in chamber than in of others shop in lock field be naturally in keeping with mean habit of customer beer shop public house abound lower poorer locality greater number of such establishment who can wonder crime requires stimulantsand poverty consolation men drink to nerve to perpetrate misdeed be attended with peril woman drink to supply artificial flow of spirit necessary to maintenance of career of prostitutionand honest poor drink to save from access of maddening despair child drink also because see parent drink because have acquired taste from earliest infancyand thus beer shop public house thrive most gloriously in most wretched neighbourhood lock field abound with small general shop where thing be sold in minutest detaila pennyworth of sugar penny farthing worth of tea farthing candle quarter of pound of bacon for penny there be also many eating house where leg of beef soup can be procured for five farthing bowl knacker do good business with owner of establishment tripe shop be likewise far from rare upon board in open window may be seen gory slice of black looking liver tongue brain in dish sheep head year old be unable to read know not who jesus christ be that saviour of mankind suffered upon cross to save a well a proudest peer most brilliant peeress shine in realm of fashion look more closely at door behind chapter x scene at house of sir christopher blunt on following afternoon shortly after four o'clock three gentleman sate sipping wine after early dinner in magnificently furnished room in jermyn street one who occupied head of table be red faced stout elderly gentleman with hair of blueish black denotes use of artificial dye with large bushy whisker of similar tint be dressed in blue coat with brass button white waistcoat black kerseymere trouser fitting very tight massive gold chain depended from neck on finger wore several ring of great value in manner be authoritative even to rudeness for being immensely rich firmly believed that money constituted aristocracy have perfect right to command pride be more excessive too a have risen from nothing be have begun life a errand boy in linen draper shop have finished mercantile career a warehouseman in wood street where amassed considerable fortune have filled office of sheriff have vainly endeavoured to procure aldermanic gown having failed to persuade livery men of portsoken ward that be very best person must possibly choose to represent in superior city court have ever since affected to rejoice at rejection to look upon city men city matter with contempt in reality too be dreadfully mortified at fact of low origin with clumsy duplicity vulgar mind often employ in such case pretended to make boast of humble beginning used subject a mean of constantly reminding friend acquaintance of what have done for while held shrievalty fell to lot to present address to prince regent on occasion received honour of knighthood such be sir christopher blunt gentleman who sate at bottom of table be mr frank curtis sir christopher nephew be tall spare thin sickly looking young man of three twenty with long straight black hair large staring dark eye very bad teeth disagreeable impudent pert expression of countenance be orphan totally dependent upon uncle who have brought up to business inasmuch a have looked upon young man a heir sir christopher however having reached fiftieth year without ever thinking of matrimony be suddenly smitten with miss julia mordaunt lady hatfield friend a miss mordaunt belonged to very ancient though greatly impoverished family sir christopher thought that must gain darling wishnamely obtain standing consideration in fashionable worldby conducting lady to hymeneal altar ardent desire nevertheless kept to a much a possible first object being to get rid of nephew in way for mr frank curtis have acquired considerable influence over uncle latter be too much of moral coward to be able to tell nephew boldly frankly that proposed to change condition passion frank have conceived for miss adelais torrens seemed to furnish knight with opportunity to settle young man thus throw off influence impeded own matrimonial design hence readiness of sir christopher to lend mr torrens five thousand pound a inducement for gentleman to compel portionless daughter to accept mr frank curtis for husband must add that frank have passed six month on continent brief sojourn in france have supplied staple commodity of entire conversational power must forget to observe that be a arrogant boaster a be in reality coward that be so afflicted with vice of mendaciousness must scarcely speak truth by accident third gentleman present in sir christopher splendid dining room be mr howard knight solicitor need not say more relative to individual than that be about five forty year old enjoyed excellent practice be considered fine looking man by lady be noted for devotion to turf table be spread with choice dessert assortment of most exquisite wine to three gentleman appeared to be doing ample justice sir christopher drank copiously because felt particularly well pleased at prospect of getting rid of nephew for whom intended bride have taken furnished beautiful house at clapham frank have frequent recurrence to bottle because felt nervous anxiousand lawyer stuck fast to burgundy because liked take care frank how fill glass too often said mr howard young lady will not find very agreeable presently mind old fellow exclaimed curtis can drink under table day why when be in paris used to think nothing of bottle of brandy with breakfast recollect once betting thirty napoleon with old major of grenadier at boulogne drum major suppose frank said lawyer with smile frank must not so far forget a to associate with drum major observed sir christopher in voice like of man who go about with punch judy show thanks to honest exertion have placed myselfand in placing have placed position will permit to call brilliant know make secret of what be rose from nothingand be proud of if gracious majesty in acknowledgment of humble merit condescended to bestow upon honour of knighthood oh blow old story uncle cried dutiful nephew be telling how laid fifty napoleon with colonel of french engineer must drink two bottle of champagne to one of share what time will horse be describe mr torrens be widower have numbered about five fifty year be tall thin dry looking man with very sallow complexion cold grey eye stern expression of countenance after having long held situation in government office retired with pension just at same period relation died leaving few thousand pound with sum bought beautiful little villa denominated torrens cottage leasehold of land at norwood where set busily to work to build row of house to be called torrens terrace have long made architecture amateur study during leisure hour moment be enabled to retire from situation in ordnance office became possessed of capital resolved to put numerous architectural theory into practice a frequently happens in such matter grew embarrassed work be menaced with stoppage for want of fund when mr curtis became enamoured of eldest daughter whom met at house of of mr torrens relation in london bargain already described be soon after struck between sir christopher blunt mr torrens who did not hesitate to sacrifice daughter happiness to own pecuniary interest unfortunately too for young lady did not regard contemplated union in light of sacrifice at inasmuch a naturally looked upon frank curtis a sir christopher heir not dreaming that worthy knight entertained remotest idea of perpetrating matrimony mr torrens therefore considered that daughter adelais be about to form most eligible connexion although be aware that affection be engaged in quarter acted upon belief that parent must know best how to ensure child happiness two daughter adelais rosamond be charming girl of respective age of eighteen sixteen dark clustering lock deep hazel eye lustrous with liquid light symmetrical figure filled beholder with admiration adelais be now pale melancholy drooping for loathed alliance be in contemplation for herloathed not only because heart be also because manner conversation personal appearance of frank curtis be revolting in estimation rosamond possessed rich complexion in glowed innate feeling of soul animating imparting to feature of beautiful face additional charm be naturally confidant of sister whose hard fate deeply deplored many be plan amiable girl have devised discussed with view to overcome father cruel pertinacity in insisting on sacrifice of adelais to frank curtis of project have failed involved proceeding repugnant to pure artless mind for instance have thought of abandoning paternal roof endeavouring to seek livelihood by needlework in safe retirement then adelais must not permit rosamond to dare misfortune of world by flying from home shethe younger sisterhad at least personal motive to desert rosamond on side must not allow adelais to set out alone again clandestine marriage between adelais lover be often debated young man urged himselfbut daughter dreaded father eternal anger thus project have be abandoned also to be brief dreaded moment be now at hand seal of misery be about to be set on roll of elder maiden destiny who be lover of adelais handsome generous hearted honourable young man occupying situation in very government office where mr torrens have served for many year although clarence villiers be so far provided for have prospect of rising rapidly on account of steady habit assiduous attention to employment yet be at present only poor clerk with ninety pound year have capital mr torrens a have seen required capital thus frank curtis be preferred to clarence villiers can not quit description without alluding to ardent affection existed between sister having lost mother in childhood father being almost constantly from home throughout day be naturally thrown entirely upon other for companionship illimitable confidence sprang up between thema confidence more intimate far than even usually subsists between sister because confidence on part of adelais rosamond extended to mutual outpouring of most trivial a well a of most important thought hope aspiration thus reader will cease to be astonished that when adelais in anguish of heart have contemplated flight from paternal roof a only alternative save hateful marriage rosamond insisted upon accompanying much a loved revered father be prepared to sacrifice even filial affection filial duty for other sake feeling may be looked upon a one involving grievous fault on side be not however le firmly rooted in mindsfor be to other illustration chapter xii adelais rosamond sir christopher blunt mr howard frank curtis be soon seated in mr torrens comfortable parlour wall of be adorned with infinite variety of architectural plan set in carved oaken frame cheerful fire blazed in grate wine be placed upon table traveller be speedily a much at ease a must wish a host must render young lady be in apartment mr torrens having desired to remain in drawing room while commercial part of projected matrimonial arrangement be being settled in parlour when usual complimentary phrase have be exchanged sir christopher have observed that weather be remarkably fine very colda proposition to mr torrens entirely assentedfor somehow people never do contradict other when commenting on subjectwhen also glass two of wine have be imbibed by knight inquired whether mr torrens happened to be acquainted with captain spark answer be negative sir christopher then began to relate adventure of evening although be constantly interrupted by nephew who be anxious to interpolate in narrative certain saving clause respecting own valour towards highwayman worthy knight nevertheless succeeded at length in bringing tale to end be clear said mr torrens that be first duped then robbed by infamous scoundrel have notion how must have learnt enough of pending arrangement to be enabled to talk so familiarly with regard to when first introduced to that puzzle dear sir returned sir christopher be likely to continue to puzzle uncle observed frank for whole business defies conjecture remember when be in france villain evidently knew that must leave town with considerable sum of money in possession said torrens aim be to get did get too not without deuced good thrashing into bargain cried frank be consolation dare say captain spark a call must gladly be thrashed hour in day on same term observed lawyer think that when little business be concluded must do well to return to london give information at bow street a speedily a possible by mean exclaimed sir christopher must keep tale to ourselves if got into newspaper with particular must only make look ridiculous might punish man must never get back money nono let matter dropfor sake thank proposed marriage took placeand thus terminated commercial part of business four gentleman then proceeded to drawing room where two young lady be seated adelais be excessively pale when odious mr frank curtis tripped smirkingly up to taking fair hand pressed to lipshis breath heated with wine rendered offensive by fume of cigar steaming upon delicate skinthe maiden recoiled a if from something loathsome father who observed narrowly cast upon rapid ireful glance adelais exerted strenuously to recover composure like victim about to be sacrificed at altar of avenging god suffered admirer to lead to seat in remote part of room placing by side frank curtis darted triumphant look at howard sir christopher a much a to say just see how successfully be going to play amiable in quarter then turning towards lovely adelais whose large blue eye be bent timidly down whose bosom palpitated with variety of painful emotion observed in what considered to be most endearing whisper come sweet gal cheer up there be nothing to be frightened at in marriage know that be not quite lady man will get on better together by bye see dear have always be used to manly sport to seeking adventure where curiosityas if be anxious to discover by expression of face whether be indeed serious in insufferable rhodomontade with sought to captivate therethat right dear gal said curtis mistaking motive of from room rosamond who while engaged in conversation with father sir christopher mr howard at other end of room have never ceased to watch sister with most lively interest now immediately followed almost heart broken girl moment sister have reached bed chamber adelais threw into rosamond arm exclaiming will never marry himi will die sooner have offended inquired rosamond affectionately embracing disconsolate sister need not ask changing countenanceyour anxious looksyour convulsive movementsand then tear while sate by oh very soul revolt against cried adelais emphatically conflict of agonising emotion painfully expressed on countenance at firstwhen approached meit required exertion of fortitude be capable to subdue feeling of aversion disgustof bitter woe heart felt miserywith be agitatedbut when coarse language met earsoh rosamond exclaimed distracted maiden must flyi must avoid dreadful fateor heart will break at moment mr torrens slowly opened door entered room countenance wore expression gave evidence that anger compunction be maintaining fierce struggle in breast former feeling be rapidly obtaining ascendancy rashdisobedient girl exclaimed fixing stern cold eye upon adelais who still clung to younger sister what signifies folly spare mespare dearest father cried adelais suddenly tearing from rosamond embrace falling on knee before sire can not marry that horrible man mr torrens bit lip almost till blood came listen to dear father continued despairing girl joining hand together while cheek be of marble whiteness unanimated by tinge of vital colouringi be feeling of nature who be ever ready to sacrifice consideration to cause of medical science speedily banished hesitation having convinced that georgiana slept so profoundly that there be chance of placethe only time be ever known to commit burglaryand such be fright georgiana experienced that for week month afterwards family frequently trembled lest reason have received shock must indeed have of womanand raising woman one remove from nature of angel chapter xix mr frank curtis pleasant adventure about hour previous to visit of lord ellingham mr frank curtis be lounging along piccadilly intelligence for purpose of assuring of sincerity of promise that must endeavour to meet in eveningfor young lady be of intriguing disposition flattered that have captivated very great at event very wealthy personbut when saw thus precipitately rush towards entrance drew back endeavoured to shut door frank be however too quick for fairly thrust into hall closing street door behind for god sake go away sir said charlotte imploringly not till have have one kissjust one cried frank threw arm round lady maid neck oh do let go sirthe servant will comeand will be ruined murmured vainly struggling with young man who not only considered adventure capital joke be also excited by present contact with pretty girl glued lip to hers pressed closely to when loud double knock suddenly echoed through paramour hence sale of ringhence theft of diamond arthur now remembered promise to mr gordon to make acquainted with particular might discover relative to business how must fulfil pledge shrank from aggravate offence by imparting result to with endeavour to banish subject from memory turn attention to more pleasurable topic hastily pursued way homeward chapter xxii alarmthe letter in meantime esther de medina have retired to own apartment immediately after strange painful exciting scene have taken place with father seating upon sofa burst into violent flood of tear delicate tinge of carnation usually appeared beneath clear transparent olive hue of complexion be now chased away be palevery pale grief be evidently intense anguish overwhelmed spirit oh esther if thou art indeed guiltyfrailfallen being eye can not refuse tear of pity to thy lost condition nofor never have even enamoured poet in dream conceived form face more perfect than nature have bestowed upon there appeared too such virgin freshness about charming creature who be just bursting into halo of innocence seemed to surround herso much modesty so much propriety characterised slightest attitude most unimportant word to contemplate for few minute yet retain stubborn conviction that be wanton amounted almost to impossibility nowto behold plunged in griefalone with own wretched thought weepingwho must believe that lip on purity appeared to dwell have ever be pressed by of seducerthat sylph like form whose sweeping undulating outline be so gracefully set forth by mournfulness of attitude have ever unveiled beauty on bed of illicit lovethat rude hand of licentiousness have ever disturbed treasure of bosom so carefully concealedwho must believe nevertheless say reader appearance be so completely against herthe evidence of guilt seem so damningthat ala there be not hope of innocence let continue thread of narrative for hour did esther remain absorbed in most profound afflictiona prey to thought reminiscence of very painful nature at length rose abruptly evidently strove to conquer grief wiped away tear from fine black eye advanced towards window from behind curtain of gazed into street with view of directing thought into new channel suddenly idea struck hastened to writing desk at sate down began to pen letter while be thus engaged crystal drop ever anon started from eye snammera thief chapter xxiv castle street long acre to north of long acre run castle streetfor many year notorious a nest of thief prostitute juvenile vagabond of most degraded description at period of be writing person of name of thompson ownedand probably still possessesthe lodging house numbered in castle street individual resided in mint street borough where have similar house in addition to others in buckeridge street st giles house in buckeridge street must make up one hundred bed in castle street sixty at lodging house of description room be filled with low truckle bed having straw mattress two coarse sheet blanket rug price of bed be threepence need scarcely be observed that men woman child sleep together in filthy receptacle without slightest regard to decency modesty sometimes when lodging house be particularly crowded three person will share one bedor motif of economy frequently compel poor family thus to herd together be by mean uncommon occurrence for grown up girl to sleep with father mother with brothersa poor married couple will even share bed with male friendand shame be known who can define where shade of doubtful honesty confirmed roguery meet blend in low lodging house labouring man be in nightly company with habitual thiefhis wife a yet uncorrupted daughter be forced to associate with lowest prostitute how long will wife remain faithfulthat daughter taint very child who breathe that infected atmosphere soon become lost triumph in degradation principal frequenter patron of low lodging house be regular customer consist of thief prostitute beggar coiner burglar hawker casual lodger be labouring men family whom poverty compels to sleep in such horrible place hawker make great deal of money can buy steel pen for d gross pocket book for d snuff box for d penknife for d on article can gain one hundred per cent many of hawker consider nine ten shilling to be only reasonable by mean good day work of woman who frequent lodging house in castle street elsewhere who have child of own hire infant for d d day obtain in shape of alms at least four five shilling day female of class care not whether husband lover work remain idle for boast that can keep themand keep well too of woman knit cap in street make more money than who merely trust to child accompanying a motive of charitable person compassion in low lodging house of castle street wherever else may be found most frightful dissipation a well a most appalling immorality prevails drunkenness be presiding genius of den how much have strong drink to answer for be strong drink help to fill gaolsthe hulksthe asylum for wretched diseased insane be strong drink call forth so many sigh such bitter tearsshortens existenceperpetuates family diseaseand foster malady of specie of kind strong drink often place criminal in condemned cell reduces beautiful girl to barter charm for bread strong drink strews land with old rag bleaching bone let temperance moderation be guide of allfor be result of intemperance habitual drunkenness behold in poor low neighbourhood of london if ask reader by what sign be to recognise will tell youby leaden eyesthe tottering stepsthe shaking limbsthe haggard countenancesthe feverish browsthe parched lipsthe dry furred tonguethe hot pestilential breathand tremulous voice of confirmed votary of strong drink apoplexypalsydelirium tremensenlarged liverossified heartimpaired digestionyellow jaundicecancerous stomachand dropsyall attend upon strong drink hideous catalogue of evil includes also broken limbsfearful accident gushing woundsas well a many of hereditary malady be handed down from father unto son in earlier chapter ridiculed phrase of merry england oh be merry to see so much miseryso much crimeso much oppressionso much sorrowso much absence of sympathy if be joyous then of surety be merriest country london merriest city on face of earth if man can find music in cry issue from crowded prison wail flow from barbarous workhouse then may dance long heartily to melodyfor never cease if poverty can excite felicitous sensation within heaven know need never be sad if crime can bring smile to lip countenance need never wear melancholy aspect if can slake thirst in heart wrung tear of human agony need never step out of way to look for fountain spring in light england be indeed merry for observer of human for unfortunate girl be now in complete state of intoxication revolting a contemplation of such scene a just described must be to rightly constituted mind be nevertheless requisite to introduce into work a present detail prove how necessary be to establish in great metropolis cheap well conducted lodging house for use of poor honest family can not be done by private speculator because efficient management must only be secured by legislative enactment government then must direct attention to very important subject poor man be compelled to quit native town village in province come to london to seek for work be accompanied by wife daughter penury compels to fix upon cheapest lodging can find cheap lodging house can not be respectable one landlord landlady have time meanseven if posse before eye find hemmed in by moral corruptionsurrounded by temptationexcited by new desiresand encouraged to go astray by companion how can leave sink of impurity otherwise than impure how can quit abode of infamy otherwise than infamous many high born lady have succumbed to seducer under circumstance venialunder influence admitting far le amount of extenuation be government with consent of legislature to establish lodging house for poor honest person immense benefit must be conferred upon class fearful progress of immorality must receive check at least in one point respectability of such institution might be ensured by placing trustworthy married couple at head applying system of rule must enforce regular hour exclude ardent spirit only permit moderate quantity of beer to be brought in for use of individual likewise empower magistrate to punish who might be brought before charged with breaking regulation otherwise subverting wholesome discipline enjoined thief prostitute bad character must not attempt to obtain admission to establishment if descriptionno more than person enjoying competency must endeavour to become inmate of workhouse scene of debauchery unbounded license alone suit abandoned male femalesand thus guarantee must exist for respectable management of institution must save honest poor from low lodging house of london footnote following be glossary be about one o'clock when old death have entered house in turnmill street saint paul proclaimed hour of three a rainford crossed smithfield market chapter xxxiii mr martha slingsby reader who be acquainted with west end of great metropolis of british empire can not have failed to notice air of gloomy grandeur characterises aristocratic mansion of old burlington street dingy brick frontsthe massive door of sombre colourthe window darkened by heavy hangingsand dead silence seems to prevail within produce upon passer by strange almost melancholy effect there be nothing bustlingnothing cheerful in street on brightest day of summer aspect be coldmournfulprison like seems to be last refuge of aristocracy of old schoolthat aristocracy still cling to ancient prejudice haughty notion exclusive pridean aristocracy find influence day narrowing into smaller compass in proportion a of mass expands around god grant thing in shape of hereditary aristocracy may shortly expire altogethercrushed by weight of new interest modern civilisation in one of gloomy looking house of old burlington street dwelt mr slingsbya lady of about forty two who enhancing by art natural conservation of beauty truly miraculous in female of age seemed at least five six year younger hair be very dark a wore sweetest french cap parisian fashion must suggest be invested with air bewilders common observer between admirable coquettishness matronly sedateness complexion be clear delicate careful regular use of cosmetic concealed incipient wrinkle appeared at corner of eye lid teeth be perfect white even figure though upon large scale be maintained in fine symmetry by skill of dress maker have naturally splendid bust a usually wore very high dress be better enabled to maintain appearance of youthful firmness in spite of prominent expansion have experienced a lady increased in year mr martha slingsby be aunt of mr clarence villiers lover of adelais torrens when very young be sacrificed by parent to gentleman double age who have acquired fortune while lost health in india shortly after union circumstance compelled mr slingsby to return to calcutta youthful wife accompanied there remained about eight year at expiration of period mr slingsby died of broken heart immense wealth having be suddenly entirely swept away by failure of great mercantile banking establishment in anglo indian capital mr slingsby however found friend in person of sir henry courtenaya baronet who have long held high office in council of india who be about to return to england having relinquished care of employment in public service be upwards of fifty at perioda widowerbut having family of young child moment that misfortune of mr slingsby be reported to by mutual friend sir henry proposed to that must enter family to supply a far a possible attention of mother whom child have lost offer be gratefully accepted mr slingsby who have offspring of own returned to england with baronet for year after arrival in london remained in family of sir henry courtenaywhere appeared to be treated a near relation not a dependant when boy girl be old enough to be placed at school removed to house in old burlington street in now find rumour declared that be enabled to take so handsome establishment in consequence of sudden unexpected recovery of portion of fortune be supposed to have be irretrievably swallowed up in failure of bank at calcutta loss of have broken husband heart at event paid way regularlyand be famed for numerous charity calumny have never assailed for be so regular in religious dutiesso retired in mode of lifeso ready to assist deserving poorso constant in donation to humane philanthropic institutionsand so zealous patroness of missionary bible society that neighbour looked history of life chapter xxxviii history of jacob smith earliest recollection be associated with occupation of playing day long in street in company with other infant be in upper whitecross street st luke where other child lived with woman who pretended to keep boarding school at received child to live with altogether for one shilling eightpence week used to turn out early in morning with piece of hard mouldy bread to nibble for breakfast fetch home again when grew dusk in evening must then give piece of bread for supper went to bed what bed few old sack thrown over heap of straw in little room about six foot long by four half in width served upwards of dozen child a sleeping room there used to cry to rest famished with insufficiency of foodand awake again in morning to undergo fresh privation said there be about twelve of under care of mother maggsas be called chiefly belonged to very poor parent who be engaged day long at work be therefore glad to get rid of child who must otherwise only be encumbrance to few be however illegitimate offspring of poor servant girl in place nearly have parent who came to see from time to time perhaps gave few penny be not however so fortunate a rest for one ever came to see meat least be aware ofuntil be about nine year old heard that twenty penny week allowed for board lodging be left regularly for mother maggs at neighbouring chandler shop saturday morning mother maggs seemed to think have really friendsfor though bullied pretty well bullied ten thousand time more than rest habit of turning dozen little child of whom be only just able to walk into street in way have described be not likely to be always unattended with disagreeable consequence sometimes child be run over severely wounded killed in latter case coroner inquest ever sate on body exposure of mother maggs neglect towards must have drawn attention of parochial authority towards when death happened in way old woman used to put body into sack carry distance into country where must sink in pond ditch often however corpse of dead child have be allowed to remain in room till be quite putrid mother maggs not having time inclination to remove before on occasion who be alive in room be so frightened to be with dead body in dark that shrieked screamed till noise reached old woman ear in public house next door so savage be at being disturbed in gin gossip that have half murdered by way of making hold tongue sometimes child be lost if parent on being informed of expressed regret anger mother maggs must take trouble to find again if not did not put out of way respecting matter in addition to boarding house for child let out lodging to person of sex a be not particular so long a got paid house be nothing more le than common brothel be always saying have time to do thing ought to be done if being day in public house be necessary duty certainly have time for other purpose though not often tipsy be never actually soberbut in constant state of muzziness liquor did not improve temper on contrary made irritablesometimes ferocious have seen fight with other woman until face be covered with long seam made by finger nail pouring with blood can not suppose that thing have just told that be going to tell directly in connexion with mother maggs establishment be noticed understood by when be quite child there must remember that stayed at den until be nine in course of year saw made deep impression on mind what be then dark unintelligible to have since be made clear plain by experience by reflection on scene circumstance will wonder how wretched companion managed to live since only have piece of bread night morning kept body soul together in variety of way chiefly feeding like swine upon offal remnant of vegetable cooked raw that found in street there be dust bin in court where mother maggs house be in whitecross street day just upon one o'clock used to crowd round waiting till neighbour came to empty potato peeling refuse of meal into general receptacle then must greedily appropriate to use scrap not even very poorest of poor chose to eat potato peeling most poor family skin potato after be boiled be quite dainty to head bone of fish such like refuse be also welcome to empty stomach then be accustomed to go prowling about street to snatch slice of raw bacon bit of cheese from board in front of butter shop steal turnip carrot from old woman stall else lay unlawful hand upon horse flesh in cat meat shop last article of food be much fancied by be comparatively easy to steal when did get such prize a large lump of carrion with stick thrust through felt a happy for time being a if have found treasure then used to conceal in dark court take bite roundeach in turnuntil be gone be afraid disgust with detail desired to tell story in own wayand want to understand dreadful mode of life thousand of poor child lead in wealthiest city in world be sure when have thought of since when see little boy girl paddling in neglected manner about street blood run cold at idea while human being be riding in carriage living in palace others be prowling in low neighbourhood happy if can steal lump of putrid carrion may next ask what did for clothesit being very clear that mother maggs must not supply with wearing apparel out of twenty penny week wellthe fact be scarcely have clothes on at a for cap shoe stocking declare solemnly never wore one of article from earliest period of recollection until be nine year old little ragged frock be yes be winter where did even ragged frock come from really hardly know be at loss to say exactly how did get even one garment sometimes child must be taken away by parent who might perhaps bring decent clothing then cast off rag in case must fall to lot of most ragged of who be left behind now then slop seller in neighbourhood must give one of old frock be useless to occasionally must steal one when must may ask why did not steal shoe also so did if opportunity served then must do without shoe eldest of lot of be on occasion commissioned to sell plunder at rag shop to afford mean to buy little better food than usually fell in way occurrence be however rareso rare that constituted perfect holiday in hideous monotony of famished livesfor shopkeeper in poor neighbourhood be constantly on alert to watch movement of juvenile prowler age of child under care of mother maggs averaged from three to ten eldest of course bullied youngest while mr maggs bullied misery did not make little one friendly together on contrary fought quarrelled ill treated other a much a must must relate to one anecdotealthough now shudder when think of have often since shed tear of repentance there be one boy named tib tucker about eight year old who used to behave in more merciless manner towards than rest did must take away bread from whenever caught eating apart alone laid to many theft on mother maggs cupboard committed false report got many many good beating from enraged hag in word boy tyranny became so insufferable that be resolved to adopt desperate measure to put end to be then little more than six year old fiendish instinct of revenge however urged to act secreted pin about rag one day when tib tucker be trying to take away morsel of mouldy bread mother maggs have just given suddenly thrust pin into right eye screamed in dreadful agony brought down mother maggs into court have not run awayterror rather horror at what have done nailed to spot bully tale be soon told expected to be half murdered by dreadful woman to surprise suddenly took partdeclared that have shown proper spiritand consoled tib tucker with assurance that if must only permit to operate on other eye in same manner must prove perfect fortune to parent 'there be nothing like blind child to draw alms said 'but one eye goodyou must be blind of remember word a well a if have only be uttered yesterday more so a seemed to be propheticas will explain presently terrible vengeance have taken upon persecutor who lost eye in consequence not only awed in future made feared by rest existence grew somewhat le wretchedat least in reference to treatment experienced from companion mother maggs also seemed to change towards through fear admiration at what termed bey spirit ' can not say be le bullied by herbut not whit better fed about six week after incident have related parent of tib tucker returned to london from country where have be harvesting passed evening with mother maggs great quantity of gin be sent for from public house afterwards learnt from companion for a to myself kept out of way through fear of being punished by boy parent for vengeance have wreaked upon when be quite dark returned to house stole up to miserable garret where companion be already huddled together on straw old sack tib tucker be amongst for heard talking about promise parent have made to take with into country where be going again in few day one of eldest girlsfor forgot to say mother maggs juvenile boarder be of sexesasked what parent have said about accident replied that have laughed at have declared that must turn to good account scarcely have thus spoken when door opened maggs appeared with candle in hand ordering tib tucker to get up follow added that father mother have little treat in store for have meant all along to sit up to supper tib be overjoyed at news made haste to accompany mother maggs to lower room where have left parent in miserable dark garret envied boy who have good supper in view rememberoh well do remember how cried night to think that friend ever came to see that indeed be ignorant whether parent be alive not have often asked mother maggs whether knew father mother invariably received cuff by way of replyand therefore at length grew tired of putting question there be however time when wretchedforlornabandoned condition almost broke heart for young a be knew that there be boy girl in world much better off than while tib tucker be absent other child began to discourse amongst saying how lucky be to come in for good supper then set to work to guess what meal be likely to consist of on sudden dreadful shriek echoed through house startled in miserable garret there laycrouching huddling nearer to other holding breath not daring to utter word filled with vague alarm a if dreadful danger hung over at length sleep came to relief when awoke in morning ran down into court first object that met view be wretched boy tib tucker being led away by parentsfor be now blind of eye be so frightened that ran into street where wandered about dayforgetting even pang of hunger have suddenly conceived dreadful terror of mother maggs have not dared to present at room door to obtain usual morsel of bread along with rest be very rainy day yet remember that roved roved about whole neighbourhood at one time cry bitterlyat stupified though still moving about like sleep walker when evening came on be so tired hungry be forced to retrace return to straw filth of close garret month year passedand reached age of nine last few month opened eye to more wickedness than have a yet known dreamt of just now told that mr maggs juvenile boarder consisted of boy girl believe understood that huddled together in same garret be regular pig sty in wallowed like swine like of brute also be conduct of eldest boy girl if other room in house be used death be along aware of real nature of mother maggs house of manner in reared child entrusted to man of experience must not help knowing be not probable that be deceived by lying statement made to relative to manner in have be treatedalthough took a far a recollect notice of word in fact have intentionally placed in position to learn everything be badto fulfil apprenticeship of petty vice might enter on career of crime whereof profit be to be own taking now in somewhat kind manner by hand led down to st paul churchyard although having hitherto lived within mile of place have never be there before be true that from garret window of mother maggs dwelling have sometimes seen huge dark dome surmounted by cross shone like gold on bright sunny day have never thought of asking what wasnor have notion that be so near often too in silence of night when cold hunger kept awake in hideous den have deep glorious sound of mighty bell booming through air proclaiming hour fallen on ear still have never thought of inquiring clock be that struck so loud be so tediously long in striking thus when entered saint paul churchyard for first time in company with old death be struck with amazement to find at foot a be of tremendous giant of architecture just at moment too mighty bell began to strike six startedfor young a be that well known sound though never heard so near before re awakened thousand conflicting thought within misery wretchedness have endured at mother maggs house rushed to mind again shed tear a reflected on poor child whom have left behind there oh mr rainfordif kind benevolent person have taken then under protection care taught to do good practise virtue a old death be teaching to do evil practise vice feelyes feel must not have be unworthy such humane attention let not interrupt thread of narrative more than can help mr bone kept by hand walked slowlyvery slowly through churchyard pointing out to beautiful shop telling that if be good boy only did what told must soon be rich enough to be able to walk into shop treat to jewellery fine clothes anything else might fancy assurance gave most heart felt joy already began to determine in mind what must buy when happy period of such affluence might arrive on sudden gay reverie be interrupted by old death who dragging hastily to entrance of passage leading into paternoster row pointed to elderly gentleman standing at shop window at corner where passage joined st paul churchyard 'do see handkerchief peeping out of coat pocket ' demanded old death hastily'yes ' replied'then go get will give sixpence if bring to without old fellow perceiving that have taken itbeixpence be inexhaustible treasure such a have often heard of seldom seen never touched without moment hesitation proceeded to execute task be winter time though evening be dark yet shop window be brilliantly lighted be against mebut on other hand place be crowded with people passing way circumstance be in favour old death stood watching at entrance of passageno doubt ready to glide away in case of being detected skill in cribbing victual other little article in upper whitecross street have be so well practised that only required to apply same art to rather more difficult branch of thieving to be completely successful success far exceeded old death expectation for when returned to in passage be enabled to place in hand not only old gentleman pocket handkerchief also gold snuff box may suppose that mr bone be well pleased with testified approval of conduct by placing shilling in hand must scarcely believe be indeed possessor of such sum immediately made up mind to ease a many old gentleman a possible of handkerchief snuff box a long a deed so simple be so generously rewarded old death now conducted to drury lane showing public house said 'jacob though young boy be very good clever boy think can trust if assure that will do just a tell will give treat gave assurance required'well then walk boldly into public house run said 'and ask for bed will have to pay two penny for fourpence left be to buy breakfast in morning woman of house will give for money if people meet there ask question say a little a possible speak
