of filthy lodging house swarm in castle street at place where procured half of bed companion being young girl of thirteen who have already be prostitute eighteen month received further lesson in school of vice in morning obtained cup of coffee couple of round of thick bread butter for fourpence having disposed of hastened to appointment with old death be waiting for at corner of street asked great many question about people have seen at lodging house satisfied a far a must through lingering feeling of shame did not tell that prostitute have be bed fellow desired to follow at considerable distance to mind not lose sight of then led for long walk about west end of londonproceeding slowly so that might have opportunity of looking at shop obtaining knowledge of position of different street in word might be able to find way about by time at about one o'clock went into public house where have something to eat drink rested for two three hour then set out on wandering again at about seven o'clock in evening came to halt in st giles where old death gave money to enter penny theatre have not practised hand at stealing thing day long because have not instructed to do so neither from moment did ever put ability in way to test in presence so suppose that little affair in st paul churchyard be merely experiment made to enable to judge whether have talent in art of conveyancing not in fact have tried to ascertain whether must be made useful finding must object be now to introduce to scene place where moral might become confirmed in iniquity where there be sphere for exercise of ability illustration need not therefore dwell on part of story for in few day use old death calculated to make of be fully explained be to thieve where must when must evening be to meet employer at place that must appoint hand over article so stolen when be to give enough money for following day expense be moreover charged to enlist in same service a many boy a must now for first time learnt that hitherto unknown protector be named mr benjamin bone companion soon informed that be famous fence usually bearing denomination of 'old death ' must not forget to state that employer counselled never to allude to in manner unless be in way of enlistment a just now mentioned said 'it will perhaps happen jacob that constable bow street runner may catch hold of sometimes breathe word about will always get out of scrape if on other hand confess that be employed by that be in service will do good must cast off for ever indeed must leave to rot in prison whereas hold tongue may happen will find best friend ' promised to obey now behold at tender age of nine companion of worst juvenile pickpocket pickpocket link have to bind to society world be harvest field in considered that have right to glean whenever member of fraternity got 'into trouble ' clubbed together to maintain well in prison if be condemned to punishment looked upon a piece of bad luckand be found that companion be a reckless improvident a must beever fulfilling old adage 'light come light go used to play at 'pitch toss ' skittle stake varying according to mean at moment from halfpenny to sovereign be not often enabled to join in sport because old death kept rather short have obtained astonishing influence over dared not attempt to deceive sometimes thought of appropriating portion of 'day work ' to own private use image haunted like ghostand must not do constantly told that have mean of ascertaining robbery be committed who perpetrated that if attempted to play trick must be sure to be found out believed himfor occasionally gave proof of most extraordinary knowledge of be passing must say for instance 'your friend one filched snuff box pocket book yesterday in regent street gave employer book pawned box on own account now mark ' old death must add boy will get into trouble soon one will help out of again'and prophecy must come true be therefore alarmed at mere idea of deceiving old deathor rather attempting to deceive though companion often jeered urged to beet up on own account lacked moral courage to break with mr benjamin bone be very expert in art of pickpocketing seldom have to disappoint old death when met in evening if did gave money same suppose be too useful to to be lost perhaps knew that always did best allowed three shilling sixpence for day expense money be usually laid out in way will now explain breakfastpint of coffee d loaf of bread d s d butter d dinnerbeef d potato d bread d beer d teahalf pint tea d toast d supperleg of beef d bread d potato d beer d gin water s bed d leaving d day for casual expense allowance of s d may perhaps seem rather liberal be seldom that earnings during day be not of sufficient value to produce old death at least fifteen twenty shillingsand often great deal more there be various grade class of juvenile thief most aristocratic amongst be who have be admitted into fraternity of swell moabites who have taken hand in housebreaking next class on descending scale be pickpocket who dive only for purse watch pocket book snuff box who must scorn to touch handkerchief third section consists of who dive for thing can get whose chief game doe consist of fourth division comprises shop sneak area sneak former enter shop slily crawl in on hand knee to rob till latter get down area step enter kitchen whence walk off with thing can lay hand on same section also includes shop bouncer who boldly enters shop while affecting to bargain for good purloins article easily abstracted fifth division be made up of thief who prowl about shop door who break glass in shop window to abstract good who rob mercer by introducing bent wire through hole of shutter bolt draw out lace silk riband sixth last division grade consists of very lowest description of thievessuch a pudding snammers who loiter about cook shop when customer be issuing forth with plate of meat pudding pudding alone a be often case pounce on eatable run away with before person robbed have even time to recover from astonishment miserable thief sell can not eat to other boy thus manage to get few halfpenny to pay for lodging mention circumstance to sir because believe that can have ever found in position to have seen what be now relating on one occasion certain robbery in be concerned made noise bow street runner got pretty accurate description of learnt from old death who advised to go up into holy landwhich need scarcely tell be st gilesbeand remain quiet there for few day until thing be pretty well blown over followed advice be very welcome to because mr bone gave plenty of money to make comfortable be not expected to do 'work ' for at least week happened to take up quarter at lodging house in lawrence lane found chiefly used by very lowest irish never did see such set a be filth misery drunkenness be familiar enough to heaven knowsbut there saw such filth so much misery yet such constant such horrible drunkenness be perfectly shockedand required something strong to shock mr rainford house be brothel daughter of man who kept be own father best customer most dreadful debauchery prevailed there old woman used to bring young boy old men young girlsmere childrento beastly stew have seen dozen men woman dancing together stark naked in largest room in house of brother sister on occasion saw irish wake in same place corpse be that of prostitute be laid upon floor with candle placed round friend relative of deceased woman got so awfully drunk that commenced dreadful battle tumbling about in direction over dead body stayed at lodging house in st giles about week never went out except of evening for about hour when looked in at milberrybethe flash public house in lawrence lane be ever there sir wellit be worth while just to give look in time be passing public room be fitted up with fine table high back partition fronting door be large black board whereon following inscription may be read pipe ca afford to give if by trade wish to live liquor proof measure just excuse sir can not trust 'to prevent mistake liquor to be paid for on delivery a soon a little affair have driven up into st giles be blown over returned to old haunt fell in again with old companion be now ten year old be considered so cunning clever old death began to employ in other way besides thieving if required to know thing concerning particular party must set to dog watch to make inquiry about sometimes be sent to flash public house frequented by gentleman servant who be accustomed to arrange with cracksman for burglary in master housesor 'put up crack a be called public house be principally at west endthe most famous be in duke street manchester square portland street there got into conversation with servant merely acted part of listener information must glean be of course conveyed to mr bone who doubt knew how to turn to greatest advantage be also visitor to flash house in london at different time on various errand for old death more business increased more necessary did become to at period be not so near stingy a since became whenever succeeded in difficult undertaking must reward with something like liberality know whether actually liked himbut be certain that exercised immense power over mind be in turn much looked up to by companion considered old death lieutenant moreover be so skilful a pickpocket that one must excel few equal have qualification necessary for arta light tread delicate sense of touch firm nerve for be then strong healthy now be sicklywastedand have within seed of incurable malady used at time to wear shoe of very light makeas indeed do nearly professional pickpocket be very easy for one who be thing of acute observer to recognise juvenile pickpocket in street countenance wear affected determination of purpose always seem to be walking forward a if bent on urgent object of business never stop in street save to 'work ' if wish to confer with pal if meet friend dive into low public house court alley knowing pickpocket never loiters about in street because be very first thing draw suspicion glance towards lad have readand how came to be able to read will presently tell youin newspaper that many people have notion pickpocket use instrument in easing gentleman lady of purse other article of value only instrument ever knew pickpocket to use used be good pair of small scissors will either rip pocket up cut off in twinkling do believe that london thief be very worst in whole world profligacy commences so early there be thing to harden imprisonment raise into hero amongst companion only fancy boy of twelve thirteen perhapsor even youngerplaced behind huge massive bar ten elephant must not pull down of course think that must be very clever fellow at least very important one that law be compelled to adopt such wonderful precaution to restrain belief that society must entertain marvellous dread of ability that boy too be superior in eye of whole fraternity of thief whose punishment be heaviest lad who have be tried at old bailey think much more of than one who have only passed through ordeal of session very pomp of justicethe idea that judge barrister in gown wig must be assembled for sake of boythat old bailey street must be crowded with newspaper reporter must be anxious to take notesthat spectator must pay shilling to obtain sitting in courtin word whole ceremony circumstance of criminal tribunal actually tend to imbue juvenile thief with feeling of self importance now might not very feeling be acted upon to good beneficial purposeto advancement of industry honest emulation think so society never seems to adopt really useful measure to reformit content with punishing may be surprised to hear such reflection come from lip who be better able to judge than one who have passed through entire ordeal here jacob paused then inquired if be wearying tom rain with narrative so far from doing so good fellow replied highwayman that although have several thing to attend to mean to stop hear to end come drink glass of wine there now will be better able to proceed will light cigarfor fancy can attend more earnestly while smoking rainford once more settled in comfortable posture lad pursued narrative in following manner footnote although aim be to render history of jacob smith regular connected narrative of initiation of neglected child in way of vice career of crime there be necessarily many phase in history of juvenile iniquity can not be introduced into text a must be impossible that boy who be telling story must have gone through scene alluded to must therefore farther illustrate aim by mean of few note derived from authentic source course be more inclined to pursue inasmuch a hope that episode formed by history of jacob smith may have effect of directing public attention more seriously than ever to awful nature extent of juvenile depravity in metropolis mr mile in report to house of lord on poverty mendicity crime place on record following observation woman girl in district live with men a long a can agree together until one other be imprisoned transported very child be prostitute living with fancy lad be difficult to say be most degraded men woman girl boy be thus that suppose crime be more engendered in low neighbourhood where poorest most idle congregate now beg to continue remark upon second head namely neglect of parent various pursuit of parent call from home during greater portion of day child be left to play idle in street associating with other lad of more experience than until seeing hearing how easy be to steal commence career of crime unchecked on one hand applauded on other there be parent who turn child out morning to provide for not caring by what mean procure subsistence so that expense of feeding doe not abstract from mean of procuring gin beer other parent require child to bring home specified sum night to obtain must beg thieve others hire out child to beggar for d day cripple be considered worth d many woman hire child in arm about same age to pas off in public thoroughfare a twin group of young neglected vagabond herd together theft becomes study even if child be well disposed be not probable that must escape contagion of such bad example there be community of child who live be separated from person more advanced in year moreover there be so rapid so certain communication among over metropolis that if discover of slang flash word to be known out of circle will substitute in course of day two will be adopted by fraternity there be lodging house exclusively for accommodation public house be chiefly supported by custom landlord of sort of establishment be ever ready to purchase plunder may bring with neglect of parent on one hand faculty to crime on other hand can be expected that child can resist temptation wonder must be if boy be honest conclusion therefore be that neglect of parent in low neighbourhood render nursery of crime number of boy in london who live by plunder be veryvery considerable thus society be maintaining at great expense in shape of prison expense by value of property steal especially when be considered that receiver never give one quarter value there be not boy thief who on average doe not expend s per diem footnote in first series of mystery of london vol ii ch cxcii there be detailed account of association denominated forty thief soon after weekly number containing that chapter appeared be inundated with letter chiefly expressing unqualified disbelief of astonishing particular recorded in respect to forty thief answered contained real name address of writer assuring that detail related be strictly true that actually possessed printed copy of regulation by forty thief be governed still most of described a belonging to association denominated 'forty thief whose head quarter be in mint southwark take opportunity of assuring reader that of what find recorded in mystery of london farfar more be based on fact than might at first suspect footnote mr mile in report from have previously quoted say in considering subject of juvenile delinquency be requisite to take into account various cause compel to be vicious though must condemn still must regret that efficient mean have be adopted to prevent lamentable evil young thief have often confessed to that first attempt at stealing commenced at apple stall that having acquired confidence by few successful adventure have gradually progressed in crime allured by others in turn alluring find companion to cheer instruct girl to share booty applaud facility to sell daily booty there be moreover kind of lottery adventure in day life a excitement be attainable at so easy rate be strange that child be fascinated with abandon to crime imprisonment to young urchin who steal have other mean of subsistence be punishment for be indifferent to where exists so long a have food raiment be in prison that boy form acquaintance more mischievous than many lad have owned to that have learned more in gaol than out of one once asked lad if there be school where boy be taught to pick pocket upon significantly observed occasion for one sir best school for sort of thing be here ' alluding to prison in saw footnote can not allow reader to attribute to imagination fact so disgusting a received information from police officer who be eye witness of such scene from whom a stated in previous note in series have gleaned many remarkable fact relative to lowest order footnote mr mile report say london thief have sense of moral degradation be corrupt to core be stranger to virtue character even by name for many of be child of thief of exceedingly dissolute people consequently can have contrition be in state of predatory existence without knowledge of social duty may lament detection because be inconvenience will not repent crime in gaol will ponder on past curse 'evil star look forward with anxiety to moment of release mind habit be not constituted for repentance mr chesterton of house of correction informed that considers reformation among juvenile offender to be utterly hopeless observed that 'boys brought up in low neighbourhood have chance of being honest because on leaving gaol return to old haunt follow example of parent associate lieutenant tracy of westminster bridewell have pointed out to lad who live constantly in gaol captain kincaid of city bridewell informed that one half of number under lock on day inspected prison june th have be more than once committed many of several time especially boy mr teague of giltspur street compter be of opinion that young thief be mostly incorrigiblethat nothing will reform opinion say have formed from experience of many year mr capper of home office stated in evidence that out of juvenile convict on board hulk euryalus eldest of whom be not have be committed more than once experienced burglar told that young thief can not will not reform 'the only thing sir ' remarked 'that may save be transportation a remove from evil companion young thief be nucleus of mischief young pickpocket named stuart aged informed that parent daily sent into street to 'look about be to plunder whatever must lay hand upon principal associate be three young thief with whom 'worked ' robbed that when be year old stood at horse head while companion stole great coat from gig that got sixpence for share of plunder that have committed many robbery because be made to do that lived entirely by plunder mr chesterton state in evidence before select committee of house of common in answer to query beome of parent lead child into evil course be uncommon thing when be listening to conversation between prisoner parent to hear conversation show at once boy situation old thief be in habit of bringing in with young inexperienced lad whenever elder thief be recommitted be frequently recommitted with also observes that 'the elder thief be continually corrupting young lad bringing into prison ' be informed that captain brenton considers total number of juvenile offender within bill of mortality to be dr lushington believe computed number still higher from evidence above quoted be evident that elder offender be daily spreading mischief far wide there be youthful population in metropolis devoted to crime trained to from infancy adhering to from education circumstance whose connection prevent possibility of reformation whom punishment can deter race generis ' different from rest of society not only in thought habit manner even in appearance possessing moreover language exclusively own there be lodging house kept by old thief where juvenile offender herd together constant intercourse tends to complete corruption be in hotbed of vice that revel in fruit of plunder though extremely young live with girl indulging in kind of debauchery chapter xxxix continuation of history of jacob smith now come to important event in lifein fact that portion of will account for sickly condition of health in see old death one evening took with to supper at place where have never introduced before be bunce in earl street seven dial mr bunce immediately seemed to take great fancy to memade sit next to herand in spite of meanness helped to best of thing on table be very good supper for old death who provided have declared that meant to launch out for once suppose be only to put into good humour be more likely to fall into scheme have in view be not however reason of mr bunce kindness because since then have often treated in manner have made forget many sorrow be true that liking only take by fit startsand have not unfrequently used cruelly enough can scarcely make woman out a far a be concerned there be moment when think great deal of kind word have ever uttered to kind treatment have ever shown be wandering from subject have entered upon remember be telling about supper at bunce house well after thing be cleared away grog be going round pretty fasti used to drink then a much a man although little more than ten year oldold death began to talk great deal about money might be made by clever lad like being able to get admittance into house of rich people went on to say must begin to think of doing business must leave more time to amuse be also le dangerous than going about street picking pocket assured be heartily sick tired of life be leading that wished be old enough to be housebreaker ' said ' cracksman doe have time can call own if doe only one job week be satisfied be obliged to gad about day to get mean of living on next besides ' said be of course running thousand time more risk by doing so many job day than must if only did one two week '' everybody must have apprenticeship ' returned old death 'and have now served yours agree with that be high time for to be doing something better have plan ready chalked out for youbers bunce mixed glass of grog produced short pipe blew cloud while old death explained scheme at first did not much relish backed with so many argument agreed to try sure enough at six o'clock one morninga few day afterwardsa boy black a devil with soot bag over shoulder brush scraper in hand be making round of bloomsbury square bawling beweep a lustily a must that boy be presently garret window opened female voice called to stop obeyed in few minute down came cook to front door be desired to walk in operate on kitchen chimney cook be fat middle aged good natured body asked great many question about myselfhow long have be sweephow happened that became have father motherand host of such query to of replied in most sorrowful manner possible assured have be sweep from infancythat have swept chimney when be only five year have parentsthat master beat cruellyand have have nothing to eat since earned then took departure having very quietly deposited dozen silver fork spoon in soot bag while back be turned business carried on successfully enough for month till at last old death told that have seen several paragraph in paper warning people against theft committed by sweep therefore gave up employment once more took refuge in st giles health be seriously injured by occupation have just renounced from time have always be ailing sickly although have seldom turned sweep more than twice week hour after robbery that thus committed be a clean again a if have never be near chimney in lifeyet seed of disease be planted in feel effect hereherein chest life led when gave up chimney sweep business did not certainly tend to improve health hired room in st giles took girl into keepingi being then eleven thirteen of profligate creature peggy wilkins be worst moment awoke in morning must have half quartern of gin then must go on drinking at short interval day long if attempted to stop supply must fly into most dreadful passion break thing must lay hand on else throw domestic article at head when tipsy must loll half naked out of window chaff people passing in street in evening went to penny concert penny theatre generally came home so gloriously drunk that entire house much le little room must scarcely hold may wonder why continued to live with fact be liked in spite of outrageous conduct a be sometimes very dull low noisy rackety disposition positively helped to put into good spirit knew nothing of connexion with old death be aware that be laying hid in st giles in consequence of having robbed house disguised a sweep used to laugh heartily when told several amusing anecdote relative to portion of career one nightafter having lived about month in idleness in holy usuala certain sign that have something new on hand did not however venture to ask question for still stood in greatest awe of knew that disposition be irritable easy to be provoked at length said to said 'jacob have something for to do be convinced will yield good harvest instantly became attentiohere be widow lady continued 'living at west end in swell street by can learn be very well off be also very charitable belongs to number of what be called religious society be sure must get into house a easy a possible chimney sweep business have well nigh blown over if not quite be high time to begin new dodge'he then explained plan agreed to adopt when got back to lodging in st giles found peggy sitting in company with young fellow of about fifteen drinking raw spirit have not expected home so early be for moment quite taken aback soon recovering put good face on matter introduced young chap a brother saying that have not seen for many year before evening when have met by accident pretended to believe moment be gone gave good beating overwhelmed with reproach showed le spirit than have expected did not attempt to return blow did treat with sulkiness ill humour on following evening at about nine o'clock very quietly laid down on door step of house in old burlington street be in such rag tatter a to be almost naked having pricked foot with pointed bit of wood in several place be almost covered with blood a if chapped with cold cut by sharp stone be in depth of winter appearance be most miserable presently carriage drove up to house fine tall elderly gentleman got out be crouched up close by threshold of door purposely let tread on one of naked foot then began to sob a if with pain now observed for first time muttered oath at instant front door opened manner changed directly spoke kindly to put crown into hand lady be crossing hall while door stood open gentleman be still speaking to immediately turned to ascertain what be matter 'here be poor wretched creature ' said gentleman be so huddled up against door did not observe be afraid trod on leg somewhat heavily'the lady instantly spoke in most compassionate term desired that might be brought into house man servant raised for affected to be unable to walk lady said 'poor boy be paralysed with cold'when be moved into hall placed in chair state of foot be observed increased compassion have already excited ordered servant to take into kitchen give good supper while warmed by fire command be immediately executed shoe stocking be also supplied in course of hour lady came down to speak to asked who be told long piteous tale already prepared for occasionhow have be apprenticed to tradesman at liverpool have undergone most dreadful treatment because refused to work on lord day insisted on right to go to church how cruelty of master have increased to extent be obliged to run away how have wandered about country for last two month subsisting on charity often starved how have that morning found way to london have be obliged to sell shoe for penny to buy roll be have eaten during thirty six hour have aunt who be housekeeper to certain bishop that knew must do must for lady seemed to eye suspiciously until spoke of aunt bishop then countenance instantly changed in favour poor lad said 'you will remain here to night first thing to morrow morning one of servant will take message from to aunt ' of course expressed gratitude for kindness lady assured that required thanks a heaven rewarded for what did towards suffering fellow creature really thought that there be something very much like what usual associate be accustomed to call 'gammon in then actually reproached for idea began to repent of imposing on so much virtue goodness when be well warmed with cheerful fire plentiful supper housekeeper of lady conducted to little room on top storey having wished 'good night retired locking door behind did not give much uneasiness for beneath rag have concealed necessary mean to counteract precaution accordingly about hour after have heard servant withdraw to bed room be on same floor a one where be placedand when thought house be quieti took off however mahogany press be fast locked drew forth small skeleton key be about to use when be alarmed by footstep in passage in moment be safely concealed under bed one almost immediately afterwards entered room only closed door without shutting dared not move even to peep from beneath drapery that hung round bed to floor must tell by rustling of silk unlacing of stay that person in room be undressing herselfand felt satisfied be lady of house be now seriously alarmed be evidently going to bed only chance of escaping from chamber be when must be asleep might not disturb situation be very unpleasantand prison seemed to open before eye in about quarter of hour lady stepped into bed how longed to catch first sound must convince be asleep be not dreaming of closing eye yet awhile for scarcely have laid down when door be gently openedthen carefully closed againand person evidently without shoe boot on came into room said few word to other to astonishment found that gentleman who have arrived in carriage of course have be sent away be going to pas hour in company with charitable lady 'well thought 'this be way in heaven reward for doe towards suffering fellow creature fancied that gentleman have gone away long before that care be taken to avoid disturbing with noise likely to excite suspicion moment lady have left room with lover thought of beating retreat must go empty handed yet have not time to force open mahogany press believed must contain jewel before must come back a have gone down in night clothes therefore resolved to stay where be accomplish purpose when be asleep because if matter did come to worst must awake dared not expose so laid quiet came back in few minute shivering with coldfor must hear teeth actually chatter hour afterwards be fast gibbet mr mile say have questioned many boy of shrewd understanding concerning opinion opinion of associate a to ultimate fate for thief be fatalist look upon inevitable doom to be sooner later transportation drop be difficult to imagine state of more gloomy wretchedness more despairingly horrible than self conviction of condign punishment without one gleam of hope to clear melancholy perspective punishment whipping be therefore useless for mind be prepared to endure more imprisonment be only looked upon a step in ladder of sad destiny lad be hopeless consequently reckless in conducthardened to present irreclaimable a to future be not by prison discipline that reformation can be effected temptation facility love of idleness be too alluring crowd of young thief will wait round prison gate to hail companion on morning of liberation to carry off to treat regale for day have asked boy under sentence of transportation if thought must reform if returned again upon society general reply have be 'no reason for conclusion give in own words'if be to be free to morrow must go to old haunt old companion for where else can go if try to be honest can not for 'pals associate must torment to return in short must only have to come back here at last be now going to country where hope to be honest men have moreover questioned many lad a to what method must adopt to prevent other boy from falling into crime remark have be betop playing in street for pocket be soon picked there be many who show others how to do itand next thing be to stop cursed receiver for if receiver know boy to have dealt with be to have sold property will make go out to thieve will never let rest even must get into employment will teaze till make rob master will tell of to police remark prove boy to be good judge of own case so like skilful physician know where to apply remedy a feel convinced that many of urchin posse requisite to be good useful member of society so be certain that reformation in majority of case be a practicable under proper mean a ultimate ruin be now certain under present system footnote mr brandon in preface to mr mile report make following observation be too important to need apology for quotation if religious fanatic brings bill into house for 'better observance of sabbath whose comfort be to be abridged why poor man of middling class for be stage coach omnibus be to be prohibited from making appearance while street may be thronged with carriage though labourer be not permitted to purchase necessary food on sacred day unable to have accomplished before from not having received wage till too late preceding night yet fishmonger may keep turbot cool be to grace lordship sunday table send home on very day just in time to be prepared for dinner penny theatre too be decried suppressed while larger one be permittedthe reason assigned being that company who frequent former render step necessary delinquency doe not arise from cheap exhibitionsit be from inefficiency of law to restrain audience for in play there be improper language used notorious thief in examination said have heard bad language at place before curtain drew up never thing indecent on stage be damning proof where fault lie if law be such a to restrain vice properly administered must effectually prevent improper conduct of loose individual preclude necessity of reducing pleasure of poor pocket be picked night at royal theatre scene of worst description carried on in lobby yet never entered into cranium of wiseacre if theatre be shut up abomination must be effectually eradicated be highly gratifying to witness order pleasure with cheap diversion be conducted on continent even so close to a boulogne calais where may be seen lowest class enjoying in dancing visiting various public garden entrance to be fee equivalent to penny proof of difference with law be administered according to party affected be manifest in proceeding against various house for play in metropolis club of aristocracy 'little go little hell c of poor chapter xl conclusion of history of jacob smith on return to earl street seven dial be at about three o'clock in morning found old death mr bunce sitting up for toby having gone to bed related adventure have met with said not word about intrigue of lady baronet for must not help thinking that kind treatment have in first instance received from mr slingsby deserved reward of secresy on head old death very kindly permitted to retain five pound out of money have obtained hurried back to lodging in st giles peggy be in bed fast asleep lay down by side without awaking when again opened eye sun be shining in brightness of frosty air even through dingy pane of window started up peggy have already risen supposed have gone out to get thing for breakfast something like suspicion arose in mindand felt uneasy searched pocket of ragged pair of trouser have purposely worn on previous night five sovereign be gone now be really alarmed peggy have certainly decamped farther search showed that have even carried off few little article of decent wearing apparel have leaving only miserable rag in have appeared at mr slingsby house yespeggy have run away with possessed be worth taking now question naturally rose in mind'will betray ' thought conduct be so suspicious that determined not to give chance if must help particularly a remembered manner in took beating gave now made think that have resolved on being revenged so dressed myself in tatter a quick a must got away from house at end of street met certain mr dykesthe bow street runner whom happen to know mr rainfordand though endeavoured to dive into narrow court pounced upon in twinkling in le than hour stood in felon dock at police court bow street charged with robbery committed by in bloomsbury square in disguise of sweep be remanded for week sent in meantime to clerkenwell prison there be placed in reception yard where mr bunce who pretended to be aunt in order to get admittance to visited in afternoon told that mr bone must not possibly come to see that must do must for if remained staunch did not mention name in waynot even to fellow prisoner be afraid that will be committed for trial ' said mr bunce 'but will be done can be done to buy off witness if wo succeed such evidence of former good character will be given that sentence will be light one in meantime will have a much money a want to live gloriously in prison mr bone have sent up sovereign for present will bring good suit of clothes to morrow so that may go up swell before beak next time be staunch jacob mr bone will never desert if only mention name to soul in improper way will leave to fate will be transportedbers bunce impressed on mind assured be unnecessary a knew must not better own plight in very considerable degree by nosing against bone whereas might be useful to if behaved well in matter went away satisfied spent rest of day in jollification with fellow prisoner amongst whom money raised to rank of hero night slept in receiving ward next morning be taken to bathing room new suit of clothes having be already sent in to by mr bunce found be to bathe in same water have already served to wash filthy body of several tramper who have also be sent to prison day before on charge of robbery knew that when entered be covered with vermin therefore gave turnkey crown to allow to dispense with bath put on new clothes be turned into felon yard there found person who have committed degree of crime huddled together a if there be difference in charge against boy who have stolen pound of potato value one pennymyself who have stolen plate in dwelling housea gentleman who have wounded in duel must not get bail who be very superior persona burglara coinerand man charged with murder be in one room together did not strike thenbut have often struck sincehow wrong be to put boy who have stolen potato along with burglar coiner practised thief a washow unjust be to put gentleman with of usand how shocking be to put murderer along with prisoner whose hand be not at least stained with blood be consequence boy who have merely stolen potato because mother be ill starving who have never done thing wrong before be entirely corrupted by coiner made up mind to turn prig moment got outthe gentleman be worked up to pitch of excitement by being in such society that be removed to infirmary died of brain fever a afterwards heardthe burglar helped murderer to escape got safely away with illustration amusement in gaol be chiefly gambling drinking money procured a much liquor a must consume with such be well supplied card dice be not allowed be true used to play with bit of wood cut marked like domino by chalking table into draught board by tossing halfpenny then there be such fighting quarrelling bad language that nothing must equal place in upper sleeping ward thing be much worse prisoner robbed other very first night duellist gentleman be there lost purse containing several sovereign when threatened to complain be quietly informed by burglar murderer that if did must be hung up to bar of window with own handkerchief very next night end must be attributed to suicide at end of week be have up to bow street once more evidence be so conclusive against be committed to newgate for trial have expected cared little for a mr bunce at visit paid at clerkenwell prison assured that mr bone must do must for kept wordbut more suppose for own sake than mine what dreadful place found newgate to be hardened a wasacquainted with degree of debaucheryand familiar with vice declare solemnly that shrank from scene there witnessed fighting quarrelling gambling thieving drinking obscene talking bullying corrupting otherall took place to great degree in clerkenwell prison in newgate be carried out to extent dreadful to think of associated with other crime impossible to mention now seemed to awake for first time from long dream of wickedness to become aware of frightful precipice on stood eye be suddenly openedand shuddered man be hanged at debtor door while be in newgate saw pas from condemned cell to kitchen be just within debtor door experienced sudden revulsion of feeling took solemn oath within own breast must never thieve again a knew nothing of religion must not read write be not likely to reform very rapidly very completely still laughed joked with fellow prisoner appeared to enter into most of fun though really began to loathe when chaplain visited other boy jeered mocked stood by dwelt on word of gentle remonstrance fell from lip next sunday paid great attention to sermon while pretending to be asleep for if have be caught actually lending patient ear to discourse fellow prisoner must have led peace afterwards understood littlevery little of sermon still gleaned notion of existence of saviour belief in whom be stepping stone to virtue also heard happiness of heaven explained for first time must confess be greatly puzzled when chaplain declared that man who be hanged for dreadful murder on preceding monday have gone to place of joy because have repented in last momentsfor thought to myself 'well then human being be quite safe in leading a terrible life a chooses a long a repents at end again be bewildered when clergyman say word made so great impression on have never forgotten never will'as stood with penitent man on drop last monday morning envied fate because knew that soul be about to ascend to heaven ' day of trial came be placed in dock before common serjeant of london clerk of court asked 'how will be triedby god country ' knew not what reply to make be actually on point of saying must rather not be tried at time since seemed to be left to own choice must faithfully promise never to thieve again'when turnkey who have charge of whispered in ear damned young fool why speak say god country ' damn ' did a be directed trial commenced charge against be fully proved verdict of guilty be recorded common serjeant asked if have ever be convicted before keeper of newgate who be present said have not counsel who have be retained for by old death then requested to be allowed to call witness to character be permitted three four tradesman who well knew be old death friend got up one after other swore have be in service one of course giving different period of time be honest hard working industrious lad until fell into bad company got into trouble dyke runner be then questioned about said be not known a thiefalthough knew contrary perfectly well old death have kept word have not spared gold offence be however grave onerobbing in dwelling house there be two three other indictment of same kind against though prosecutor did not come forward old death have made right with too be accordingly condemned to seven year transportation with hint that sentence must be commuted to two year imprisonment at hulk be little more than eleven when career of crime be thus interrupted be glad that be so interruptedfor resolved that must not be renewed when regained liberty be scarcely resolution produced by moral consideration by fear therefore required strengthening whether be not will soon inform few day after session terminated be removed with several other boy to euryalus convict hulk at woolwich vessel have three deck upper be appropriated to lad convicted first time second to next grade of juvenile criminal third lowest to worst kind of offender be assigned to upper deck where there be about sixty of on being received on board be first sent to wash house where be bathed well cleansed then received suit of dark grey denotes felon employment be to make clothes for entire establishment be shirt jacket waistcoat trouser person who taught be convict boy who have be tailor cutter out belonged to second deck visited department a often a service be required be divided into section having at head boy selected a chief on account of good conduct when in prison will describe routine of daytaking period when summer regulation be in force at five o'clock in morning hand be called port be opened hammock be lowered lashed up washed for chapel at half past five signal be given for prayer went to chapel in section division taking seat in profound silence morning hymn be sung schoolmaster read prayer returned to ward on upper deck there stood in rank till six o'clock when breakfast be served steward of ship superintended giving out of provision saw that boy have fair allowance of bread gruel being done steward ordered rank one after other to approach table hold up bread say grace then sit down eat at half past six be marwilled on quarter deck in division officer of hulk be then prepared to hear complaint receive report might have to be submitted to such complaint be noted down for after investigation of boy be kept above to wash quarter deck remainder be sent down to cleanse own deck at eight o'clock be set to work at tailoring strict silence being preserved at nine o'clock report upon complaint be received from commander of hulk punishment awarded be made knownsuch a good thrashing with cane stopping dinner solitary confinement on bread water at twelve o'clock dinner be served out steward superintending quartermaster guard be also present to see that one boy allowance be not taken from by from half past twelve to half past one be allowed to take air exercise on quarter deck without making noise at past one be marched down again to work at two section of one third of be sent into chapel where be taught reading writing by schoolmaster at five left off work schooling cleaned ward then washed being done supper be served out went on quarter deck again for air exercise till seven when be once more marched to chapel for evening prayer catechism at eight o'clock returned to own deck where signal be given for getting out hammock slinging up at nine profound silence be ordered whole ship be then a quiet a if there be not soul on boardthis deep tranquillity being only broken by striking of bell cry of 'all well ' half hour such be life led on board euryalus convict hulk be happiermuch happier there than have ever be before schoolmaster be excellent man took delight in teaching who be anxious to learn be of number improvement be rapid quite won regard devoted unusual pain to instruct so at end of year obtained leave for to give up making of clothes assist a usher be employment pleased greatly allowed plenty of time to read book lent by worthy schoolmaster so fond be of reading used to take book with on quarter deck at time devoted to air exercise sitting apart from others must remain buried in study until be time to go below again examined how book be written how be accustomed to speak that isi compared language of book with own be shocked to find how wretchedly ignorant have hitherto be in respect to grammar ignorance strove hardoh very hard to surmount good schoolmaster assisted to utmost of power read studied bible with avidity more became acquainted with more fixed grow determination to avoid relapse into way of crime when must be released during two year passed at hulk mr bunce came very often to see passing off a aunt relation be not allowed to speak to except in presence of guard so name of old death be never mentioned by of mr bunce used to tell that bey uncle must give home when time be up supposed by meant husband toby knew that old death be person who have directed assurance to be given often often did lay awake of night deliberating within must do when be set free to earn honest livelihood avoid hateful necessity of returning to service of mr benjamin bone at day of liberation cameand have plan of proceeding settled clothes be given to shilling be put into hand by steward old schoolmaster be absent at time be sorry have not opportunity of thanking for kindness imploring advice how to proceed struck must appeal to commander of hulk did so solicited to counsel how to get honest livelihood burst out laughing in face exclaiming ' suppose think be to be deceived by humbug that will put hand into pocket give guinea to see way with such thing lad used to do so when be first here assisted in way be always first to come back again'and turned on heel leaving quite astounded at reception sincerity of behaviour have experienced few moment reflection showed that must scarcely blame for conduct quitted ship in tear moment stepped from boat landed in woolwich met mr bunce threw arm round neck called 'dear jacob ' in loving manner that one must really have believed to be aunt even mother if have chosen to represent so then pointing to public house at little distance said good kind friend mr bone be there will be so delighted to see have ordered nice steak good ale mean to let enjoy yourself'the idea of having such glorious repast after being kept on short common on board euryalus made mouth water then remembered influence old death have be accustomed to exercise over meand knew that if once again entered within range must never have moral courage to withdraw from so mind be made up suddenly darting down bye street be beyond mr bunce view in twinkling heard shrill screaming voice call after heeded notand hurried onward a if escaping from wild beast presently relaxed speed at length entered public house where called for pint of beer two three soldier a many young woman be sitting at table drinking indulging at same time in most filthy discourse suddenly one of female started up advanced towards after considering for few moment exclaimed with terrible oath 'well thought must be old fancy cove jacob'and offered to embrace however repulsed with loathing for in miserable tattered sickly wretch before have already recognised peggy wilkins seemed ashamed of herself for minute then recovering impudence said blast for sulky snivelling hound who devil be that ca treat civilly do think know be happened to why have only moment left hulksand ca deny it'the soldier hearing demanded if be true without waiting for answer thrust out of place have reached end of street when recollected have not received change for shilling have tendered in payment of beer therefore went back to ask for pot boy who have served swore never gave shilling at landlord evidently believed be vagabond endeavouring to swindle servant so be kicked outpenniless be for time before must muster up courage to adopt plan for support indeed sate down in retired nook cried bitterly even regretted having left hulk so miserable did feel at last hunger compelled to act entered shop to inquire if boy be wanted man behind counter said did not require assistance of lad that neighbour of must probably hire went to place pointed out to having explained business be asked for testimonial of good character candidly confessed that have just be discharged from euryalus that thought schoolmaster on board must recommend man flew into dreadful passion rushing round from behind counter must have kicked out of shop if have not run away of own accord be sure that tried twenty different shop day in woolwich at explained positionat others carefully concealed fact of late ignominious punishment charactercharactercharacter where be even for starving lad who only asked fair trialwho promised to work from sunrise to sunset to be content with morsel of bread to eat cellar to sleep in a recompense for toilseven to one who offered so much required so little in return character be necessary night camei be famishing in despair at length charitable baker gave roll hunger be appeased struck that tradesman at be perhaps more cautious than people elsewhere how engaged service of young lad in consequence of place being station for convict hulk therefore resolved to try luck in quarter set out for greenwich reached at midnight slept till morning in shed near house be being built cold famished dispirited did awake with sinking heart commenced round before noon have called at hundred shop public house tavern without success few required service of boy people who did demanded reference begged piece of bread of baker then set off for london so slow did walk so often be compelled to rest that be evening before reached blackfriar road there again did endeavour to procure honest employmentbut in vain remember that when one shopkeeperan old manlistened to with more attention than rest burst into tear imploredbesoughtprayed to receive into service if be only to save from becoming thief did not tell have already be one shook head saying sorrowfully 'if have already thought of turning thief moral must be more than half corrupted'he gave few halfpenny went away balanced for minute between craving of stomach fatigue of limbsthat be whether must spend halfpenny in food on bed decided in favour of food having satisfied hunger crept into timber yard on bank of thames slept there till morning awoke at sunrise crossed blackfriar bridge limb shivered with ague clothes be damp with dew of night knew not what to dowhich way to turn hope have deserted there be poorwretchedhouselessfriendlessstarving being anxious to remain honest yet impelled by circumstance towards relapse into career of vice prayed a went along streetsyes prayed to god to save from that last resource succour came day long did rove about night arrived againand for twenty four hour have eaten nothing dragged back to timber yard there be great dog prowling aboutand dared not enter sought shelter elsewhere for rain began to descend in torrent be wet through before must even find entrance of court to screen never slept wink night be afraid to lie down on cold stonesthey be so chill morning came againand be now so weak that must hardly put one foot before be moreover starvingyes starving passed baker shop saw nice hot bread smoking in window went in to implore stale crust be ordered out then idea struck that in few minute might obtain money to buy good breakfastnot only bread meat tea be by picking pocket idea however assumed horrible aspect moment afterwardsand recoiled from must sooner plunge into river end woe therethan steal again to river brink hurrieddragging slowly morebut running yesabsolutely running fast to terminate wretchedness by suicide be near westminster bridge be on point of throwing into thames when collar be suddenly grasped from behind be drawn back turnedand saw old death then uttered scream struggled dreadfully to get away might still accomplish purpose held tight saying beilly boy why do fly from life since may yet have many pleasure for '' cried will never become thief again '' will never ask to do so replied come with let talk over prospect '' prospect repeated in hysterical manner then followed mechanically to early breakfast house close by ordered plentiful meal ate ravenously food hot coffee cheered began to feel grateful to bone for having supplied mean to appease hunger be devouring moreover one look with different eye upon suicide after good meal must not do otherwise than regard a saviour of life be therefore already prepared to listen to with attention when proposed that must repair to bunce where must converse without fear of being overheard willingly agreed to accompany during walk to seven dial constantly repeated within own breast most solemn vow not to yield to threat representationsmenaces coaxingsto induce to become thief again when reached house in earl street mr bunce received with more kindness than have expected to meet at hand after trick have played few day before at woolwich did not treat thus without motive for when once old death got between endeavoured to utmost of power to persuade to resume old avocation be faithful to vow assured that might kill sooner than must again do thing to risk imprisonment in horrible newgate be not hulk so much dreadednor yet transportation because knew nothing of shrunk from mere idea of going through ordeal of newgate second time old death saw be not to be movedat least then gave up point ' said 'you must do something to get living ca starve wo maintain in idleness if like will take into service to run on errand look after people want to learn thing about make useful in way will give shilling day agreedfor must not starve now of course be a plain to a be even then to that old death be playing deep game with be cleverest thief that ever served have received ampleample proof that must trust knew that be safe with be therefore too useful person to lose thought that by throwing again amongst old companion keeping on very short allowance disagreeable impression of gaol must soon wear away must relapse into old habit be quite mistaken pretend that particular idea of virtue made great change in have be in newgateand there have seen man going out to be hanged thought that if got into dreadful gaol second time must become hardened that also must go out day to be hanged so resisted temptationand lived a well a must on shilling day without increasing mean by theft villany mode of life on part did not suit old death few week passed when found that be resolved not to return to former way stopped allowance altogether be now steeped to very lip in wretchedness misery somehow managed to get crust here there just to keep body soul togetheralthough oftener slept in open air than in bed mr bunce showed little kindness now then quite unknown to old death to surprise did not urge necessity of returning to career of theft for several week saw nothing of mr bone at last fished out in low place told might return into service if liked that must pay according to use proved to be to to glean information for himrun on errandsdog watch personsor even loiter about in runner jacob pausedfor tale be told well boy said tom rain have gone through much seen enough to form good stock of experience commend resolution never to put within reach of law again for be just determination also have got money in pocket now will do something more for before leave england ah mr rainford exclaimed jacob much affected how wish have met with friend a earlier in life how wish from jacob be overjoyed at specie of promise thus held out to a be now midnight rainford intimated intention of taking departure from public house where have passed evening with poor lad when have gray inn lanehe having removed to locality from former abode in lock field footnote discipline of criminal prison be particularly lax at time of jacob smith be supposed to be speaking footnote dreadful state of thing continued in new prison clerkenwell up to year footnote report of prison inspector of home district contains observation upon state of newgatethe association of prisoner of age shade of guilt in one indiscriminate mass be frightful feature in system prevails here first in magnitude most pernicious in effect in prison find that young oldthe inexperienced practical offenderthe criminal who be smitten with conviction of guilt hardened villain whom scarcely penal discipline can subdue be congregated together with utter disregard to moral distinction interest of prisoner welfare of community in such state of thing can be matter of wonder that effect must be such a have be described other evil be aggravated by must be worse than idle to attempt remedy for rest while demoralising intermixture of criminal of age degree of guilt be suffered to frustrate very end of prison discipline to give tenfold violence to mischievous inclination passion upon be incessantly operating be design of justice to discourage repress apart from higher consideration sound policy demand that system must be instantly rectified for so long a continues society be nursing moral pestilence in bosom maintaining institution in be forged weapon be destined to be wielded with fatal dexterity against community device by fence of property may be overcome be here framed divulged to ready agent fraudulent artifice successful trick ingenious mode of over reaching cautious of plundering unguarded be perfected here communicated to who have not hitherto be initiated in mystery of crime most distressing circumstance connected with system be cruel indifference with regard condition necessity of on whom extreme penalty of law be doomed to fall prisoner actually awaiting execution of awful sentence of death be placed by evil influence of companionship in most unfavourable circumstance for self reflection religion humanity combine to point out imperative necessity of providing men brought by sentence of law to verge of eternity with mean of spiritual improvement consolation system of prison discipline in newgate practically defeat such merciful design human authority have right thus to trifle with eternal interest of dying criminal against serious evil chaplain have repeatedly loudly protested be in evidence that unhappy victim have earnestly implored officer to deliver from situation in be impossible for to devote few remaining hour that law allowed to reflection prayer companion in guilt of wretched men become further hardened by influence of association indulgence of thoughtless apathy unfeeling mirth revolting ribaldry be productive of incalculable mischief to mind of who be subjected to influence prisoner who witness with levity indifference last moment of culprit in newgate come forth greater villain than when went in in evil principle have done work very exhibition of terror justice designed for reclaiming of survivor by perversion of moral influence irremediably hardens heart be intended to soften amend if human ingenuity be tasked to devise mean by most profligate of men might be rendered abandoned to last degree of moral infamy nothing more effectual must be invented than system now actually in operation within wall of first metropolitan prison in england footnote fact chapter xli fresh alarm rainford be within twenty yard stood before fire in state of extraordinary nervousness in fact appeared perfectly unmanned can conceive feeling of appalling doubthope mingled with terrific fearand agonising suspense must be experienced by individual accused of capital crime awaiting in dock return of jury in whose hand be life death such be state of tom rain during five mortal minute elapsed ere door again opened at length did openand though have back turned towards yet rustling of silk light airy tread convinced that lady of house be now in room turned light streamed full upon countenancefor have laid aside hat however necessary to relate particular of interview inasmuch a nature of conversation passed between will be developed hereafter chapter liii execution fatal monday morning broke gloomily light stoleor rather struggled by degree into convict cell shortly before seven o'clock tom rain awoke casting eye rapidly around successively fell upon turnkey who have sate up with himthe still flickering lamp upon common deal tablethe damp stone wallsand massive bar at window for instant cold shudder convulsed frame a convictionthe appalling truth burst upon that horror of dream be not to cease with slumber have given birth with knitting brow compressed liplike strong minded man who endeavour to conceal pain inflicted on by surgical operation of dreadful naturehe struggled with emotion when governor clergyman entered dungeon found firm resolute though not insolent reckless chaplain offered to pray with consented to join in devotion there be profound sinceritybut affectation hypocrisy passionate exclamationin prayer tom rain uttered extemporaneously a clock chimed half past seven arose from knee saying be now prepared to die there be yet half hour before scarcely have clock finished chiming when door be opened earl of ellingham entered cell heedless of impression conduct might produce upon prison authority present arthur rushed forward threw into rainford arm exclaiming noi have not willfully abandoned thomas just now said be prepared to die convict returning embrace with congenial warmth now may even add that will die contented time be too precious to waste in mere detail returned arthur must tell how have be kept away from by forceby vile outrage now believe be willingly absentthat wantonly neglected nono exclaimed rainford seek not explanationi require none be enough that be here nowat last hour earl then related in few hurried word vain exertion have made on preceding evening on behalf of rainford who expressed lively gratitude arthur next requested governor to permit to have few minute private conversation with prisoner favour must not be grantedand earl dared not persist in demand a chaplain hinted that convict have bidden adieu to affair of life have little time left for devotion thus be that arthur rainford have opportunity of speaking together in privatealthough former have something important to communicate latter perceived that such be fact arthur said tom approaching close to half brother speaking in low solemn tone be there hope noneon side of scaffold returned earl with significant glance a dwelt on word a spoke took prisoner hand a if to wring fervently rainford felt something in earl palm instantly comprehended that be object be to take unnoticed by gaol authority then rapid a lightning flash perceived double meaning in wordson side of scaffold because knew that arthur must not use awful word scaffoldbut must have said tomb have not have special profound motive rainford did comprehend hintthe hope conveyed though thanked half brother with rapid expressive glance yet sickly smile played upon lipindicative of faintness of hope so created at same instant heavy footstep be heard approaching cell chaplain said in solemn tone hour be almost come then arthur once more threw into prisoner arm whispered rapidly in ear keep tube in throatand will be saved rainford murmured assent brother embraced with fervour astonished present to whom relationship be totally unknown arthur then tore from cellnot for world must behold that horrible process termed toilette have also motive for quitting dungeon before last momentthis be to meet sheriff of county in passage behold in corridor encountered that functionary javelin men under sheriff behind whom came executioner assistant earl accosted sheriff with whom be acquainted who be naturally surprised to meet nobleman there drawing aside arthur said in hasty tone have favoura great favour to ask of convict be well connected friend demand body to bury decently earnest prayer have to offer on behalf be that will not prolong feeling of shame ignominy will experience during time corpse remains suspended lord replied sheriff body will be cut down at twenty minute past eight delivered over to unhappy man friend thousand thanks said earl pressing sheriff hand then hurried away procession moved on to cell immense be crowd gathered around gaol to witness hants yes immense be crowdand not only did living ocean inundate open space about gaol thoroughfare leading thitherbut seemed to force off shooting stream channel up very wall of surrounding dwelling
