footnote mr peck b in interesting paper on electricity in reynolds miscellany give ensuing particularsthe discovery of galvanic electricity be result of accident madame galvani wife of distinguished italian philosopher being recommended by medical adviser to partake of broth prepared from frog several of little animal be procured be placed prior to being cooked in laboratory of husband of monsieur galvani friend happened to be amusing with electrical machine be standing in room by chance one of frog be touched with scalpel to madame galvani surprise observed limb of frog exhibit convulsive motion upon examining closely perceived that muscle be affected at very time when spark be received from machine when husband returned acquainted with circumstance for time previously m galvani have entertained belief that muscular action be affected by electricity have be experimenting for purpose if possible of verifying hypothesis delighted by discovery lost time in trying variety of experiment at first tested effect of spark alone on dissected frog gradually varying intensity of spark in case however even when electric action be feeble noticed that muscle of frog gave evidence of susceptibility to influence next made experiment with atmospheric electricity same result ensued a when electric action have be elicited by artificial mean in paper of same interesting series following account be evening of january th during somewhat extraordinary display of northern light lady became so highly charged with electricity a to give out vivid electrical spark at end of finger to face of of company present did not cease with heavenly phenomenon continued for several month during time be constantly charged giving off electrical spark to conductor approached so that must not touch stove metallic utensil without first giving off electrical spark with consequent twinge state most favourable to phenomenon be atmosphere of about deg fahrenheit moderate exercise social enjoyment disappeared in atmosphere approaching zero under debilitating effect of fear when seated by stove reading with foot upon fender gave out spark at rate of three four minute under most favourable circumstance spark must be seen heard felt passed second must charge others in same way when insulated who must then give spark to others to make satisfactory that dress did not produce be changed to cotton woollen without altering phenomenon lady be about thirty of sedentary pursuit delicate state of health avail ourselves of digressive facility afforded by note to text to relate true history of resuscitation of man who have be hangeda history be perhaps one of most extraordinary romance of real life upon record be a followsambrose gwinett be hanged at deal for murder of man who merely disappeared whose body be not found circumstantial evidence certainly pointed strongly to gwinett a murderer still be not proved in first instance that murder have be really committed gwinett man of name of collins arrived together at inn in deal gwinett borrowed collins clasp knife during supper time in presence of waiter on following morning collins be missing gwinett have be met on stair in middle of night coming up from garden blood be found in garden in midst of blood be clasp knife open trace of blood be continued down to sea side there ceased gwinett be moreover found to have in pocket collins purse waiter have seen over night in collins possession gwinett defence be that have received purse after waiter left room on preceding evening in consequence of arrangement that gwinett must be paymaster for that have gone down stair in night for certain purpose to garden that nose have bled dreadfully that have used clasp knife to raise latch of door have dropped in dark that have walked down to sea side close by to wash face hand stop bleeding at nose with cold salt water tale be not believed gwinett be found guilty of murder hanged on sandown common shepherd passing by gibbet few hour after execution while victim be hanging in chain perceived sign of life in cut down gwinett be recovered kind hearted shepherd sent abroad in distant colony gwinett met mr collins very man for whose alleged murder have be hanged explanation immediately ensued on night in question collins have also gone down stair to garden have be carried off by press gang who passed along sea shore at time be conveyed to boat in transported to tender vessel lying in down vessel sailed next morning collins have heard nothing of dilemma of friend until met a just described chapter lvi history of past mr de medina be son of spanish merchant who died leaving considerable fortune behind of son be sole inheritor by villainy of relation corrupt decision of spanish judge mr de medina found despoiled of rich be rightfully own at age of two twenty quitted native land in disgust to return to england where indeed have be educated language of country spoke a fluently a own be hardly necessary to state mr de medina be of jewish persuasion on arrival in london naturally applied to eminent merchant of own creed for employment be fashion in country to decry jewsto represent a invariably sordid mercenary avaricious gripingindeed to carry charge laid against to such length a to associate with name spirit of usury amounting to most flagrant dishonourable extortion charge have be repeated so often echoed seriously by so many person deemed respectable authority that prejudice against jew have become interwoven with englishman creed exception have be mistaken for rule andstrange a assertion may sound to many earswe boldly proclaim that there be not more honest intelligent humane hospitable class of person on face of earth than jew fact be when englishman be broken down in fortune can no longer raise fund by mortgage on estate by credit of name fly to money lender now jew be essentially financial nation money broking in detail be special avocation class of israelite money lender be therefore numerous be ten to one that broken down individual who requires loan address to jeweven if take money lender living nearest to to whom be first recommended wellhe transacts business with jew a can give security beyond bond bill spendthrift habit be notorious can not of course obtain loan seek save on term proportionate to risk incurred by lender yet go away curse jew a usurer thus voice be raised to denounce entire nation a avaricious griping doe person however reflect have applied to christian money broker term must have be equally high seeing that have real security to offer that name be already tarnished talk of usury of jewslook at usury practised by christian look at rapacity of christian attorneyslook at greediness of christian bill discounterslook in word at money making spirit of christian then call jew usurer par excellence be detestable calumnya vile prejudice a dishonourable to english character be unjust towards generous hearted race deem right to state that observation be recorded a disinterestedly a impartiallyas honestly a conscientiously a other comment upon prejudice abuse have ever appeared in mystery of london not drop of jewish blood flow in vein have honour to enjoy friendship of several estimable family of jewish persuasion have therefore have opportunity of judging of israelite character reader must be well aware that writer who wields pen against popular prejudice be more likely to be instigated by upright motif than who labour to maintain in following current of general opinion one be sure to gain friend in adventurously undertaking to stem be equally certain to create enemy thank god work be addressed to intelligent enlightened peopleto industrious class of united kingdomto who be true pillar of england prosperity glory greatness when mr de medina arrived friendless almost penniless on british soil addressed to head of several eminent commercial firm in city of londonfirms constituent of be of own persuasion jew always assist other to extent of meansdo christian answer ye caviller against persecuted race of israel mr de medina accordingly found occupation so admirably did conduct himselfso well did promote interest of employer by time reached age of thirty found partner in concern whose prosperity talent industry have so much enhanced then repaired to liverpool to establish branch house of trade of became sole manager partner dying soon afterwards effected arrangement with heir by abandoned share in london business retained liverpool house a own success be now extraordinary dealing be proverbially honourable fair went upon principle of doing large business with small gain paying good wage to who be in employment thus though naturally of stern severe disposition name be respected character admired at age of thirty fivetwenty year before opening of talehe married lady of own nationbeautiful accomplished rich within twelve month union be blessed with daughter on whom name of tamar be bestowed at expiration of year second girl be born who be called esther in giving birth to latter mr de medina lost life for considerable time bereaved husband be inconsolable kindness of friend conviction of necessity of subduing grief a much a possible for sake of motherless babe who be left to aroused mr de medina from torpor of profound woe became so passionately attached to child that must fondle a if be child a grew up remarkable resemblance be observed between a esther be somewhat precocious in physical point of view be a tall when ten year old a sister stranger then took for twin although there be really twelve month difference between age actually appeared to be counterpart of other hair be of precisely same intensely black glossy shade eye be of same dark hue liquid lustretheir countenance presented same blending of white rich carnation beneath transparent tinge of delicate olive bistre marked origin very teeth be of same shape shone too between pair of lip nature have made in same mould dyed with same vermillion twin rose did lovely sister seemroses on same stalk by time tamar be sixteen esther fifteen ripe beauty of former somewhat precocious loveliness of latter appeared to have attained same glorious degree of female perfection mind be not equally similar tamar be vain of personal attraction while esther be reserved bashful former be never so happy a when be centre of attraction in ball room while latter preferred serene tranquillity of home in style of dress be equally different from other tamar delighted in richest attire loved to deck with costly jewel well aware that possessed splendid bust wore gown so low a to leave room for conjecture relative to charming fullness of bosom esther on contrary selected good not showy material for dress never appeared with profusion of jewellery though of proportion a rich symmetrical a sister yet rather sought to conceal swelling contour than display tamar be of warm impassioned temperament breast be easily excited by fierce desire be embodiment of chaste pure notionsher soul abode of maiden innocence mr de medina often remonstrated with tamar upon love of splendid attire anxiety to shine in circle of gaiety way be so winning that when threw arm around neck besought not to be angry with to allow to accompany female friend to ball concert to have be invited invariably yielded to soft persuasion tamar be few week past age of sixteen esther have accomplished fifteenth year when incident occurred be fated to wield material influence over career of elder sister one night mr de medina while returning home on horseback from neighbouring village where have dined with friend be stopped plundered of purse pocket book be by mean man who be likely to yield without resistance to audacious demand of highwayman be unarmed at timeand by accident be unattended by groom robber who wore black crape over countenance be armed to teeth seemed resolute a well a desperate mr de medina therefore risked not useless contest with surrendered property a above mentioned on return home while conversing on incident with daughter suddenly recollected that pocket book contained paper of great value importance to of use to other person accordingly inserted advertisement in local newspaper offering reward for restoration of document promising impunity to robber if must give up for several day notification remained unanswered week elapsed one morning individual dressed in semi sporting style called at house inquired for mr de medina mr de medina have just left home for purpose of conducting esther to dwelling of friend who resided in neighbourhood of liverpool with whom be to pas few day tamar be however at home a servant informed that gentleman said business be important desired that might be shown up into drawing room be evidently struck by dazzling beauty of jewess who have thus accorded audience there be something so dashingso rakishso off hand without vulgarity in mannera something between frankness of open hearted man easy politeness of one who know world tamar did not treat with degree of cold courtesy seems to say have kindness to explain business then may depart requested to be seated when made few observation led to connected discourse on gaiety doings of liverpool folk suffered to be drawn into conversation without pausing to ask motive of visit thus nearly hour passed away while tamar thought to herself that have never met more agreeable gentleman in lifeand certainly never one who possessed brilliant set of teeth who looked so well in top cordsthe stranger came to conclusion equally favourable concerning indeed be quite charmed with personal attraction conversation of beautiful jewess when took leave forgot that have not communicated business even name when father returned home in afternoon mentioned to visit of stranger added that only remained few moment must not explain business to mr de medina immediately expressed belief that call have reference to advertisement concerning lost paper tamar enthusiastically repelled suspicion declaring that though have not stayed minute yet manner appearance address be of too superior nature to be associated with dishonourable avocation mr de medina asked if have intimated when must call again to question tamar fearful that must appear strange to give negative reply answeredin few day thus terminated conversation in tamar have be guilty of much duplicity be marked by first deliberate falsehood ever unblushingly told father on following day stranger returned mr de medina not having expected so soon be not at home to receive tamar be in drawing room to be conducted a on previous day be summer time be engaged in tying up drooping head of flower in large balcony stranger begged not to desist from occupation on contrary offered in gay manner of frank politeness to assist must not refuse aidshe did not wish to refuse be soon engaged in very interesting conversation held stalk of flower too while tied thread beautiful hand passed over of strangerbenot without touching while breath sweeter than perfume of flower fanned cheek once when stooped little lower under pretence of examining particular rose bud more closely hair mingled with hers must see that rich glow of excitement flooded countenanceher neckand even extended to bosom of intention to take leave tamar remembered how long have be alone together when did at length take up hat riding whip also picked up flower tamar have accidentally broken off from stem in balcony have be thinking of incident of floweryesand also of commingling of raven lock with fine manly light hair when father returned home on occasion did not mention fact of stranger visit at throughout remainder of day wondered whether must return on following one made up mind if did not to suffer to depart before have elicited business name in evening went out to make few purchase at shop in neighbouring street be retracing way when two young men walking arm in arm smoking cigarshaving withal something most offensively obtrusive in entire appearancestopped short in front of tamar passwell wo let escort home wherever be demanded one for be devilish sweet girl upon honourscarcely be word uttered when long lash of riding whip began to belabour back of two young swell in fashion made almost scream with agony tamar who instantly stepped aside recognised in champion have thus come to assistance very individual who be uppermost in thought at moment when be stopped in insulting manner described two swell be for instant so taken by surprise that dropped other arm cigar simultaneously began to caper about in most extraordinary manner stranger continuing to lash with so good will yet in such easy unexcited manner that tamar must scarcely forbear from laughing heartily when perceived that there be only one assailant rushed in upon stranger endeavoured to close with did not retreat single step hitting one of heavy blow on wrist with butt end of whip sent off roaring while with left hand caught other by collar of coat swinging roundapparently without extraordinary effortlaid on back in dust then offered arm to tamar led away a quietly a if nothing have happened at same time commencing discourse upon totally different topic a if must not even give opportunity of thanking for manner in have chastised insulting youngster tamar did thank himand very warmly too for feat be just one of very nature calculated to improve hold stranger already have upon heart of gentlythen let fall without uttering word fixed deep blue laughing expressive eye upon countenance with steadiness meant much though tongue be silent softa delicious languor came over congenial with moonlight hour conducted to within few door of father house then took leave of saying will see again to morrow entered dwelling retired immediately to chamber for heart be filled with happiness knew towards lip met embraced tenderly then declared love for herand murmured word in reply convinced that be loved in return thus on fourth occasion of meeting did pour fourth secret of heart tamar not disarm male passenger who have be robbed of rage rancour mayor be particularly indignant entire town of liverpool have be insultedgrossly insulted in worshipful person such wrath required vent pound a reward week elapsed before proclamation received answer at expiration of time following incident occurred one evening mayor entertained select party of friend at splendid banquet cloth have be removed timethe lady have retired to drawing roomand gentleman about dozen in number be passing wine rapidly round when servant entered to inform master that person wished to speak to in hall servant mendicity crime place on record ensuing observation be generally admitted axiom that among uneducated human mind be more prone to evil than virtue how greatly then must vice be disseminated evil propensity encouraged by person of description from hardened murderer to truant playing apprentice mingling without one admonitory antidote to check unemployed uneducated in proper school of morality idler tiro in crime petty misdemeanants be boy adult will listen with eager curiosity to gossiping of old hardened offender while relating to other exploit have achieved when giving instruction how to escape detection in certain situation from own experience have be led to conceive best to hear plot fresh depredation to be committed a soon a will have finished term of captivity be set at large upon verdict of 'not guilty what evil can arise from such state of congregating mind can not fail to become contaminated in degree even in best disposed among whilst others incited by picture of pleasure have described in event of successful enterprise from encouragement given to growing desire by hardened wretch enter recklessly into path of vice a soon a have turned back on prison door future accomplice companion of 'gaol bird ' who have be tutor commencing career perhaps by robbery planned whilst in prison mind not over strong sufficiently guarded by moral education be easily led astray very punishment be enduring a requital for fault committed will be used a rudder by be steered to crime in persuading that be aggrieved victim instead of criminal paying penalty due to offended justice be certain effect of present system to expect thing like repentance thorough reform in criminal must be ridiculous in work published time since be generally considered authentic autobiography of james hardy vaux notorious thief be following anecdote a corroborates be illustrative of fact above stated namely that vice be taught in prison be here inserted vaux have in most systematic manner robbed jeweller shop a conceived one of note have fallen under lash be at length taken up for stealing gold snuff box committed to newgate where made acquaintance with two brother of same profession a own committed for similar offence be very communicative to other vaux discovered that there be of favourite shop have escaped notice pointed out ' say text 'about dozen shop appeared have omitted to visit arising from making display of good from being situated in private street where have idea of finding such trade although have little hope of acquittal be agreed that in event of being so fortunate must visit tradesman have overlooked promised in case be successful to make pecuniary acknowledgment in return for information ' be further instructed in what manner to proceed what sort of good to order mr belger first rate jeweller in piccadilly be particularly recommended to notice a good fiat succeeded in getting acquitted in robbing shop pointed out to notice when like bean of honour ' did not fail to perform promise to two brothershis associate in newgate good fiat robbed more than once once too often for vaux be discovered by at last through instrumentality convicted footnote mr brandon have remark in preface just quoted frompoverty be one of great cause proceeds from public private abuse be originator of minor crime when arises from want of employment commensurate to earn sufficient to maintain large growing family so often to be found in hovel of poor of greater offence when be owing to idleness total dislike to labour of there be too many instance individual never attempting to work more day than will procure food of scant portion for family while for particular self make up deficiency by quantity of pernicious spirit so destructive to health become besotted rest of time until be compelled to labour for supply of provision at length work fails altogether either from slackness in trade party having become too enfeebled besotted to use proper care exertion then with poverty staring in face favourite liquor refused turned out of same house in have squandered so much when flushed with cash becomes half mad inflamed state of mind from drink adding to wretch have associated with in boozing hour being of worst description giving bad advice be tempted failsbut there be others who struggle in vain can only get partial employ at most who find strive to utmost can not gain sufficient to drive 'the gaunt wolf famine ' from door be doomed to behold wife child of love dearer to than life in state of starvationwhat wonder that must be induced to steal food to soften craving of hunger alleviate bitter cry of young helpless infant parental affection be strong what for man must scorn to do for sake of poor suffering child rush to rather than behold family dying in agony of starvation begin by robbing victual for be placed in prison with set of reckless vagabond by whom be taught to become a degraded a crime following crime stop not till rise to acme of profession whereas if description of prisoner have be kept apart must have returned to society nothing worse for incarcerationearly marriage be one of great cause of poverty folly to labouring class be greatly addicted getting large family before be enabled by strength ability to maintain dr granville made very curious table showing age at marry a calculation be made upon lying in hospital practice be confined to lower class none else taking benefit of such institution be confirmatory of fact of extent of evil chapter lix jew family in meantime mr de medina captain o'blunderbuss captain o'blunderbuss be gentleman of irish extraction according to own account possessed of vast estate in emerald island be evident to friend that rent be very irregularly paid inasmuch a gallant proprietor be frequently under necessity of soliciting loan of guinea when must not obtain that sum demand must suddenly drop to crown even eighteen penny whenever captain talked of estate one ventured to suggest doubt relative to existence for gallant officer be notorious duellist having be engaged a principal in thirty seven of pleasant little contest a second in ninety two more be about forty five year of age of exceedingly fierce appearance crown be entirely bald huge bush of red hair stuck out between temple earsenormous whisker of same meteoric hue portent covered faceand formidable pair of moustache red also curled ominously over upper lip end being twisted greased so a to look like two small tail in person be tall thin not ill made held particularly upright a relative to military service than be definite concerning locality of estate one knew assuredly one ever ventured to ask to what regiment have belonged stated to be unattached be sufficient must a faithful chronicler observe that have be whisperedbut then scandal be so rife in wicked captain o'blunderbuss be never in army at that formidable name be merely assumed one newsmonger who propagated first revolution in france aristocracy be steeped in licentiousness profligacy glorious nation rose in mighthurled down throne encrusted with misery of peopleannihilated bloated infamous nobilityand even gave proud arrogant clergy lesson a have never since forgotten aristocracy of france have never recovered that blowand thank heaven never will hereditary peerage exists no longer in france title talent have be substituted mechanic may now rise to be ministerthe ploughman have fair chance of becoming politicianthe delver of soil can aspire to post of deputy france be regenerated england can premium of to apprentice subject of sketch to house surgeon of one of great metropolitan hospital young wagtail though cunning crafty enough be wretched dolt only succeeded in passing examination by dint of most extraordinary cramming by mean however became member of royal college of surgeon set up in business for house surgeon of hospital soon after hinted to that intended to resign mr wagtail senior on hearing private communication made to son immediately sent house surgeon five hundred pound note in gold snuff box a token of esteem for high character of admiration for splendid talent be intelligible enough house surgeon immediately began to canvas friend on behalf of young wagtail a successor when resignation of said house surgeon be publicly announced majority of person who have right to vote be already enlisted in cause of mr wagtail several of most eminent surgeon became candidate for vacancy ability stood chance when weighed against mr wagtail interestand mr wagtail be accordingly elected thus jumped into renown handsome emolument almost a soon a entered profession thing went on smoothly enough for three four year until one morning took into head to cut off man leg when amputation be positively unnecessary disturbance ensuedthe thing got into newspapersand mr wagtail employed three poor author constantly for six month at crown day to get up pamphlet issued in defence so inundated british public with printed statement that literally bullied persuaded majority into belief that be right after then with becoming indignation threw up berth at hospitaltook magnificent house at west endgot doctor diploma at same timeand announced through medium of morning post morning herald st james chronicle that dr wagtail might be consulted daily at residence from till father died soon afterwards leaving handsome fortune a doctor when time of mourning cut a short a possible have expired began to give splendid entertainment dinner procured friend friend procured to be one of be blubbering at matilda be now surrounded by loose woman who vowed that must treat must tear eye out vainly did protest that have money tear remonstrance be of avail prostitute be village church on sunday only person who looked upon a mean spirited fellow be landlord of ale housebecause father so seldom entered george dragon even to take glass of beer at barand never stopped there to pas evening mother be very handsome woman have be village belle before marriage with farmer splint marriage be one of affection on side for though mother parent be very poor unable to give daughter thing yet farmer splint preferred to wealthier young woman of neighbourhood on side though father be nearly ten year older than refused offer of rich young farmer became spouse of man whom must respect esteem a well a love fruit of marriage be two childrena daughter named marion mother found time even amongst numerous duty care of household to teach to read write village schoolmaster then taught little arithmetic history geography be a well instructed a child of poor parent be likely to be much better than of even many richer people living in neighbourhood now from have just told will see plain enough that mother father be good honest moral well intentioned people only care be to toil with possible diligence to make end meetput by little saving when harvest be very plentifuland bring up child in respectable decent manner father be particularly anxious to prevent boy from resembling young black guard of village must never let play about in high road at marblesnor yet go bird nesting said encouraged cruelty be also first step to poaching did must to render hardy promoted innocent sport of athletic nature altogether farmer splint family be considered to be best when marion walked to church arm in arm on sunday one noticed a much a to express conviction of fitness of intended union of handsome manly youth such modest pretty girl well be summer of marriage be to take place in october when harvest be got in good ale be brewed for ensuing year thing appeared gay smiling for young people for george father have promised to give up farm to son to continue to live in house a soon a marion must have become daughter in law about three mile from farm stood beautiful seat of squire bulkeley gentleman have be left orphan when young estate be managed by guardian until came of age living with one of in london when attained majority soon showed to be tired of london life came down to take possession of bulkeley hall settle there be in beginning of for two three month squire kept pretty quiet of sudden however became a gay a be before tranquil retired change learnt arose in consequence of guardian leaving having accompanied to hall remained there until paper deed connected with accession to property be signed moment be gone number of fashionable gentleman from london arrived a guest at old mansion long silent room echoed to sound of late revellings then there be steeple chase horse racing cock fighting badger baiting kind of sport of nature sometimes young squire be more than half tipsy when lounged into church in middle of sunday evening service bulkeley a farm be own have positive fear of although land joined estate be not so however with dalton who be only tenant farmer rented fifty sixty acre of squire farm have be in old dalton family for many many year be one of best tilled best stocked in county a mr dalton be always regular with rent did not seem probable that lease be shortly to expire must be refused renewal one morningit be in month of june remember marion happened to be alone together in house when squire attended by groom rode up to door marion sent out to learn cause of visit 'this be farmer splint boy believe ' said squire who must observe be handsome young man in spite of dissipated appearance replied in affirmative adding that father be not at home 'who be at home then asked squire 'for caught glimpse of face so pretty just now at window must not mind beholding again '' be sister marion sir ' answered not seeing thing insolent in remark perhaps rather pleased by a flattered sister of whom be very fond'well boy ' said squire leaping from horse 'here be crown for now be off try find father a want to speak to in mean time will walk in rest ' catching coin threw hurried away delighted with handsome present living out of so small farm a '' get enough for want sir be able to assist friend now then ' said father'well if sell land become tenant farmer will be much better off ' observed squire for instance answer'then will not sell field '' have rather not sir '' may have equivalent portion of seven acre field over by mill yonder property will be much more compact '' land be not equally serviceable sir marion without waiting to be asked for explanation gave in following manner 'you can not dear parent think for moment have acted unworthily imprudent may have beenbut guilty oh nono one day squire called here a be well aware sent tim to search after father be most probably mere vile subterfuge on part for when tim have departed bad man began to speak to in disparaging way of george when begged tell insulting languagebut proposed to meto daughter beloved by george dalton a then wasthe detestable man implored to fly with to mansionto become mistress'here father mother made movement indicative of deep indignation marion then continued thus started away from himi be rushing towards inner room when tim returned be now no longer alarmed though still boiling with anger nevertheless have presence of mind sufficient to command emotion so far a not to utter word of reproach complaint in presence of brother for in moment did perceive how necessary be to retain in own breast secret of gross insult have received reasoned to myself that squire be landlord of daltonsthat lease must expire at end of yearthat must break old man heart to be compelled to quit farm have be in family for so many yearsand george possessed fiery spirit must render blind to consequence of avenging on squire insult offered to of thought idea flashed rapidly through brainand therefore not only resolved to remain silent in respect to insolence of mr bulkeley also tutored tim to be so reserved that dear father mother must not notice thing unusual having occurred when tim brought squire note week ago scarcely hesitated to read thinking that might indeed contain apology oh may conceive feeling when discovered that repeated insulting proposal made to on first occasion knew not how to act prudence struggled with wounded pride reflected that mr bulkeley be wealthy powerful enough to crush allfor have seen instance dear parent of rich landowner ruining small farmer who to appearance be independent of again resolved to adopt cautious line of conduct accordingly answered squire note implored a be gentleman christian not to molest more with importunity from very heart revolted besought not to ruin for ever happy prospect of two family by mean of vengeance with circumstance accident might supply conjured to believe that in keeping secret have hitherto passed between be actuated only by best of motif that letter be one tim conveyed to squire now dear parent know ' remember perfectly well that father mother be greatly affected by narrative pure minded sister thus related to be frequently interrupted by burst of bitter anguish on part moreover added that possessed squire letter to copy of one have written to him'give paper dear child ' said father 'and will at once proceed to neighbour dalton house if find george at home will undertake to bring back with to pas remainder of day to implore forgiveness for unjust suspicion if be not there be sure to see old friend to whom will give necessary explanationsbearion be somewhat soothed by hope thus held out father departed to dalton farm be about mile off two hour elapsed before came back when at last perceived returning through field be alone marion burst into tear presentiment of evil struck chill to heart a father approached serious expression of countenance filled with alarm entered seated without uttering word marion threw into arm saying in broken voice tell worst can bear thing save suspense '' dearest child ' answered old man tear trickling down cheek 'it have pleased heaven to afflict thee of likewise through thee george have quitted home and'and what ' demanded marion hastily'and father know not whither have gone ' continued 'but when first fever of excitement be over there can be doubt that will return old mr dalton be perfectly satisfied ' marion heard not word last addressed to have fainted in father armsand when be restored to consciousness be so unwell that be immediately removed to own chamber for three week life be despaired of be constantly raving of george dalton at last youth good constitution care taken of triumphed over rage of fever be pronounced out of danger ala what reply must be given to anxious earnest question concerning george old dalton have not heard of since fatal day when disappeared be no more have in moment of frenzy laid violent hand upon there be too much reason to suppose that such be case otherwise must not have written returned a gently a possible be fatal truth that tidings have be received of broken to marion partial relapse be consequence in week rallied again then first time spoke of said in a excited tone at feebleness must allow 'have ceased to love mehad loved must have borne that must think lostfaithlessdegradedoh be worse than even bitterness of death ' slowlyslowly did marion recover sufficiently to rise from bed how altered be gay cheerful ruddy girl blooming with health rustic beauty be changed into pale moping mournful creature whose very presence seemed to render joy crime smile sacrilege autumn camethe corn be cutthe harvest a plentiful a have be expected be gathered in have george be there then be period settled for wedding strange a may seem be precisely on day originally resolved upon a one to render young couple happythat old dalton did receive tidings of son george be alive have enlisted in regiment then stationed at chatham shortly to embark for india young man wrote letter communicating fact referring to former letter have written to father few day after have quitted home miscarriage of have produced so much uncertainty painful suspense colour came back to marion cheek when heard that lover be alive said 'even though may never see more can yet be happy for will now learn that be still a have ever be faithful devoted marion meantime old dalton father be deliberating together what course to pursue be determined that discharge of george must be immediately purchased proper step be taken under advice of attorney in nearest market town in mean time father wrote to full account of squire treachery marion complete innocence return of post brought tenderest most pathetic letter to marion imploring forgiveness assuring that extreme love have driven to such state of desperation a to render native district hateful to have induced to enlist need scarcely say that marion now enjoyed hope of happiness again cheek recovered lost bloomher step grew light a formerly musical voice once more awoke echo of homestead in six week time heard that george be free on way home cameit be impossible to describe unbounded joy of meeting now there be longer obstacle to union of lover wish in quarter to delay marriage be accordingly celebrated happier pair never issued from village church did ever bell appear to ring so merrily before there be grand doings at farm house for mother be determined to give treat to neighboursand feast be one a never can forget long after george have borne away bride to father house a already long before arranged be to be young couple home dancing be kept up on green in front of dwelling though cold weather have already begun to show heart be gay happy warm with good feeling old ale punch flowed bountifully for be one of day in people life be reward for whole age of care ah when look back at time think of what wasand now reflect for moment on what ambut must not reflect at let continue history without pausing for meditation happiness of family be now complete for even old dalton declared that have so much reason for joy in turn circumstance have lately taken that must even make up mind to receive refusal when must apply for renewal of lease just at time fortune seemed determined to be propitious for squire bulkeley who be in london when return of george marriage took place sent down legal gentleman to make arrangement with steward for sale of part of estate in hampshire a wanted to make up money to purchase small property in kent be wild reckless fellow full of whim fancy cared not portion of land be sold so long a preserve park be left well happened that old dalton hearing of went straight to lawyer proposed to purchase farm have be rented by family for so many year offer be accepted by aid of father money be made up paid dalton be now landowner did not remain so longfor made over newly acquired property to son george who laboured hard to improve shortly after transaction be rumoured in neighbourhood that squire have flown into tremendous passion when received news that dalton have purchased farm have doubt intended to turn out at christmas have omitted to except farm from part of estate to be sold dalton cared nothing for anger george even said that now considered sufficiently avenged upon perfidious gentleman shortly after christmas squire came down to bulkeley hall with party of friend mansion once again rang with din of reveller now come to very important incident in narrative one day george dalton have occasion to visit neighbouring market town to buy horse stayed to dine in company with other farmer at principal inn landlord of inn dined at same table with guest during meal informed company that poor discharged gamekeeper have died at house on preceding evening leaving behind only possessionthe only thing that have be able to retain from wreck of former prosperitynamely beautiful greyhound farmer be interested in tale instantly made subscription to defray expense of poor man funeral remunerate good landlord for care attention have bestowed on deceased during last illness hound be brought in one admired greatly landlord observed that wife have such aversion to dog did not dare keep on premise proposed that farmer must raffle amongst to decide to whom hound must belong be assented to lot fell on george dalton accordingly took dog home with related have occurred to father wife of whom be much pleased by acquisition of fine animal under such interesting circumstance poor gamekeeper dog accordingly became immediate favourite about week ten day afterwards in month of february george went out early accompanied by hound morning be fine frosty excessively cold george whistled cheerily a went along ponto trotting close at heel suddenly hare started from form away dashed greyhound after george knew that have right to pursue game even on own land ran after dog a hard a must calling back might a well have whistled against thunder ponto be too eager in chase to mind invocation of master well after short exciting run hound caught killed hare in very last field belonging to george farm adjoining land being squire sure enough at very instant mr bulkeley appeared accompanied by two gamekeeper on other side of boundary paling dalton by god ' cried squire with malignant sneer on countenancebut george took notice of enemy for have promised marion in most solemn manner to avoid possibility of quarrelling with so dangerous individual did not know that took out certificate mr dalton ' observed squire after pause'neither do sir replied george in cold respectful manner have done nothing be ashamed of for if have be here many minute must have heard trying to call dog off '' know what heard dalton ' said squire with significant grin at gamekeepersand away gentleman keeper went chuckling audibly very next day information be laid by squire against george dalton who accordingly attended before magistrate squire bulkeley be justice of peace sate on bench along with brother magistrate acting a judge prosecutor two gamekeeper swore that saw george encourage dog to pursue hare be in vain that defendant represented whole circumstance of case be condemned in full penalty cost abused shamefully into bargain smarting under iron scourge of oppression acting by advice of attorney whom have employed in case george dalton gave notice of appeal to quarter session wife father old mr dalton implored to settle matter at once have done with declared that must be unworthy of name of englishman if suffered to be thus trampled under foot of despotic magistracy attorney who be hungry after job nagged on too thus preparation be made to carry affair before session event made great stir in part of country liberal paper took george part said how utterly worthless a engine of justice be entire system of unpaid magistracy denounced system a monstrous oppression instituted against people well case came on before assembled magistrate on bench sate not only justice who have condemned george dalton likewise squire bulkeley prosecutor judgment be given against brother in law suddenly found called upon to pay about sixty poundsthe amount of aggregate expense original case appeal occasioned money be made up with great difficulty not without father aid though george dalton be thus relieved from fear of consequence yet became altered man went to work with heavy heart because must not prevent from brooding over wrong also found frequent excuse for visiting village on occasion never failed to step into ale house for few minute there found sympathizer generous nature prompted to treat who took part one pot led to time entered ale house stay be prolonged care now entered farm house in one old dalton marion deplored change have taken place in george in other parent must not close ear to rumour reached shut eye against altered manner of son in law great proof of dogged obstinacy george gave be in conduct respecting hound who wished well implored to dispose of declared that considered bound by reason of manner in have acquired dog to maintain treat animal kindly however kept ponto chained up in farmyard illustration time wore on summer arrived passed autumn yielded so good harvest that produce be complete set off against heavy expense entailed on two family by unlucky appeal circumstance somewhat cheered george spirit birth of fine boy restored almost completely to former gaiety in evening instead of finding pretence to repair to village sate with beloved marion happiness once more entered homestead misfortune be again impending over head of george dalton be one morning in month of november that be repairing to work with spade hoe over shoulder whistling a be wont to do ere oppression have wronged wondering also how must ever have be so foolish a to pay such frequent visit to public house in village mind be occupied too with image of marion whom have left nourishing babe perhaps heart be never lighter than at moment suddenly heard slight noise behind turning round beheld ponto who having succeeded in slipping collar have scampered after master george first impulse be to secure dog a devil must have at very instant hare jumped from form close by ponto escaped from george grasp chase ensued brother in law be bewilderedhe knew not how to act at last pursued hound taking care however not to call away went pontothe hare doubled turnedgeorge managing to keep in sight at length to horror hare swept towards hedge in point separated dalton property from squire preservesthe hedge be passed by pursued pursuing animal chase be now maintained on mr bulkeley estate run soon terminated by death of hare george after casting rapid glance around to assure that coast be clear sprang through hedge to secure ponto be however doomed to misfortune on a on former occasion gamekeeper be up before must retrace step into own property be immediately seized a poacher trespasser in dogged silence accompanied keeper to house of same magistrate who have before convicted that 'worthy gentleman ' be absent in london prisoner be accordingly taken before rector of parish who be also in commission of peace squire be sent for case be entered into under unfavourable circumstance of previous convictiona fruitless appealthe exaggerated positively false representation of gamekeepersthe malignity of squire readiness of reverence to believe thing be set forth to prejudice of prisoner parson justice determined to send case to session george be ordered to find bail be easily done be accordingly liberated second misfortune of same kind plunged two family into deepest affliction made marion very ill george said little on subject refused time to employ legal advice in getting up defence on account of expense because be notorious that unpaid magistrate always dealt more harshly with person who dared to show fight with weapon of law again there be great sensation in neighbourhood one waited anxiously for day of trial that day came george left marion on bed of sickness to repair to market town squire parson justice magistrate who have convicted defendant on previous occasion who have by time returned from london be on bench two gamekeeper swore that george dalton have coursed with same hound have led into trouble beforethat have persisted in keeping dog in spite of remonstrance of friendsthat in case then under cognisance of court have encouraged dog to chase harethat have followed into squire landand that be in act of concealing hare about person when be stopped by keeper george told entire truth in defence implored magistrate not to allow to be crushed ruined by malignity of squire bulkeley be then about to enter into explanation to show wherefore squire persecuted chairman stopped abruptly saying that have right to impute improper motif to member of court squire moreover indignantlyor at least with seeming indignationdenied such selfish purpose a sought to be imputed to be very evident that even if magistrate be not already prejudiced against dalton attempt at explanation on part fully succeeded in rendering so george be sentenced to three month imprisonment in county house of correction be forthwith removed thither without being allowed to go home first embrace sick wife may suppose marion be distracted when received intelligence although mother went broke to a gently a possible old dalton be so overwhelmed with grief that became dreadfully ill took to bed died three week after beloved son condemnation mother went to stay altogether with marion until george return took place at expiration of sentence how be alteredaltered in mind a well a in personal appearance be gaol tainted honourable feeling be impairedhis generous sympathy be ruined be still kind tender to marion child visit to ale house soon re commenced neglected work more more one night about six week after release from prison tremendous conflagration be seen in immediate neighbourhood of squire mansion out house farm be on fire despite of assistance rendered by mr bulkeley people premise be reduced to ash that be work of incendiary be clearly ascertained suspicion instantly pointed to george dalton be taken before magistrate examined nothing must be proved against magistrate however observed that felt convinced of george guilt deeply regretted necessity there be to discharge well remember that father mother evinced by manner fear that george be indeed incendiary from moment dreadful change came over sister marion grew profoundly melancholy not murmur complaint escaped lip there can be doubt that be aware who incendiary be that knowledge be death blow to happiness child deprived of proper nutrimentfor marion wasted to mere shadowdrooped died poor mother declared hysterically that loss be greatest blessing must have happened to be only allusion absenting from church will never go again sir ' be dogged answer'and why not ' demanded clergyman'because got good by ' replied dalton 'the more strove to be respectable more be persecuted hound liked almost a if be human being got into two dreadful scrape be obliged to be given away father be killed by grief for wrong wife sorrow have led to death of child character be gone know that sooner later must be ruined a have heart for work thing one prays for have so often prayed for have be swept away mean honest reputation bread of industry cheerful disposition health long life of who be near dear to '' then refuse to go to church more ' said parson justice ' do ' be answer 'and law ca compel '' will see ' observed rector away went few day afterwards squire issued summons for george dalton to produced such effect upon father that like old dalton fell ill soon died when george be liberated once more be compelled to part with farm at great loss for misfortune absence on two occasion have left indifferently cultivated moreover a father be now gone be thought better that must live together dalton farm be accordingly put up for sale squire became possessor of land once more george be now almost constantly at ale house instead of expending money realised by sale of farm after paying debt due in increasing stock improving tillage of land squandered away on worthless companion wife never remonstrated when came home late must sit up for patiently resignedly if ever mother said thing must observe george feel wrong too acutely to be able to bear up against there be great allowance to be be paid marion gradually got worse endurance be inexhaustible often gave pain to look at poor pale wasted young woman think of blooming charm when first loved george dalton heart be breaking slowlyslowlyslowly have be passionate liable to influence of strong emotion must have gone rapidly down to tomb be so meekso amiableso resignedso patientso enduring that very weakness be strength upwards of two year have passed since george second liberation from confinement when be found necessary to raise money to increase stock of farm buy seed for sowing george applied to same attorney who have got up defence on occasion of appeal man offered to induce one of client to lend certain sum on george mother joint bill of exchange said must save expense of mortgage mother objected strongly george promised so faithfully to amend conduct if must consent that did agree money be raised considerable portion found way to public house before purchase be made even then george forgot pledge became if possible more idle dissipated than before bill became due there be asset to meet lawyer however undertook to manage affair induced george mother to sign parchment deed previously read over in hasty mumbling way in blank be left for name of person who appeared to be interested in also blank for certain date fixing particular condition a to time mother inquired why name of other party be not filled in lawyer replied with chuckle be for name of client a have only lent money to serve not a mere lender motif of delicacy induce suppression for time beingbey mother did not like george urged to sign did so three month after execution be levied upon farm at suite of squire bulkeley lawyer accommodating client who have hitherto kept name secret george dalton be at first prey to most humble lodging in village need say how felt sad reversethis dreadful degradation mother marion strove hard to subdue anguish in order not to irritate already much excited george there be moment when outburst of rage be furious in extreme invoked curse upon head of squire whom denounced a murderer of father of mine also of child vowed to wreak deadly vengeance upon at ale house seems threat be repeated accompanied with bitterest imprecation on following day george be arrested conveyed before parson justice on charge of threatening life of squire bulkeley be ordered to find good bail for keeping peace security be impossible in respect to one so fallen lost characterless a to prison then again be sent for three month languished there doubtless brooding over awful wrong squire have heaped upon time squire held up head high one in own sphere of life seemed to think that have acted at unjustly tyrannically on contrary gentry influential farmer in neighbourhood looked on george if give dog bad name may hang lived a sparingly a possible on wreck of little property during three month that george third imprisonment lasted found very difficult to get work a farmer said 'that be a bad a brother in law yet there be not steadier lad in whole county than though invited never set foot in ale house be moreover regular in attendance at church along with mother sister got bad name without deserving even when must procure little employment be subjected to thousand annoyance unpleasant hint must be dropped about burning down of squire out house name of george dalton be darkly alluded to in connexion with business if refused on saturday night to accompany fellow labourer to ale house be taunted with knowing something be afraid of confessing in cup at time often thought of see in what state of mind must come out of prison three time during incarceration be marion allowed to visit on occasion returned home to humble lodging weeping bitterly mother ever questioned much for knew extreme devotion to george that must not only always endeavour to conceal failing a much a possible that likewise strove to hold out hope of complete reformation when be emancipated once more have become sullen dogged moroseforbearing only in respect to marion to whom must no longer be said to be positively kind did not mention name of squire in way allude to neither did visit ale houseand homeward mournful enough when passed large lime kiln owner of have be very intimate with george father mine happened to be coming up from pit at moment when be passing stopping entered into earned enough to keep home comfortably master be good kind to spirit of brother in law appeared to revive never mentioned squire alluded to past oftener than must help have be employed in manner for about three month when one evening george stayed later than other labourer in chalk pit to finish job knew owner wanted to be completed a soon a possible be ten o'clock before made end of toil be just seen even if have looked attentively downward 'tim ' said george in low hoarse whisper 'one of men be squire recognised infernal countenance just now when moonlight fell full upon it'we remained of pit about thirty foot above spot where george be crouched up 'tim ' said george at lastand voice be deep hollow although spoke in low whisper'do remain here quite quiet must have word two with man '' for god sake george ' said ' seek quarrel '' wo seek quarrel exactly returned brother in law 'but can not resist opportunity to tell mind to miscreant who be now seeking to deprive of bread'and before have time to utter word george be gliding rapidly almost noiselessly up craggy side of chalk pit holding by furze grew in thick strong bunch confess that strong presentiment of evil struck gamekeeper have quitted himmost likely brooding over new scheme of vengeance hateful mind have planned 'holloa said 'who be there '' george dalton cried brother in law suddenly leaping to within few still ' demanded george ' overheard word passed between vile agent if there be doubt before a to detestable malignity there be none now '' listener never hear good of retorted squire if called rascal a perhaps might have done meant what said heard mentioned by proper name '' villain miscreant cried george now quite furious 'you will no longer triumph over me'and in moment be locked in firm embrace not of love in next moment after rolled over edge of precipice down to within few pace where be standing scream of terror escaped for thought that must be killed squire lay senseless george leapt upon feetand almost at same instant low moan denoted that enemy be not dead'thank god murder have not be done exclaimed'but murder will be done tim night ' said george in voice not loud so terrible in tone that made blood run cold in vein continued bey mortal enemy be now in power for long time have brooded over vengeance have resolved to take upon when one must be near to tell tale for will not betray timyou will not give up to hangman on account of what may do '' george implore not to talk thus said falling on knee at feet'as there be living god tim above ' said george solemnly 'if attempt to thwart will make away with also ' having thus spoken raised squire in arm while still remained on knee horrified speechless never never will forget feeling then possessed squire recovered sens exclaimed 'where be who be '' george dalton mortal enemy ' be terrific reply'oh recollect now cried squire wildly murder '' last hour be come death will be a terrible a human revenge can render ' said in law must not move hand to help raise voice to shout for assistance in behalf of victim there remained on kneesspeechless stupified deprived of motionable only to exercise faculty of sight that showed horrible spectacle for having half stunned squire with fearful blow inflicted with lump of chalk george dragged towards kiln in lime be still burning diffusing pale red glow immediately above beercy once more cried squire recovering sens second timebeercy miscreant exclaimed george 'what mercy have ever shown to ' a uttered word hurled victim rather oppressor into burning pit there be shriek of agonybut be almost immediately stifled lurid glow became brighter form of brother in law seemed to expand grow vast to affrighted view so that appeared dreadful fiend bending over fiery receptacle for damned soul still be motionless speechless stupified spectator of horrible tragedy at distance of about twenty yard word can describe dreadful feeling seized upon when suddenly beheld object reach top of burning kiln cling there for instant until george dalton with foot thrust backfor object be indeed squireinto fiery tomb then film came rapidly over eyesmy head seemed to swim roundand fell back senseless be aroused by sensation of violent shaking on opening eye saw george dalton bending over shuddered fearfullyfor particular of dreadful deed so recently performed rushed to mind with overwhelming force remember that clasped hand together in agonising manner exclaiming bey god george how must do '' tim ' replied ' repent what have done human endurance must not stand more if have to live last hour over again must act in same manner fathermy fatherand child be all a good a murdered by man have deserved death death have met at last sweetest moment ever tasted be when saw crawling painfully up from smouldering bottom of pit with flesh scorched clothes singed to tinder face awfully disfiguredclinging too with burnt hand to burning lime too wretchedyes too full of horror have really be accomplished in ridding earth of monster whose delight be to crush oppress poor george said that have be to deliver message to owner of kiln after have separated from that made so late must not indescribable feeling of uneasiness be upon found even against will balancing calculating chance for against detection of murder at length mind be worked up to pitch of excitement must remain in bed no longer rose dressed having opened shutter found that day be just breaking cleared away bedding laid breakfast table a be custom presently mother marion made appearance sate down to morning secret anxiety knew be preying upon renewed protestation that be mistaken 'well tim ' said in quiet plaintive manner while blue eye filled with tear 'if thing must happen blow will be certain to kill because will be unprepared for it'for few moment hesitated whether must confide to terrific secret of murder have not courage hurried away to join brother in law at kiln a passed through village with pickaxe on back met person whom knew beplint said 'have heard thing ' know that turned deadly pale a stammered out 'no nothing particular'he did not notice change of countenance added 'the squire be missing foul play be suspected that be have heard where be george '' why must instantly ask that question after mentioning report about squire bulkeley asked be with utmost difficulty must restrain way not having intended to say thing cruel cutting for be good kind of fellow alarm increased felt so terribly uneasy that knew not whether to throw down pickaxe run away altogether whether must proceed to chalk pit while be still weighing in mind chance for against detection came within sight of fatal spot where dreadful murder have be perpetrated there be height from brother in law squire have rolled down so firmly locked in other hostile embrace there be chimney of kiln in burning pit of wretched man have endured such fearful agony before death released know not how wasbut though really wished to fly from fatal spot strange influence urged on rather attracted thither when reached point from must command view of depth of chalk pit icy chill struck to heart george be in grasp of squire two principal gamekeeper labourer of pit be gathered round mouth of kiln in manner convinced that have made discovery at instant word george have addressed to that morning flashed back to mindbehould thing happen to must be at least safe for poor creature of woman can not be left without friend protectorbey soul recovered power felt that truth of word be strong indeed yeswhat must become of poor mother unhappy marion if of protector be snatched away from never be presence of mind more necessary with firm step descended sloping path leading into pit affected extreme surprise when beheld george in custody of gamekeeper rapid significant glance on part encouraged to maintain part be playing fortunately one suspected that mere lad of fifteen sixteen like have hand in dreadful deed of there be now evidence to prove perpetration be however with affected horror gathered from hurried word of labourer particular of discovery appeared that absence of squire from home night have created alarm be augmented when be ascertained that squire have be with one of gamekeeper at chalk pit that hour afterwards same keeper have encountered george dalton in same vicinity gamekeeper finding that squire have not returned home night repaired direct to chalk work where found george dalton have just arrived dawn of day showed enough at bottom of lime pit to convince that murder have be perpetrated to question put to by who arrested george replied that have parted from at about quarter to ten o'clock on previous eveningthat have returned homeand that have remained behind to finish workbut denied having seen squire at may a well state now although be not aware of fact till hour later on terrible day that squire bailiff have be sent for moment george be arrested murder be discovered that having heard george answer to question put to set off for village by short cut over bulkeley estate whereas took main road to pit therefore have not met appears that on arrival at village bailiff went straight to lodging began to question marion mother a to whether george have be home at during night if so at what hour have returned marion named hour at have returned adding that be so late because have be on leaving off work to deliver message to owner of chalk pit bailiff then brutally revealed whole terrible truth to two female though be not there to witness same be easy to believe that be terrible heart rending indeed heedless of misery abrupt discourse have produced bailiff hastened off to owner of chalk pit learnt from that george have not be near on preceding evening back to pit went bailiff now accompanied by owner next step be to convey prisoner before nearest magistrate who happened to be rector of parish be desired to go with party suspicion be attached to be proved that calcined remains of human body be found in hole where lime be burnt that metal button picked up be belonged to coat squire have on previous evening need not detail nature of evidence appeared to tell against george dalton because can well understand from circumstance have already related conducted with wonderful calmness presence of mind throughout long examination lasted for several hour when magistrate asked if have thing to say in defence to show why must not be committed for trial answered in firm tone ' be innocent have nothing more to say ' be accordingly committed for trialhandcuffs be put upon be removed to out house guarded by constable until cart must be got in readiness to convey to county gaol in yard of rector abode heart rending scene took place marion be there waiting to see husband of whose guilt poor thing must entertain doubt have left mother who have fallen down in fit when disclosure be so rudely made by bailiff to care of landlady of house in lived crushed with deep afflictionweaksicklyalmost heart broken a be have dragged to place where heard examination be going on 'oh george george ' exclaimed a rushed forward to embrace husband whose manacle rattled a forgetting that wore endeavoured to extend arm to receive how poor marion weptwhat convulsive sob escaped bosom george wept also said thing fond endearing to console parson justice appeared at door of house perceiving sad spectacle said that woman away will not have such scene under window be doubt a bad a he'never will forget look of imploring anguish marion turned towards that minister of gospel who spoke so sternly so unjustly then in next moment fell senseless upon ground constable rushed upon george to drag off to out house hurled away manacled a be cry in voice struck terror to soul ' will not move inch till see poor innocent creature properly cared for keep offor will do murder '' murder ' exclaimed rector confesses that of squire'but george heard not observation did seem to notice tremendous oversight have committed in bewildering anguish of moment bending over marion raised with chained hand while one of rector servant more humane than master brought out water to sprinkle upon countenance at length slowly opened eye george beckoning to said 'now tim take away can not bear scene more approached lent support to poor marion while george of own accord hurried to out house not once casting look behind know not how got wretched sister homeand be nearly a wretched a herself at length reached humble lodging where landlady who appeared to be only friend left to in world did must to console miserable young wife have not be for kind hearted woman must have perished through sheer want for received notice from owner of chalk pit that service must be dispensed with in future one else must give work week after george committal mother died who be once wife of farmer well to do in world be now buried at expense of parish when funeral be over marion grew somewhat more composed insisted upon removing to winchester so a to be near gaol wherein husband lay go ' said must beg way '' then will beg way tim ' answered marion whether innocent guilty george be husband can never cease to love ' offered farther remonstrance so bidding kind landlady farewell set out with only crown in pocket for sum be indebted to same good landlady on arrival at winchester took small lodging near goal marion went to see husband insisted upon going alone did not thwart in of wish when returned to seemed little more tranquil than have yet be since dreadful disclosure of george arrest on accusation of murder be consoled by having seen husband although must not do otherwise than believe guilty of never spoke to be very careful not to touch upon point now tried to obtain work at place where applied character be inquired about at others assistance be wanted at last be actually compelled to go into street beg for marion be attacked with severe indisposition one evening a be returning home without having succeeded in obtaining single halfpenny day long in state bordering on despair be warned by beadle that if be seen begging in street again must be taken up a rogue vagabond frightened by threat hurried away be already in sight of house in lived where have left poor sister in morning when by light streaming from shop window saw old gentleman drop something on ground a drew out pocket handkerchief went on without noticing occurrence picked up object proved to be purse gold glittered through net work at one endsilver be in other ran after gentleman a hard a must hoping to receive reward for trouble must not find thinking have entered house in street waited for nearly hourbut still appeared not came on to rain hard be soon wet through to skin for clothes be old tattered pang of hunger be now dreadful idea of using small portion of money in purse by degree grew stronger stronger in mind thought of poor marion who be famished a well a myselfthe temptation be too strongand yielded rushing to baker shop procured bread thence proceeded to general dealer purchased little tea sugar butter other necessary then returned home told marion that charitable gentleman have given crown be also promised work poor brother said 'you be compelled to think of supporting a well a will not be for long tim added ' feel there now'and touched forehead'as well a here'and placed hand on hearti burst into tear implored not to talk in mournful way shook head sighing piteouslybut said nothing next day went out remained absent until night when came home again said that have obtained work at rate of two shilling day be to be paid evening so laid two shilling on table forgot to observe that purse contained about eleven pound in gold silver be determined to dole out in such way that marion must not suspect of deceiving a often a gaol regulation must permit visited husband for little comfort be now able to provide for restored strength in trifling degreeat event sufficiently so to enable to drag drooping form along to dungeon held deemed most dear once only did see george before day of trial for marion preferred to visit alone be greatly affected at beholding together thanked for kindness towards sister at last after lapse of about three month assize commenced on second day trial came on george have counsel to defend for supplied mean from purse having invented tale to account for possession of requisite sum to fee barrister so marion be satisfied be with greatest difficulty must persuade to remain at home during proceeding at be compelled to be present a witness need not detail particular of evidence given against unhappy brother in law circumstance told in disfavour observation have let slip ' will do murder ' be made most of by counsel for prosecution be examined swore have quitted prisoner at lime kiln at quarter to ten on night in question be proved that be not until past ten that gamekeeper accompanied squire to neighbourhood of fatal place therefore question be put likely to embarrass counsel for defence argued most ingeniously in george favour judge summed up against jury did not deliberate ten minute verdict be guilty george be standing in dock time that jury be whispering together when foreman pronounced doom slight muscular twitching of lip be only sign of emotion judge put on black cap sentenced to death in usual horrible term must confess that though have little room in soul for reflection of kindso much be occupied with one dreadful fact of dayi shuddered looked with loathing upon judgeto hear that old man having one foot in grave uttering disgusting cruel inhuman sentence a this'you will be taken back to place whence came thence to place of execution where will be hanged by neck until be dead then when man have done worst will not forgive attempt to reform criminal awful atrocity concludes with damnable mockery'and may lord have mercy upon soul ' call mockery because be insulting to heaven to invoke pity compassion human being so positively refuse then old judge be mere mouthpiece through blood thirsty law spoke be compelled to do duty for be so well paid still loathed that old man who must sell feeling for money who must be allured by temptation of large income to undertake office constrained to doom fellow creature to die death of mere dog wondered whether must sleep comfortably in bed afterwards thought at time must sooner be veriest beggar crawling on face of earth than judge with respect shown to himand title of lordship illustration have wandered away from subject poor george be removed from docki mean accompanied turnkey back to gaol for walked a firmly a must do at moment now have most dreadful duty to performto convey result to marion hastened back to fearful lest must learn that result from lip might not break horrible tidings slowly to when entered garret where have left found on knee praying aloud fervently sight be too much for burst into tear rose slowly took by hand said 'timdear tim need not attempt to break gently to a know have come to do feelsomething tell indeedthat be over have be long prepared for awful in hell'and then thought of crime have committed in appropriating content of purse to own useand felt ashamed in few moment other feeling came over struck that there be use in being good old daltonmy grief on account third interview be on evening previous to fatal day be heart rending indeed marion no longer resigned enduring be absolutely frantic be borne away raving wildly from condemned cell hoped that might sleep until must be over hour after hour passedeleven o'clock struck still slept now then started convulsively murmured name of husband oh how anxiously did then wait for chime proclaimed quarter how slowly went time george what be feeling now kept repeating to myself quarter pasthalf past elevena quarter to twelvethese have struck still slept a sate by bed side must hear fatal hour scarcely have done playing when marion awoke with sudden start raised to sitting posture in bed wildly glanced aroundand again started fearfully a chime being over clock began to strike hour began in tone of piercing anguish on went counting stroke till tongue have numbered twelve god 't be hour exclaimed with dreadful shriek then extending arm wildly cried ' come georgei come fell back heavily in bed a if shot through heart be more appeared that drop fell about minute after last stroke of twelve therefore by strange chance poor george must have breathed last almost at very
