shilling in pocket set out to walk to london during journey passed chalk pit where dreadful deed have taken placei passed purposely because now wanted to harden mind a much a possible for saw be use for poor friendless orphan like to think of being honest in most civilised country a be called in world have seen such abominable act of oppression perpetrated under colour of law envied naked savage in island great way off of whom have read in book for thought that be better to be barbarian without pretence of civilisation than to be barbarian with pretence have heard great deal said by father by old mr dalton also by clergyman from pulpit about paternal nature of english government now began to perceive that have be mere delusion on part of well meaning parent mr dalton rank hypocrisy wanton deception on part of parson must now think of paternal government be that favoured institution by mean of poor men might be driven to desperation then be coolly quietly hanged for deed to perpetration of have be so goaded began to look upon english people a most chicken hearted contemptible nation in world for allowing aristocracy to ride rough shod over whereas great high minded french people a have read in book have risen up like one man overthrown aristocracy altogether let continue history having passed by chalk pitthe fatal chalk piti visited immediate neighbourhood of farm house where happy family have once dweltmy own now be tenanted by stranger went on came to house to george dalton have borne sister marion blooming bride that tenement be now desertedand struck horror to heart to observeor rather to feelthat death like silence pervaded place where joyous laugh of george dalton musical voice of dear sister have once be heard o god so much misery must have fallen upon two family who strove so hard to live honestly in peace with mankind tear streamed down face a turned back into high road pursued way towards london now thought a went along if must possibly obtain honest employment in great city honest must endeavour to remaini say remain because although have committed two theft yet be far from being utterly depraved tear painful remembrance have called forth have softened heart image of lamented sister appeared to urge to virtue armed with resolution proceeded towards metropolis be evening when after two day fatiguing journey entered london put up at miserable lodging house in window of saw bill stating that single men might have bed for fourpence night eight hour good rest gave strength spirit to begin search after employment went into city inquired at several warehouse if light porter be wanted having met with many refusal being wearied with walking about went into public house to get refreshment happening to mention situation to landlord very kindly recommended to apply at certain warehouse named where knew that porter be wanted did so be fortunate enough to succeed in obtaining place with salary of twelve shilling week commenced new avocation on following morning exerted to utmost to obtain good opinion of master be regular in hour of attendance frequently remained behind at office when clerk have departed to finish labour have be assigned to in morning be economical prudent in expenditure pittance received be ample to keep at expiration of four month from time when first entered establishment have entirely gained confidence of employer salary be increased began to think that fortune be once more inclined to smile upon when circumstance occurred convinced that long lane of life have not yet taken turn employer one morning desired to proceed to particular address at west end of town insist upon payment of bill in course of business have fallen into hand have be protested instantly set out for place intimated having inquired for gentleman whose name be familiar enough to though must not suspect identity proved to be case be shown into elegant apartment where gentleman be sitting with face to fire back to door smoking cigar 'who devil that ' demanded occupant of room without turning head in voice be not unknown to 'if be dun ai at home '' have called for payment ' began'holloa who have here ' ejaculated from door of reproached for impertinence in calling by others treated with coolness contempt by third set of men one seemed to believe must possibly be honest day after day saw renewal of of old death footnote taken a body there be not more infamous tyrannical set of authority on face of earth than unpaid magistracy of england how high spirited people of country can endure such atrocious system be to surprising almost entirely irresponsiblechosen on account of wealth influence in respective county without least reference to abilitiesand by very circumstance of position opposed to interest of mass justice of peace be so many diabolical tyrant vested with power completely coerces industrious labouring class if be necessary to have paid barrister a magistrate in city great town why must not same rule apply to smaller town to rural district to invest irresponsible narrow minded prejudiced body of men with such immense power a wielded by magistrate be foul blot upon civilisation prison chain fine treadmill be at disposal of justice use make of power prof that entire system on attribute jurisdiction be based deserve universal execration thousand thousand of honest well meaning hard working family have be ruined by hierarchy of terrestrial fiend talk of freedom of british subject boast of trial by jury why magistrate by own single decision can award heavy fine month of imprisonment unpaid magistracy exists a protection also a agency for infernal game law local power influence give immense weight in general election for poor people be afraid to offend worst kind of unpaid magistrate be clergyman who be in commission of peace men usually act more like off shoot of czar of russia than a magistrate in civilised country a minister of charitable generous doctrine of christian faith footnote act be not only still unrepealed be put in force about eighteen month two year ago by certain county magistrate against two three poor labourer footnote be generally understood that judge must be merely expounder of law affecting case brought under cognizance of court also mean of refreshing memory of juryman by reading over note salient point in at least to thinking judge must never allow own opinion on point at issue to transpire if do be almost sure to bias jury unfortunately nearly judge in country act in dictational manner with regard to jury direct verdict returned assumption on part of judge of privilege attribute of jury render latter perfectly unnecessary for believe that trial by jury be in island mere farcean idle mockerya contemptible delusion judge be real jury after yet boast of institution that institution must indeed be glorious one be judge to discharge duty properly in nine case out of ten footnote there be something uncommonly barbarous in many of institution custom be not associated with such solemn occasion must laugh at mountebank piece of solemn humbug of black capas if judge must not assume demeanour serious dignified enough for awful atrocious duty law imposes upon in pronouncing death sentence custom of judge barrister disfiguring in huge wig be mere relic of barbarism unworthy of civilized age if law can not maintain solemn majesty without such wretched aid heaven know there must be something radically wrong either in constitution of tribunal in conduct of functionary of justice away with such mockery fool play a wig black cap let men distribute justice of men a men not muffled up disguised like old woman maintenance of custom barbarian ancestor handed down to show aversion to progress on part of government legislature wisdom of ancestor existed imagine only in wig let wisdom of present day show by fact of discarding useless pomp vain ostentation footnote aristocracy of england history for people by john hampden junior pseudonym of very clever writer real name whoever may be be work must be read by classesby aristocratic section of society because may warn of impending storm by middle poorer grade because will shew oppressor in true character william howitt history of priestcraft published by messrs chapman newgate street be glorious sign of time in live from first mentioned book quote ensuing passage look at france one be familiar with dreadful condition to proud imbecile aristocracy reduced one know in what storm of blood terror oppressed people rose took eternal vengeance on oppressor if read account of france just previous to revolution can not avoid being struck with terrible similarity of circumstance feature with of own country now nay following description by own historian thiers seems to be that of england at present'the condition of country political economical be intolerable there be nothing privilegeprivilege vested in individual in class in town in province even in trade profession thing contributed to check industry natural genius of man dignity of state civil ecclesiastical military be exclusively reserved to certain individual man must take up profession without certain title compliance with certain pecuniary condition even favour of crown be converted into family property so that king must scarcely exercise own judgment give preference almost only liberty left to sovereign be that of making pecuniary gift have be reduced to necessity of disputing with duke of coigny for abolition of useless place thing then be made immoveable property in hand of few where few resisted many who have be despoiled burden of state weighed on one class only noblesse clergy possessed about two third of landed property other third possessed by people paid tax to king long list of feudal droits to noblesse tithe to clergy have moreover to support devastation committed by noble sportsman game tax upon consumption pressed upon great multitude consequently on people collection of impost be managed in unfair irritating manner lord of soil left long arrears with impunity people upon delay in payment be harshly treated arrested condemned to pay in person in default of money to produce people therefore nourished with labour defended with blood higher class of society without being able to procure comfortable subsistence for town people body of citizen industrious educated le miserable than people must nevertheless obtain none of advantage to have right to aspire seeing that be industry that nourished talent adorned kingdom'be not that wonderful fac simile of own present condition circumstance produced revolution in france what will produce here if be allowed to continue will produce very same thing french historian assert have cry of people be listened to before grew maddened with misery there must have be reform instead of revolution nation must have be spared year of unexampled horror self laceration through have to wade now be same saving crisis with people most industrious of in town country starve by ten of thousand lead sort of half life in incessant labour rag hunger part of social system call out for relief manufacturer farmer equally complain agricultural labourer be reduced to condition worse than serfdomto condition of unparalleled destitution in district gang of be driven to field a learn from parliamentary report under gang master be lodged promiscuously like cattleman woman child in temporary booth fitter for beast than human being in many part of once happy country agricultural labourer be getting five six shilling per week while be asked l acre for bit of land to set few potato on author of mystery of london must not have reader imagine to be in favour of physical force nowe abhor war even with foreign power word be strong enough to express loathing abhorrence of bare idea of infernal scourgea civil war quotation from work of john hampden junior will serve to express also opinion on point neglect of public interest extends to whole frightful mass of delegated taxation under nation groan even more heavily than under direct national impost reviewer justly remark that maxim of legislator be 'every one for public for ' must state of thing possibly exist if englishman did duty if resolved to do own public business a do privateto do time a assailant have represented by beautiful figure of rhetoricthe twinkling of bed post mr curtis have deemed most prudent to go off into fitfrank be nailed to floor by terror of being captured dragged off to debtor prisonthe footman considered wise to remain mere spectator of fightand thus captain be unassisted in gallant onslaught upon sheriff officer man captain however have advantage on side namely that when have once succeeded in driving enemy back a far a staircase be comparatively easy matter to fling headlong downa feat performed without least ceremony hesitation to infinite alarm of female servant in kitchen who came rushing up into hall from lower region screaming a heartily a must under conviction that house be tumbling about ear hold pace dear exclaimed captain o'blunderbuss rushing down stair after vanquished enemyhis countenance purple with whiskey excitementevery vein in forehead swollen almost to burstingand fist clenched for renewal of onslaught will make smart for man growled mac grab a rose painfully from hall floor be jiggered if too added proggs picking up a be from last step feeling leg arm to see if of bone be broken out of house ugly baste that ye be thundered captain officer have received sufficient evidence of redoubtable gentleman warlike propensity to induce to beat rapid retreatand moment have evaporated by front door captain banged violently after securing with bolt chain be way serve out riptiles in ould ireland dear exclaimed turning towards female servant who having at length comprehended nature of amusement going on have ceased to scream be enjoying animated scene a much a if have be play frank curtis have heard front door close violently drawing of bolt afterwards convinced that house be cleared of invader accordingly descended stair laughing heartily now that immediate peril have be averted by prowess of captain resplendent footman be following close behind mastervery anxious to solicit wage discharge there then only prevented from acting thus abruptly by formidable presence of captain o'blunderbuss now frinds exclaimed gallant gentleman who be quite in element under existing circumstance house be in complate state of siege ye must look to a commander of garrison so let area ground floor window be properly fastened take care of back door wherever lead toand be jasus will keep rascal out know chapter lxxix earl of ellingham lady hatfield again be about two o'clock on day following incident just related that will find earl of ellingham seated with lady georgiana hatfield in drawing room at residence of latter arthur have returned on preceding evening from france accompanied by mr de medina esther after having seen tom rain tamar jacob smith embark at havre de grace for united state chapter lxxx mr slingsby mr torrens while scene related in preceding chapter be taking place at residence of lady hatfield in piccadilly incident requiring mention occurred elsewhere mr slingsby be seated in drawing room prey to most frightful alarm sir henry courtenay have left evening before to acquaint mr torrens with rosamond flight consult with relative to necessary step to be taken to prevent exposure mr slingsby so much dreaded on thus parting with baronet have faithfully promised to call early in morning inform her of particular of interview with mr torrensbut be now past one o'clock in afternoon have not made appearance what must absence meanhad thing disagreeable occurredwas possible that rosamond must have made away with sir henry have taken to flight through dread of exposure consequence suspense mr slingsby endured be horriblehorrible guilty conscience invariably magnify into giant even most dwarf like cause of apprehension there be exception to rule on present occasion hundred time have glanced at elegant molu clock on manteland a hour after hour passed came not restlessness increased to degree that at length reached state of nervous excitement no longer endurable accordingly hurried to chamber dressed in walking attire having left word with servant that in case sir henry courtenay must call be to be requested to wait until return sped to nearest hackney coach stand where stepping into vehicle ordered driver to take over to torrens cottage yesthither be determined to proceed without delay even at risk of encountering rosamond though must scarcely believe that wronged girl have returned home for not precisely remembering detail of conversation took place between herself baronet rosamond have overheard guilty woman imagined that something more than mere allusion might have be made to connivance of mr torrens in ruin of daughter hence mr slingsby very natural supposition that victim of infernal plot have not returned to parental dwelling coach did not proceed with particular celerity distance from west end to torrens cottage be greatmrs slingsby have therefore ample leisure to continue harrowing meditation upon real supposed danger menaced in position be by mean enviable oneunless indeed convict under sentence of death might have preferred state to of imminent ignominious death for circumstance appeared suddenly to combine against be in family wayand be alone sufficient to cause most serious chagrin especially a impious scheme of proclaiming second johanna southcott have be so completely frustrated by determined opposition of paramour then there be affair of rosamond torrens one word from whose lip must have effect of tearing away mask of hypocrisy mr slingsby have so long worn exposing to world in hideous nudity of criminal character lastly unaccountable absence of baronet filled mind with most serious misgiving for knew that if have indeed absconded if must cease to maintain in pecuniary sense position must become lamentable in extreme maddening reflection raised storm of agitation in guilty mind must scarcely subdue excitement so that must escape notice of coachman a opened door of vehicle only one establishment will break up in old burlington street be contented to dwell at cottage certainly be reply sale of furniture will pay debt perhaps leave surplus at event will have two thousand pound clear sum will place in hand to morrow morning said mr torrens interrogatively noto morrow evening after ceremony responded widow then can not trust other continued mr torrens think must act prudently to adopt a many mutual precaution a possible observed mr slingsby coolly granted exclaimed mr torrens what guarantee have when once indissoluble knot will have be tied will hand over promised sum simply fact that wish to marry man who will be next morning conveyed away to prison be mere assertion security remonstrated mr torrens be talking matter over in purely business like sense now a far a can see advantage will be on side if happen to be in debt will have husband on whose person creditor will pounce instead of on own at event a be with child will have person whom can represent a legitimate father of expected offspring will tell how business can be managed said mr slingsby after pause thought have struck will lodge money in hand of very respectable solicitor whom know can accompany to office for purpose in keeping will remain with understanding that be to be paid to on becoming husband good observed mr torrens who be solicitor mr howard be answer know have about twelve will go to bank between ten eleven can in meantime obtain marriage license will be done returned mr torrens ceremony will be performed here added interrogatively yesat seven o'clock in stated a laconically a possible that bread have risen to thirteen penny quartern loaf recorded rapidly disposed of regret that provision must be so dear on account of poor second gave laboured fulsome tom foolery of royal dance be deemed of sufficient importance to merit nearly two column oh instead of giving ball splendid entertainment at time if sovereign of land be to say to people be starving make heart bleed to think that from very vitals be wrung hundred of thousand of pound be wasted by other member of royal family on frivolity whim caprice wanton extravagance therefore will give ye back one half of enormous income have hitherto enjoyed in full confidence that example will be imitated by many others who prey upon sovereign thus speak to nation nation must be justly proud of sovereign yet sovereign must only be performing duty dictated by humanity common justice what must be thought of father of family who feasted on turtle venison accompanied by generous wine day while child be thrust into cold humid cellar to devour mouldy crust drink water yet sovereign delight in attribute of general comprehensive paternal solicitude in welfare of people be attribute exists only in imagination of grovelling courtier lick spittle historian royalty aristocracy be intenselynecessarilyand thoroughly selfish a for anxiety on behalf of toiling suffering million idea be absurdthe notion be mere delusionthe assertion that feeling exists be liea monstrous wicked atrocious lie there be more of milk of human kindness in single cottage than in palace of europe taken together there be more true philanthropy in one poor man hovel than in thousand mansion of great wealthy in fashionable quarter of london oh if father mother can dance be glad while child be famishing sooner tie be severed between such worthless parent oppressed outraged offspring better nero danced sang on summit of tower at spectacle presented to eye by burning romeand festivity rejoicing reign in english brow people of ireland ye now comprehend how much pity starving condition excites on part of ruler people of scotland ye now perceive how worthy great one of realm be of adulation be sickening a be sorrowful to dwell on subject of reader may perhaps ask wherefore broach at will reply by mean of few question be not individual member of society interested in welfare of society ought not at least to be so be not justified in denouncing error downright turpitude of magistrate whom that society have chosen to govern who derive power only from good will pleasure be not indeed duty to proclaim error that turpitude must not duty be performed even if be unpleasant can ever hope to ameliorate condition unless expose abuse oppress degrade demoralise oh let one rashly in random manner say that care nothing about politics such assertion denotes wilful disregard not only of neighbour interest also of own be men to entertain such indifference people must be veriest slave that unrestrained despotism unwatched tyranny must render be a necessary for industrious class to protect right privilege by zealously guarding a to adopt precaution to save house from fire one word more be common saying a absurd a be commonoh woman have right to meddle in politics woman on contrary have a much right a lord of creation to exhibit interest in system institution by be governed for sake of child a well a for own must assert exercise right be lamentable delusion to suppose that intellect of woman be not powerful comprehensive enough to embrace such consideration intellect of woman be naturally a strong a of man have le chance le opportunity of developing capacity masculine study of politics must aid intellect of woman in putting forth strength hope that day be gone by when female sex be to be limited to occupation of drawing room nursery kitchen wish to see woman become soldier sailor to work at severe employment be anxious to behold thinker a well a readersutilitarians a well a domestic economist know of greater benefit must be conferred on society in general than might be derived from influence of well developed intellect of woman mind be naturally better poised than of man far seeing quick sighted be shea readiness at devising combining plan to meet emergency be intuitive with judgment be correcther taste goodand profit by experience far more usefully than doe man be not absurd thenis not unjustand be not unwise to deny to woman right of exercising proper influence in society of be ornament delight ala that there must be such exception to general rule of female excellence a martha slingsbya woman whose principle be thoroughly corrupt whose licentious passion be of most devouring insatiable kind whose talent for wicked combination evil plottings be unfortunately so great let return to hypocritical abandoned creature follow in vile scheme now occupies attention having breakfasted at early hour seated at desk whence drew forth packet of letter received by at various time from sir henry courtenay signature of now became object of special study art of counterfeiting late baronet autograph be practised by for nearly hour for though be already tolerably confident of ability to forge signature most successfullyas have assured mr torrensshe nevertheless deemed prudent to render imitation a perfect a possible at last atrocious deed be accomplished to complete satisfaction cheque for two thousand pound lay drawn in thoroughly business like manner upon desk be bold courageous in execution of plot carrying out of deep schemesbut dark dangerous crime have just perpetrated caused to shudder from head to foot hitherto wickedness have be of nature calculated only if detected to involve in disgrace not in perilto ruin character not place life in jeopardy now have taken stepa bold desperate stepwhich at once set on high road conduct who be found treading pathway to foot of scaffold yesshe shrank back trembled violently a rose from desk whereon forged cheque now lay for moment be inclined to seize itto rend into thousand piecesand thus to dispel at once in instant tremendous black cloud of stormy danger have drawn over own head noshe have courage enough to be wicked rash have not strength of mind sufficient to render prudent therefore decided on daring allrisking everything by presentation of forged cheque having dressed in style of unusual elegance proceeded in hackney coach to lombard street alighted at door of banking house on cheque be drawn saying to herselfnow for aid of courageshe entered spacious establishment advanced towards counter one of numerous clerk in attendance instantly received cheque handed across to himand a left hand chill struck to heartand must at moment have given world to recall composure be now only effect of utter desperation so unruffled be countenance that not lineament be so changed a to be calculated to engender suspicion clerk took cheque to nearest desk upon attorney bowed client out of office mr torrens escorted mr slingsby back to old burlington street then repaired a fast a horse gig must take to own dwelling to sit down to early dinner afterwards for step be now taking cannotcannot support idea of dwelling beneath same roof with lady who be soon to be mother in law know promised not to desert paternal home that promise be given in sinceritythough maddening reflection now render incapable of keeping be well aware how dreadfully feeling have be woundedhow cruelly heart have be lacerated during last few hour have struggled against violence of griefi have endeavoured to subdue anguishbut occurrence of last nightthe outrage attempted by villain jeffreysthe revelation of terrible secret relative to sir henry courtenayoh dear followed by blessing grieve not for dear fatherheaven will protect from time to time will write to must happier day arrivebut of ala dare entertain hope at present to must leave painful task of in hand be cry very much sir responded servant made quite sad to see attempted to comfort only shook head impatiently then sobbed a if heart must break knew that be going to leave because have small package in hand did cry so dreadful when told to give note mr torrens turned aside hastened to chamber where remained until half past five o'clock then descended to parlour dressed for nuptial ceremony to servant enquiry relative to serving up of dinner replied that have appetite immediately gave order for horse gig to be got ready by stable boy who have be hastily hired in morning to take place of jeffreys until more efficient substitute must be found command be soon obeyed shortly before seven o'clock mr torrens arrived in old burlington street flight of daughter from home have proved more severe shock to than reader might imagine considering cold heartless disposition of man be not that felt must miss societynohe did not love enough to harbour regret of naturebut departure from paternal dwelling have made writhe beneath maddeningthe galling conviction that independence be in measure gone that stern necessity have compelled to assent to link fate with of woman so vile abandoned that own child fled at idea of approach influenced by such feeling a be easy task for mr torrens to assume complacent demeanour suitable to occasion of nuptials nevertheless managed to conceal emotion wrung so acutely played part with tolerable satisfaction to mr slingsby a introduced to dr wagtail other guest including clergyman who be already assembled at house ceremony be performed by reverend gentleman just alluded to dr wagtail giving bride away splendid banquet be then served up shortly after ten o'clock mr mr torrens departed together for cottage chapter lxxxiii reward of crime at past eleven on following morning mr torrens entered office of mr howard solicitor countenance wore smile of satisfaction in spite of various event have lately occurred to harass for be about to receive large sum of moneyand finger itched to grasp bank note gold have seen stowed away in safe on preceding day already beheld debt paidhis mind freed from pecuniary anxietiesand speculation prospering in manner giving assurance of realization of splendid fortune pleasing vision with imagination have cheered during drive from cottage to attorney office naturally tended to bestow on countenance expansiveness of good humour after be pleasant thing to enter place where one be about to receive good round sum of money even though amount will not remain long in pocket must be paid away almost a soon a fingered mr torrens have never felt more independent than did on occasion look bestowed upon poor beggar woman with child in arm a ascended step leading to front door of mr howard abode be one of supreme contemptas if pauper be indeed despicable object wellmr torrens entered office with smiling countenancebut be immediately struck by strange aspect of thing there presented place be in confusion clerk be gathered together in group near window looking particularly gloomy conversing in whispersseveral gentleman be busily employed in examining japanned box bore name contained title deedsand two three female be weeping in corner exchanging such dimly significant observation asoh rascalthe villainto rob poor creature mr torrens recoiled aghast speechless from contemplation of alarming scene chill struck to heart in common parlance one might have knocked down with straw good heaven gentleman exclaimed at length recovering use of tongue what be meaning of ask youngster there sir said one of individual engaged in examining tin box speaker pointed towards clerk in manner seemed to imply that news be too shocking for to unfold that be moreover duty of lawyer subordinate to give required information well gentleman what be matter demanded mr torrens turning to clerk have thing sudden happened to mr howard oh very sudden indeed sir be answer vouchsafed by one of person thus appealed to accompanied by sinister grin be dead enquired mr torrens excitement now becoming absolutely intolerable sirhe be dead exactlybut what cried torrens trembling from head to foot be bolted sir be astounding answer absconded murmured mr torrens faintlyand reeling like drunken man must have fallen have not come in contact with wall yesit be indeed too note chapter lxxxv history of livery servant parent be very poor very honest be only child father be light porter in warehouse earning fifteen shilling week mother took in washing to obtain few shilling more lived in court leading out of high holborn occupied one room be very decently furnished for people in parent condition of life thing moreover being own father have good suit of clothes mother nice gown bonnet shawl for sunday holiday also took care to keep neat decent in dress of ever went to public house except just to fetch beer for dinner supper be always regular in attendance at church in addition to proof of good conduct respectability put by two three shilling week a provision against rainy day may be sure that to be able to do lived very economically indeed in fact more industrious couple did not exist than father mother will admit that deserved to succeed in world much have heard from people who knew for died when be too young to be able to understand way judge of merit seems that mother be very pretty young woman have be servant in family of merchant in whose warehouse father be attachment springing up between married merchant whose name be shawe have sona dissipated young man addicted to gaming bad company consequently source of great uneasiness to parent who be highly respectable people during time that mother be in service at merchant frederick shawe be on continent father having sent to commercial establishment at rotterdam in hope that must amend way when under care of comparative stranger hope appears be completely disappointed young man be after sent back to father house a irreclaimable at time parent have be married three year be two year old mother be in habit of taking father dinner to at warehouse whenever duty prevented from running home to get on one of occasion frederick shawe saw a be going out of establishment followed made insulting proposal behaved most grossly have with circumstance rendered conduct more abominable if thing be wanting to aggravate indeed persecution be carried to excess that be obliged to take refuge in shop where went into hysteric through fright indignation shawe sneaked away moment found that master of shop be disposed to take mother part against when be little recovered be sent home in hackney coach on return of father in evening told have occurred seems that have scarcely made end of narrative when frederick shawe entered room declared that have come to express sincere penitence for what have done to implore that father might not be made acquainted with behaviour seemed so earnest so excessively sorry for infamous conduct that parent consented to look over thanked over over again took departure father however desired wife never to come to warehouse to more a be unwilling to expose to even chance of repetition of insult few week after occurrence frederick shawe one evening when under influence of liquor called at lodging father being absent renewed outrageous conduct towards mother alarm be created in dwellinga constable be sent forand young gentleman be taken off to watch house of course matter be now too serious to be hushed up elder mr shawe necessarily learnt particular son be fined held to bail to keep peace towards mr jeffreys father obtained situationfor though old merchant knew that son be alone to blame yet father thought that must not prudently remain in place where must daily meet person who felt convinced be now sworn enemy such indeed did frederick shawe prove to be for by misrepresentation heaven only know what other underhand mean so successfully avenged that poor father soon lost new situation be totally unable to find most infamous report be circulated concerning took cruel treatment have received so much to heart that spirit be completely brokenhe fell ill died in few week poverty despair thus seized upon mother at same moment saw happiness suddenly blasted by agency of reckless villain to add to affliction only friend who showed compassion for who came forward to assist in midst of wretchednessnamely old merchantwas suddenly snatched away by hand of death ten day after earth have closed over father remains poor woman be unable to bear up against sorrow languished for few month then departed life leaving friendless unprotected orphan at tender age of three year may guess what then became of be taken to workhouse have sketched circumstance just to show how unfortunate be in earliest infancy parent must have lived to thrive prosper have not be for miscreant frederick shawe under protection must have be happy however be destined that father mother must be cut off thus early cruel fate threw a pauper child upon parish at workhouse remained until be thirteen be from elderly couple whom distress brought to same place who have known parent well that learnt particular have related to well at age of thirteen be transferred to care of surgeon accoucheur who took into house to clean boot shoe run on errand beat up drug in mortar finding active a said good looking ladfor be not then seared with small pox a be nowhe put into regular livery of doctor boy after have be with few month be then entrusted with delivery of medicine master be old man wife be bustling active elderly lady in whom implicit confidence might be placed a long a be well paid for service secresy will understand what mean very shortly in fact one day noticed great deal of whispering between doctor wife housekeeper look be mysterious important certain preparation too commenced showed that visitor be expected for be shrewd observing boy for age be ordered to clean window in spare bed room well furnished little parlour communicating with while be thus occupied housekeeper put two apartment into nicest possible order asked if one be coming to stay at house be desired to mind own business accordingly held tongue curiosity be only more excited in consequence of answer received mystery in motive of preparation in progress be involved at earlier hour than usual be ordered to retire to own room a commanded view of streetit be brook street holborni sate up watching at windowfor felt sure have not be dismissed to attic without good reason be mistaken at about half past ten hackney coach drove up to door two trunk be carried into house lady muffled in cloak be assisted to descend from vehicle by doctor wife who seemed to treat with greatest respect be able to notice passed because moon be bright be looking out of open window lady accompanied doctor wife in door coach drove away next morning saw housekeeper take up breakfast tray to room have now no doubt be occupied by lady who have arrived night before be cautious not to appear even to notice that thing unusual be going on much le to ask questionsfor remembered rebuff have already received in latter respect cook housemaid be a mysteriously reserved a housekeeper herself must not for life of make out what meant to be brief month passed away though never saw tenant of spare room while yet knew that tenant room have for meal be regularly taken upthe doctor looked in there two three time dayand wife passed hour together there at length housemaid who be pretty wicked looking girl of about nineteen undertook to initiate into secret so much puzzled taking advantage of sunday evening when be alone together other servant having gone out explained how young lady who be not married be about to become motherand how spare room be always kept for lodger of kind'have seen ' asked'no ' replied 'nor be likely to see have be four year in house during time there have be eight ten lady here in same way never caught glimpse of face of one of pay friend pay for good round sum to master for accommodation be manner in have made so much money for can see follower man have seen in morning into house without caring how master mistress might take on part threw open dining room door led officer in pointing to person wanted said 'this be mr frederick shawe ' officer instantly arrested scene of extraordinary confusion followed mr turner fainted in right earnest while several of lady flocked round others began tittering whispering mr turner requested mr shawe to pay bill before went to prison conduct of mr percy be most extraordinary part of whole performance be however most probable that acted in way did to conceal vexation annoyance for bursting out into loud laugh casting look of contempt at man with whom be on such good term few minute before expressed surprise 'fellows of stamp must dare to force way into genteel society'to be brief mr turner must not get amount of claim on shawe whose trunk accordingly detained scoundrel be conveyed away by officer followed party to street door took good care to let shawe know that be who have betrayed exposure of person caused sensation in house that share in created feeling of curiosity when questioned by mr turner before company explained how have treated parent so be rather praised than blamed for what have done mr percy applauded most spoke warmly in favourat be very much pleased two three day after occurrence mr hulse returnedbut only for few hour during time be alone with mr percy in parlour nature of interview be soon known throughout house for appeared that news have brought from uncle be favourable engagement be now no longer kept secret be fortunate for widow that did not remain in boarding house until marriage for if have kind friend must have be sure to tell of flirtation have gone on between herself scoundrel shawe a be thing turned out well mr hulse took furnished nice house in bloomsbury square in few week mr percy be married former service be not forgotten by on contrary be rewarded on wedding day by guinea from gentleman half sum from lady have thus seen end of very extraordinary courtship being thoroughly tired of place began to look out for accordingly made usual enquiry heard of several vacancy very first application be successful be engaged by honourable mr ilverton mr turner giving good character expressing dissatisfaction at desire better ' honourable mr ilverton resided in st james square be gentleman of about forty year of age be on point of marriage with lady much younger than who be one of numerous daughter of marquis of mountcharlton a mr ilverton be very rich marquis be poor peer match be considered very desirable one by friend of lady hortensia stanhope heard fellow servant in new place say that be very beautiful creature longed to see six week be yet to elapse before celebration of marriage place be very nice one establishment be on large scale there be six female servant four men besides butler coachman two of footman be constantly on duty in hall be have nothing to do for four hour that turn lasted to look out of hall window attend front door when four hour expired other two took place for like interval there be great deal of aristocratic feeling amongst servant butler have room housekeeper have room took meal apart from rest other servant be obliged to say beir to butler bea'be ' to housekeeper cook two housemaid be likewise above kitchen maid who said beiss when addressing one of footman also considered above coachman allowed latter to take meal at table a for myself be looked upon a mere child by men probably by woman toofor be very much addicted to fondling when happened to be alone with one of well six week passed away day came on mr ilverton be to be married ceremony be performed at st george hanover square 'happy couple a newspaper always call new married people started off for mr ilverton country seat fortnight elapsed then came day when town mansion be to receive new mistress whom have not yet seen remember profound curiosity felt on occasion fellow servant who have frequently beheld having spoken so high of beauty be about six o'clock in evening when be expected to arrive dinner having be provided for seven stationed in hall to obtain a early view a possible of lady hortensia ilverton shortly after six carriage drove up to door from hall window saw ladyship alight have veil over face be however enabled to admire beauty of figure be very finely proportioned thought a stepped from vehicle have never before seen charming foot ankle loveliness of form rendered more anxious to behold face curiosity on part be soon gratified for on entering hall lady threw back veilbut word can explain full extent of astonishment when beheld very same charming creature of whom have once before caught hasty glimpse at doctor house in brook street faint exclamation of surprise escaped lip one however heard itand instantly mastered feeling lady hortensia passed through hall leaning on husband arm without looking to right to leftand a did not therefore observe have opportunity of knowing whether must remember not be part of duty to help to wait at table longed for dinner hour to arrive to clear up point at length doubt be set at restdinner be served upthe lady saw felt convinced that have completely forgotten face be not however quite year older than when saw at doctor therefore not much changed nevertheless evidently did not know again really felt relieved attentively though conversed pleasantly enough with husband when started subject addressed to yet struck that be not altogether happyfor seldom commenced topic of own accord seemed rather to love silence now then fancied that sighed in subdued manner know when ever felt deeper interest in one than did in lady seemed to a if must do thing to serve be afraid that be tiring with long storyand few observation relative to large important classdomestic servant first of female servant be said that great number of be immodest that from rank class of unfortunate woman prostitute be largely recruited believe that immorality of female servant be considerably exaggerated by representation that case of frailty be exception not rule there be thousand thousand of female amongst class a respectable well conducted a woman ought to be who take pride not only in maintaining spotless character in so behaving that there will be chance of becoming tainted be more creditable to themthe more to honour inasmuch a temptation to be exposed be very great sent out on errand at hourscompelled to go to public house to fetch beer spirit for use of familyconstantly placed in contact with serving men belonging to family tradesmenexposed to chance of sustaining insulting liberty at hand of visitor to houseand often persecuted by lustful address of male inmate of establishment such a brother son of master perhaps master strength of mindwhat moral courage must servant maid posse to resist temptation escape from so many peril mean to say then that if do fall there be far more scope for pity far greater amount of extenuation on behalf than on of lady who surrender unmarried to embrace of lover in manytoo many instanceswhat life of slavery be that of female servantand how little enviable be lot of poor maid of work talk of hard fate of negressthink of hard fate of maid of work excellent saint of exeter hall need not send sympathy travelling thousand of mile across sea there be plenty of scope for exercise at home if be really sincerewhich know be not look to maid of workup at five in winter heaven only know when in summercompelled to keep entire house neat decentto black boot shoesto run on errandsto put in awful peril by standing sitting outside window be compelled to cleanand very frequently half starved by whom serf so assiduously so faithfullywhat life be hers female servant be treated with much greater kindness in france than in england in former country be considered rather in light of humble friend of family than a mere slave be estimation in be usually held be sorry to say in british island let be treated with kindness forbearance have much to try patience sour temper by very nature of condition miscellaneous character of avocation man woman who be unkind to servant be wretch deserving obloquy execration master mistress who through petty spite sheer malignity refuse to give to discharged servant good character such servant may in reality deserve be very fiend unfit to remain in civilised society illustration before take leave of subject can not resist opportunity of expressing opinion relative to practice adopted at court mean fact of queen being waited upon in private apartment by lady of high rank good family instead of by female servant who be queen victoria that duchess must select gown marchioness hook be goddess that countess must help to put on shoe baroness tie must not royalty be touched by hand of female servant ala strongly suspect that queen victoria be woman made of same flesh blood a most ordinary mortal feel confident that practice of attaching lady of rank title to august person be a pernicious to a be degrading to lady a flagrantly insulting to entire class of well conducted lady maid royalty in country must be idolizeddeified mean must be left untried to convince credulous public that royalty be something very different from commonalty delusion will however be dispelledthe people must be taught to look on victoria a nothing more than chief magistrate of country deriving power from nation at large holding only so long a majority of inhabitant of realm may consider worthy to retain contemptible farce of firing cannon to announce movementsof illuminating dwelling house on birth dayof cheering whenever appears in public just a if cared two fig for bawling idler who gaze on majesty with awe astonishmentall miserable humbug must be abolished more sovereign be deified more people be abased instead of nation being obliged to queen victoria for ruling over queen victoria ought to be very much obliged to nation for allowing to occupy high post for only real sovereign power be that of people individual who look on royalty a something infallibledivinesupernally grand awe inspiring be drivelling narrow minded idiot unworthy of enjoyment of political freedom fit only to take place amidst herd of russian serfdom footnote incident be founded on fact many of reader will doubtless recollect case of jnand mother who be convicted of robbing ready furnished lodging about ten year ago miss jnhad be mistress of noble lord who be cabinet minister at time of condemnation of mother who be cabinet minister at present moment affair created great sensation at time dispatch other independent newspaper took up not in order to persecute unhappy woman on public ground result be that original sentence passed upon ministerial favouritism sought to commute to much milder penalty be carried into force entire business so far a noble lord be concerned be vile scandalous in extreme footnote avail ourselves of opportunity afforded by glance be taking at subject to recommend to perusal admirable little work written by esteemed talented friend mr john taylor sinnett entitled servant girl in london be published by hastings carey street lincoln inn field be little book must be found in family a contains sentiment precept useful alike to employer employed in work from have frequently quoted in note belonging to present series of mystery of londonwe allude to poverty mendicity crimewe find important passage bearing strongly upon subject of text run a followswe must now direct attention to class of female servant form insignificant number from higher rank of prostitute be recruited thirst for dress finery have crept on to degree that be not very rare sight to behold waiting on mistress in morning bedecked in silk ornament equal to young lady even where lady be of highest class of community great censure be due to lady especially who be mother for not restraining servant from squandering away whole of money loss of place ought to be consequence of not laying by small portion of wage to sustain in event of illness other unforeseen calamity dress of female servant ought to be good perfectly void of ridiculous ornament frippery lady maid of aristocracy be race most highly culpable of sex aping pride air of lady desiring to appear abroad with equal clat to effect wardrobe of mistress be not unfrequently resorted to purse not always held sacred becomes prostitute whilst under roof of employer till descending from one false step to at length link fate to favourite of swell mob to whom at first listened a suitor end in being accessary to robbing family have fostered be ascertained beyond doubt that most of house be robbed arises from connexion intimacy servant have contracted with of petty workman who have be employed about premise many of whom be thief connected with gang of villain who resort to expedient to learn what property be kept on premise how be disposed of at night ' great deal of crime ' say mr nairn in evidence 'be generated in consequence of tradesman who employ journeyman to work for in gentleman house not taking care to inquire into character by getting acquainted with servant get knowledge of part of house where anything valuable be kept number of men be in prison be painter plasterer bricklayer be in practice of communicating with thief be in secret manner that get information where property be kept'vide j h nairn p nd report lord on state of gaol there be most infamous conspiracy existing between purveyor housekeeper of aristocracy tradespeople latter paying former large per centage on bill for sake of 'gaining custom ' twenty per cent be often given have be known to rise a high a fifty unfortunately nobleman considers a derogatory to high rank to look into pecuniary domestic affair taking in moral point of view be duty to do so for sake of preventing specie of peculation be absolute theft one of stepping stone to crime generally a money so attained be mostly a lightly spent servant out of place for length of time difficulty to procure wherewithal to keep alive former extravagance make not hesitate to become regular thief fine sense of honesty having be destroyed by transaction with tradesman who have not failed in turn to make out bill more than sufficiently long to cover merely generosity in bestowing christmas box upon domestic of patron tradesman be rank disgrace to more honest fellow shopkeeper be worse than fence be greatly to be regretted that complete expose can not take place such tradesman dealt with according to merit evil in society be pregnant with mischief be giving false character to servant lady be constantly in practice of doing to avoid being plagued 'perhaps a say 'insulted by discarded servant whose character if correctly stated must not be such a easily to procure new situation thus pilferer having once have luck to start off in private family with good name be from shameful habit let loose upon public to commit depredation at leisure convenience with chance of blame falling upon honest individual through crafty machination of wicked by making servant conscious that must only procure such character a really deserve great good must accrue to public generally servant must be taught to curb temper other bad propensity by must become infinitely more contented happy being valuable member of society be too often case that servant be looked upon a little better than slave so to treat to say least of such conduct be unwise for in proportion to kindness with be treated so will study in return to make enjoy numberless little comfort so delightful to experience be in power to give life to destroy humanity ought to suggest that situation in person be placed witnessing nightly scene of pleasure without being permitted to join in be sufficiently grating for have feeling in common with best of ought to be one of first care of head of family to lighten a far a consistent with rule shade of society state labour of dependant in france servant be in enviable condition compared with of england if plan be followed in country giving little pleasure many one whose propensity be wavering must be confirmed in virtue become useful member instead of disgrace to society chapter lxxxvii blackamoor upon quitting old death abode tim snammer josh pedler proceeded together in direction of blackfriar bridge while john jeffreys having wished worthy good night pursued way up horsemonger lane plunged into maze of narrow obscure street lying at back of prison although have said good night to companion be in reality morning for clock of gaol chimed quarter past three a jeffreys passed by dismal looking establishment having reached door of house in lodged be in one of street above alluded to drew pas key from pocket be about to apply to lock when sound of footstep close by fell upon ear almost at same moment heavy hand be laid upon shoulder conscience of mr john jeffreys be not quite so free from source of alarm a to prevent from being painfully startled by occurrence turning suddenly round towards individual who have thus accosted found face to face with blackamoor fear notno harm be intended said negro in deep solemn sonorous voice without least peculiarity of accent be added if follow direction who be demanded jeffreys reassured by certainty that be addressing myrmidon of law be not for to question to answer said black in cool authoritative manner seemed to indicate consciousness of possessing power to enforce will even against resistance might be offered have time to waste in unnecessary discourse must accompany whither will lead if refuse asked jeffreys trembling scarcely knew why then will summon to aid who be ready at hand who will carry off by force calmly replied black if raise alarm said jeffreys gradually yielding to sensation of awe in presence of mysterious stranger who spoke with confidence of power authority neighbour will come to rescue truce to argument interrupted black sternly if accompany of own free will will be to advantage harm will befall if venture to resist will unhesitatingly make prisoner by force will then see what account john jeffreys can give of long intimate connexion with old death will go with youi will do thing command said villain trembling from head to foot only again tell that have nothing to fear much to gain observed black taking jeffreys arm led hastily back towards horsemonger lane of uttering word a thus hurried along nightor rather morning be dark sombre there be lamp in street be threading thus although arm in arm together jeffreys must obtain very imperfect view of companion feature nevertheless struck that though stranger countenance be black a of african negro facial outline be not characterised by protuberant thickness of lip hideous flatness of nose usually belong to race jeffreys be too much alarmedtoo much bewildered by sudden mysterious adventure have befallen to be able to make very steady reflection whenever threw furtive glance towards companion countenance be instantly met by eye pupil of seemed to glare upon from brilliant white like of basilisk be indeed awe inspiring most uncomfortable situation in jeffreys found placed having numerous misdeed upon conscience shuddered at idea of coming in contact with law if offered resistance to strange companion such contact be alternative with be menaced who be strange companion who be black that spoke with tone of authority acted in manner denoting consciousness of power for what purpose be now hurrying jeffreys along through darkness of silent night whither be going even have man be armed with conscious innocence position be one calculated to engender acute suspense painful doubt wild apprehensionbut knowing that have be guilty of many deed one of must be sufficient to involve in serious trouble with regard to law miserable wretch have thing to fear scarcely thing to hope be true have received assurance that harm must befall that incident must on other hand prove advantageous to influence of assurance be completely absorbed in vague terrible alarm dread mystery of adventure be so well calculated to excite conscious guilt made complete coward idea became so confusedhis nervousness so greathis excitement so wild that began to fancy be in power of unearthly being of evil nature design a impression grew stronger in attenuated mind cast in terror more frequent glance at companionand now seemed a if black countenance be rapidly changingbecoming hideous to behold lighted up with eye burnt in socket like red hot coal john jeffreys felt leg failing beneath himhis brain whirlinghis reason goingand be on point of falling to ground overcome by terror oppressed when companion voice suddenly broke upon ear dispelling superstitious portion of alarm recalling to sens step in said blackand jeffreys found by side of hackney coach be waiting beneath wall of horsemonger lane gaol obeyed command issued in authoritative tone dared not resist black followed into vehicle immediately drove away must now blindfold observed mysterious stranger warn not to attempt to discover road be about to pursue even in darkness prevails in coach will be able to distinguish movement where be be about to do with asked jeffreys in imploring voice if be such coward a now seem to be will prove of little service to be afraid said black a fastened handkerchief over prisoner eye cheer up man added in tone not altogether free from contemptuous disgust if meant to deliver into hand of justice for numerous misdeed must not take round about manner of accomplishing task once more tell that result of adventure word just addressed to great deal be laconic answer will not continue discourse at present if please intimation be followed by profound silence vehicle rolled along at rapid rate jeffreys be now so soon became aware that be taking such circuitous tortuous way a fully to destroy possibility on part of instituting clue to course at last threw back in vehicle to give way to reflection on to second pamphlet stay exclaimed knight smiling with brightness of idea have just struck will manage better than that will write pamphlet must address to in term just now specified by work must contain throughout opinion totally opposed to mine object of pamphlet must seem to be conversion to particular way of thinking then must write pamphlet in answeror rather must write for must cut up hip thigh completely refute doctrine set forth in first pamphlet in fact must start theory in first pamphlet knock down altogether in second must be supposed to come from very ingenious idea dear sir said mr lykspittal just one a must have expected from man of enlightened mind admire plan amazingly will set to work at once very good exclaimed sir christopher will write cheque for thirty guinea on before emancipation of catholic took place illustration chapter xci captain o'blunderbuss againanother strange visitor sir christopher blunt be man having many antipathy since rejection for portsoken have disliked alderman individually collectively since union with present lady blunt have conceived violent aversion for lady maid abominated italian organ player hated mendicant many other dislike have sir christopher bluntbut of whole batch none be more settled more genuine more sincere than antipathy for irishman generally captain o'blunderbuss in particular interview with mr lykspittal have left complacent smile upon countenancebut suddenly yielded to cloud of darkest description when domestic announced name of dreadful dreaded man be power how be wor r r ship roared captain o'blunderbuss at top of stentorian voice rattling r most awfully a strode towards knight with outstretched hand tip fin heartyand allow to congratulate ye on appintment to commission of pace thus speaking captain shook with such exceeding violence member metaphorically designated a fin that wretched sir christopher groaned aloud while tear started into eye be jasus be proud be to own ye a frind sir christopher continued gallant officer not observing pain proof of extreme cordiality inflicted upon worthy knight then throwing into chair exclaimed that rascal of lacquey of told be out be over entire hemisphere though 't be time for rest yet repose slumber be not companion of couch crime sickness sorrow close not lid in balmy sleep weighed down with weariness though be too much horrorsgrim spectre hideous phantom appalling sight on one hand on other then with what tremendous speed doe memory travel back through vista of mi pent life foul deed of become personified in from world itselfand flung into felon dungeon nono be impossibleabsurd have have folly of idea be enough to make one laugh butoh merciful heavenshe extended arm hand touched coldruggeduneven wall thence wandered to iron of bed steadand came in contact with coarse horse cloth covered burning feverish limb then dreadful groan burst from hima groan even be ten thousand thousand time more guilty than really be must have be lamentable heart rending to heara groan of such ineffable anguish that satan might have said man hath suffered enough sufferedholy god how deeplydeeply have suffered since massive door of mighty stone sepulchre first closed upon himappearing to shut out pure air of golden light of day to mark point where even human sympathy must follow farther sufferedthe wretched felon whose foot be upon first step of scaffold never suffered more than crushed ruined accused torrensfor guilt have arisen from lack of moral courage to meet misfortune face to face now that misfortune have thrust upon compelled to gaze on pale death like countenance be completely weighed down infamy in respect to rosamond lay a heavily upon conscience a must have lain crime of murder have really perpetrated suffered more on account of deed have committed for law have not touched than on account of charge of be innocent for law have seized upon miserablemiserable man darknesssilenceand sleeplessness be indeed terrible to himso terrible that a lay tossing upon feverish pallet wished that be deadyet have possessed mean of inflicting self destruction must have be afraid to die be not placed in ward along with other prisoner because charge against be so black terriblethe charge of murderthat be lodged in dungeon by himselfa cell have seen many many previous occupant most of whom have gone forth to scaffold for in newgate possession of room to oneselfif room coffin of masonry can be calledis horrible privilege of who be accused of murder whose alleged offence be of le deep dye of mr torrensthat woman so well known to reader by name of martha slingsbywas not lodged by herselfbeing accused of crime one degree le heinous than of murder be placed in ward with several other deed wasdeath yesdeath by hand of common executioneran ignominious death upon scaffold knew that almost very minute be now numberedthat a clock struck eight on monday morning not very far distant must be led forth to diethat after trial be sure to end in condemnation must be consigned to condemned cellthat from cell must proceed through several dark dismal passage to door upon whose very threshold aye century of bitterest bitterest anguishthat attentive ear must catch even sound caused by finger of executioner when touched bolt of drop instant before pulled backand that soul must be yielded up featureevery minute particular of appalling ordealand in imagination also did now pas through a vainly craved for sleep in silence darkness of prison ward dread routine of whole ceremony assumed historical exactitude palpable shape frightful reality in mind terribleterrible be for to think upon what now be upon what might have be not hope be left to in world must be cut off in meridian of yearsshe must bid adieu for ever to pleasure enjoyment delight of society of life oh for poweroh for mean to avert maddening harrowing thought from prophetic contemplation of fatal morning when must walk forth to scaffoldwhen close air of prison must suddenly change to fresh breeze of heaven a stepped forth from low dark door passer by outside ever beholds with shudderand when must raise eye to black ominous frame work with chain hanging from cross beam own coffin beneath drop be horriblehorriblesufficient to deprive strongest mind of reasoning faculty to paralyse boldest with excess of terror for oh reward of crime be dispensed in two way upon earthby law by criminal own thoughtsand farfar more dreadful be punishment inflicted by guilty conscience than by vengeance of outraged justice even horror of scaffold immensetremendous though must be in reality be magnified hundred fold by terror stricken imagination from example of wretched man guilty woman of whom have be speaking declare differ totally from opinion majesty have expressed concerning wellwell dear earl said sir phillip in conciliatory tone one have right to own opinionwe be aware of fact permit to represent to establishment of central criminal court great judge of kingdom preside at old bailey to try prisoner charged with grave offence chapter xcvix condition of working class in afternoon of same monday on mr torrens be acquitted wife condemned vast crowd collected in vicinity of house of parliament multitude consisted chiefly of member of industrious class many individual being accompanied by wife
