spiritual stranger gallery overlooking throne woolsack be crowded with fashionable gentleman elegantly dressed lady amongst audience there assembled be lady hatfield mr de medina esther georgiana be not however seated near jew daughter being unacquainted with otherwise than by name a reader be already aware soon after five o'clock earl of ellingham rose from seat advanced towards table proceeded to address house on motion of have given notice illustration began by expressing regret so important subject a proposed for discussionnamely condition of industrious populationshould not have be taken up by noble lord more competent than to do adequate justice declared most solemnly that selfish idea of obtaining popularity have influenced in course be pursuing then proceeded to expatiate upon state of working class to urge upon house necessity of adopting measure to ameliorate lamentable condition be too frequently alleged observed that class be thoughtless improvident ungrateful intellectually dull assertion emphatically denied despair produced by unhappy condition naturally led to dissipation in many instance be working man placed in position so that livelihood must be rendered le precarious than now waswere labour adequately remuneratedwere more fairly paid by representative of propertywere scale of wage established having fixed minimum fixed maximum increased comfort thus ensured to must naturally remove from mind care drove to public house lordship must have fixed maximum of wage because wage ought always to be increased in proportion to value of productive labour to employer must have minimum established to obviate cruel disastrous effect of period when labour exceeded demand in market must not be considered unfair towards employer because when market be brisk trade be flourishing employer reaped greatest benefit from activity enriched in very short time therefore when market be dull trade be stagnant must still be compelled to pay such wage a must enable employed to live comfortably profit gained during prosperous season not only enabled employer to enjoy handsome income also to accumulate considerable saving a best wage scarcely enabled employed to make thing like adequate provision for period of distress be not fair that representative of property must use labour of working class just when suited discard only use on miserable recompense when did not so well suit for labour of employed not only made annual income for employer also permanent fortune value of labour must not be calculated a lasting only just a long a be available for purpose of producing large profit labour be working man capital must have constant interest a well a money placed in fundsthat interest of course increasing in proportion to briskness of market never depreciating below standard valuemuch le being discarded a valueless altogether in time of depression thousand pound must always obtain three per cent interest under circumstance at particular period might be worth six seven per cent labour must be considered in same light stagnant market diminished profit of employer did not ruin if did not obtain profit enough to live upon have accumulation of good season to fall back upon how different be case with employed to stagnation of business be ruinstarvationdeaththe breaking up of little homesthe sudden check of child educationthe cause of demoralisation degradationand terrible necessity of applying to parish supply demand of labour be necessarily unequal at many time in many district government must therefore adopt measure to prevent frightful fluctuation in wage carried desolation into home of thousand of hard working industrious deserving family in fact law must be passed to ensure working man against casualty of being employed at price below remuneration in england poor be not allowed to have stake in countrythere be small propertiesthe land be in possession of few individual comparatively thus landed interest constituted tremendous monopoly most unjust oppressive to industrious class only way to remove evil influence ameliorate condition of working populationthe only way to countervail disastrous effect of monopoly short of revolution must treble quadruple number of landed proprietorswas to compel property to maintain labour a long a labour sought for employment occupation noble earl then proceeded to state if working class be thus treated must not be driven by care trouble to excessive use of alcoholic liquor must not become demoralised by being compelled to migrate from place to place in search of employmentgoing upon tramp sleeping in hideous den of vice where number be forced to herd together without reference to age sex must not be unsettled in little arrangement to bring up child creditably with due reference to instructionthey must not be made discontented anxious for change matter what vindictive towards society thus rendered outcast sullen reckless in general conduct a thing now be industrious man never felt settled knew that hut called home be held on most precarious tenurehe felt sickening conviction that if have bread meat to day might have only bread to morrow food at day after be positively frightful to contemplate condition of mental uncertainty anxiety apprehension in million of person be thus existing who reproached with recklessness sullenness must blame a cause of that vituperated lord ellingham next proceeded to show that although there have be vast increase of wealth comfort amongst middle upper class yet condition of industrious million be not only unimproved have positively deteriorated population be increasing at rate of soul dayand pauperism be keeping pace with increase unrepresented in parliamentwithout mean of making voice heardpositively incapacitated from having stake in country industrious million be mere slave tool of wealthy class thus immense mass of person be kept in bondagein absolute serfdom by oligarchy be such state of thing just be rational be even humane million be ground down by indirect tax in shape actually contributed more to revenue in proportion to mean than rich only luxury poor enjoyed have become a be necessariesnamely tea sugar tobacco beer spiritswere most productive source of revenue if noble lord reproached poor for dirty habit a well knew that be custom to do must ask why soap be made article subject to so heavy tax be contemptible fallacy to suppose that because poor contributed little nothing in shape of direct taxation to revenue be positively untaxed must again declare that poor paid more in indirect tax than rich did in direct indirect way when relative mean of two party be taken into consideration from subject earl passed to consideration of inequality of law incongruity severity injustice of administration towards poor advantage be given to rich in way of procuring bail in case where security for personal appearance be required poor man must possibly give such security must go to prison there herd with felon of blackest dye perhaps on trial innocence must transpire then what recompense have for long incarcerationhis home broken up during absenceand ruined family be possiblenay often happened that man must lie thus in prison for four five month previously to trial during period must be strange indeed if escaped gaol contamination then again there be offence of comparatively venial kind for penalty might be inflicted in shape of fine alternative being imprisonment fine be insignificant trifle in estimation of rich man smallest of be quite fortune in eye of poor even person with hundred year must pay fine of five pound rather than go to prison for month six week labouring man earning ten twelve shilling week must no more satisfy demand thus made upon than must influence motion of earthunless indeed pawned pledged little article belonging to infliction thereby became blow never afterwards recovered did poor man offend clergyman be forthwith put into spiritual court a common saying be expensive proceeding must not stay involved in utter ruin when poor man be oppressed by rich one be vain ludicrous to assert that court of law be open to law be luxury in only who possessed ample mean must indulge in case where grievous injury be sustained by poor manthe seduction of wife daughter for instanceredress recompense be impossible unless attorney took up case on speculation be practice most demoralising pernicious if left entirely unassisted in respect poor man must no more go to westminster hall than must afford to dine at long hotel with regard to subject of education noble earl declared that be positively shocking to think that such care must be taken to convert negro to christianity thousand of mile off while most deplorable ignorance prevailed at home church enjoyed revenue amount of actually brought minister of gospel into discredit a evidencing avaricious grasping dispositionwhile people remained a uneducated a if not single shilling be devoted to spiritual pastor lay instructor boldly accused house of parliament upper class generally of being anxious to keep mass in state of ignorance where instruction be imparted gratuitously be entirely of sectarian nature just a if men required to study grammar history arithmetic astronomy on church of england principle whole land be over run by clergyman who lived upon fat of ituniversities public school have be richly endowed for purpose of propagating knowledge encouraging learningand yet people be lamentably ignorant be wicked impudent falsehood to declare that be intellectually dull averse to mental improvement common sensethat best of sensewas special characteristic of working class who must read be absolutely greedy in anxiety to procure book newspaper cheap publication for perusal fact be that mind of industrious population be rich soil wherein good seed must speedily take root shoot up bring forth fruit to perfection apprehension narrow prejudice of upper classesthe oligarchywould not permit seed to be sown now a soil must naturally produce something even of own accord too often gave birth to rank weed be made matter of scorn reviling reproach real object of scornthat revilingand that reproach be who obstinately wickedly neglected to put good soil to full test of fertilization lastly earl of ellingham directed attention to state of criminal law be only calculated to produce widely spread demoralizationto propagate viceto render crime terribly prolific manno matter what offence might have beenshould be deemed innocent untainted again when have paid penalty of misdeed because to brand human being eternally be to fly in face of almighty assert that there must be such thing a forgiveness be such thing a repentance nature of punishment in country be so to brand individual so to dare majesty of heaven for gaol be perfect nest of infamysinks of iniquity imprisonment in necessarily fastened indelible stigma upon individual came forth tainted else be supposed that must be so under circumstance vainly endeavoured to obtain employment utterly failing in attempt to earn honest livelihood be compelled perforce to relapse into habit of crime lawlessness fact accounted for immense amount of demoralization bishop so much deplored true cause of obstinately refused to acknowledge criminal gaol be moral pest house in cure be effected where contagious malady became more virulent society must not immure offender solely for sake of punishmentbut with view to reformation of character noble earl then summed up argument by stating that be anxious to see measure adopted for minimum rate of wage to prevent sudden fluctuation of wage to compel property to give constant employment to labourhe be desirous that indirect tax upon necessary of life must be abolishedhe wished law administration to be more equitably proportioned to relative condition of rich poorhe insisted upon want of general system of national education to be intrusted to layman to be totally distinct from religious instruction sectarian tenetshe desired complete reformation in system of prison discipline explained paramount necessity of founding establishment for purpose of affording work to person upon leaving criminal gaol a mean of obtaining honest livelihood retrieving character prior to seeking employment for themselvesand hoped that franchise must be so extended a to give man who earned own bread by sweat of brow stake interest in country welfare noble earl wound up with eloquent peroration in vindicated industrious million from aspersion misrepresentation calumny seemed to be fashion for upper class to indulge in against concluded by moving number of resolution in accordance with head of oration earl speech be received with very partial cheering by assembled lord to whom tenor be most unpalatable such be effect upon auditor in stranger gallery that contrary to established etiquette be loudly applauded by lord chancellor immediately called to order in few minute dead silence reigned throughout house leading minister present then rose to answer earl oration did in usual style adopted by official men under such circumstance entirely blinking main argument declaimed loudly in favour of prosperity of countrydwelt upon happiness of english cottagerslauded wisdom of ancestorsuttered invariable cant about glorious institutionsspoke of church state a if be siamese twin whom must be death to severand after calling upon house to resist earl of ellingham motion sate down several noble house in baker street captain be commandant of garrison superintended manuvres device be necessary to adopt to keep out enemy front door be constantly chained inside time there be knock ring john footman reconnoitred from area whenever one be compelled to go out to order in provision captain stood at door armed with kitchen poker looking so grim terrible that officer who be prowling about in different disguise dared not encounter with warlike gentleman grocer butcher baker lowered respective commodity down area by mean of rope basket provided for purpose took very good care to receive cash first milkman pot boy be enabled to supply article through opening afforded by door with chain up inside likewise strenuously advocated ready money principle condition of siege be source of great delight to captain o'blunderbuss be completely in element little cared for opinion of neighbour feeling be by mean concerned house from first moment set foot in be in state of perpetual excitement be constantly ordering servant to do something dozen time day did perform what called going round armed with poker in case bailiff must have crept into place through unguarded avenueand be indeed with greatest difficulty mr curtis must divert from plan have conceived declared to be necessarynamely drilling of inmate of house male female including five child for hour daily in yard a be compelled john footman to mount sentry in yard aforesaid morning while housemaid be dusting carpet so forthindeed during whole time that domestic duty rendered necessary to have back door open if john remonstrated captain must threaten with terrible oath to try by court martial once when poor fellow respectfully solicited wage discharge formidable officer must certainly have inflicted on cat o ' nine tail if cook have not begged offshe being footman sweetheart mr curtis took great fancy to captain allowed to do pretty well a chose considered to be politest genteelest bravest most amusing gentleman have ever known soon struck that various qualification threw husband considerably into shade whenever felt low spirited have ready remedy for if be in forenoon must exclaim arrah be jasus mim be wonther ye be dull with inimy besaging in way be nice mutton chop glass of port wine that will be afther sitting to right mim then forthwith must ring bell order three chop so that frank might keep dear lady company if be in evening mr curtis be attacked by unwelcome visitor termed blue devil captain must recommend leetle dhrop of potheen brewed afther fashion in ould ireland while exhausted power of eloquence in assurance that must be a wake a wather not too swate must mix respectable lady stinger that eye must fill with tear time put glass near lip sometimes must undertake to amuse child up in nursery by going on four allowing to play at horse soldier by riding on back then what with shouting bawling laughing screaming be enough to alarm whole neighbourhoodand very frequently did little attention on part of captain to child gave mr curtis admirable opinion of rose rapidly in favour success in obtaining five hundred pound from sir christopher blunt be considered by a sublime stroke of mingled policy daring a ever be accomplished tactic in opposing successful foil to stratagem devised by sheriff officer to obtain admission into dwelling made declare more than once have commanded allied army at waterloo must have be up with french in hour female servant in house did not altogether admire position in be placed be so dreadfully frightened at captain that never uttered murmur in hearing moreover have little consolation for sir christopher five hundred pound enabled besieged to live a captain declared like fighting cocksso that kitchen be a luxuriously supplied with provender a parlour account be taken of quantity of wine spirit consumed in establishment have before hinted that house be perfect nuisance in baker street wonder indeed that must have be so considered for seemed to be main source whence emanated frightful noise must possibly alarm nervous old lady irritate gouty old gentleman sooner did day dawn than captain o'blunderbuss must fling up window of bed room be at back of house with crashing violence that made people think be mad thrusting forth head with white night cap upon must roar outjohn john to arm a lustily a must bawl be not only to save trouble of repairing to footman chamber to summon also for purpose of letting sheriff officer if be in neighbourhood know that be on alert then john must poke head out of window answer captain call few minute afterwards back door must open shut with terrific bang john must be seen to sally forth to mount sentry in yard with shouldered poker then hour interval of comparative silence must prevail while captain turned in again to take nap at length up must go window againout must come headand john hot wather must roll in awful reverberation throughout entire neighbourhood confusion dismay produced by alarm be terrific neighbour threatened landlord to give warning on next quarter for be not only in morning that noise prevailed throughout entire dayaye best part of night also sometimes captain must take into head to discharge pistol in yard else must have fencing match with frank curtis weapon being poker made hideous clang then there be row in nursery be truly awful by way of variety captain o'blunderbuss must occasionally show at drawing room window vociferate most appalling abuse at suspicious character whom might happen to behold prowling about exhibition frequently collected crowd in front of house captain must harangue with a much earnestness a if be candidate at general election on one of occasion parish beadle made appearance from pavement remonstrated with gallant officer who kept in parlance until frank curtis have time to empty pitcher of water over enraged functionary from front bed room window worst part of whole business consisted in going on at night time just when sedate quiet people be getting cozily into first sleep at about eleven o'clock mr frank curtis be getting uncommonly drunk though captain seemed proof against effect of alcohol matter in what quantity imbibed nevertheless grew trebly quadruply uproarious when under influence of poteen thus from eleven to twelve shout of laughterthe yell of delightthe cry of mirthand vociferation of boisterous hilarity came from front parlour made night perfectly hideous amount of human patience ever possessed by good forgiving neighbour must possibly tolerate din disturbance prevailed during small hour then must captain friend curtis rush like mad men into yard shoutingroaringand bawling like demon so that resident in adjacent house leapt from bed threw up window in horror alarm expecting to find whole street in blaze performance on part of frank o'blunderbuss be intended to show officer that be upon alert not only have desired effect accomplished far moreinasmuch a produced absolute panic throughout entire neighbourhood thus be that mr curtis abodelately so serene quiet in time of mr goldberrybecame perfect nuisance scandal have bedlam in very worst day be located there noise alarm must not have be greater will be remembered that captain plan when first took up residence in baker street be to get mr mr curtis child away on sunday night sell off furniture on monday morning scheme be postponed at first for one weekthen for because officer kept constant look out that captain saw necessity of standing siege until creditor must be completely wearied of paying disagreeable spy to watch premise determination be more readily come to inasmuch a five hundred pound obtained from sir christopher blunt supplied sinew to carry on war in grand style when captain paid second financial visit to worthy knight with view to effecting of further loan on assignat frank curtis have resolved to issue be not because money be scarce in baker street simply because captain admired fun of thing also considered prudent to raise a ample supply of bullion a possible rage experienced at discomfiture on occasion can be better conceived than described firmly believing that be sir christopher who have dealt from carriage window tremendous blow sent sprawling on pavement in most ignominious manner vowed most deadly vengeance against new justice of peace picking up a well a couldfor gallant gentleman be sorely bruisedhe repaired to nearest public house to cool a said in own mind with tumbler of invariable poteen having reflected upon insult have received thought best not to communicate dishonour discomfiture on return to baker street accordingly having returned to garrison into effected easy entryfor one dared approach door when opened to give egress ingresshe assured mr mr curtis that knight be out of town must not be back for week however in couple of day wonderful adventure of sir christopher blunt dr lascelles burst upon metropolis like tempest a morning newspaper be duly dropped down area of besieged dwelling in baker street entire report be read aloud by frank curtis at breakfast table therefore being evident that sir christopher be not only in town at moment be likewise in london when captain have called upon gallant gentleman affected to fly into violent rage swearing that knight be denied to on purpose vowing to make repint of un gintlemanly conduct o'blunderbuss did not however in heart mean to do such thing a call again in jermyn street for have despaired of inducing knight by threatenings coaxing to advance further supply now that worthy gentleman be justice of peace captain thought that must be somewhat imprudent to visit for mere sake of committing assault battery accordingly invented diver excuse day after day for remaining in garrison a fund be abundant one urged to undertake financial mission to sir christopher blunt reader must remember that messrs mac grab proggs be very roughly handled by captain o'blunderbuss when visited house in baker street for purpose of arresting mr frank curtis honour of sheriff officer being particularly dear to possessor worthy considered to be at stake unless fully vindicated by capturing aforesaid mr curtis in long run therefore have recourse to kind of device to obtain entry into house being armed not only with writ against gentleman person on behalf of mr beeswing also with execution against furniture at instigation of of mr curtis creditor trick practised by worthy to obtain entry into besieged domicile be a varied a be ludicrous on one occasion mr proggs dressed for nonce a butcher carrying leg of mutton in tray on shoulder hurried up to door gave loud sharp single knock peculiar to trade shouted t cher in most approved style ignominy of baffled strategist on occasion mr mac grab attired a general postman rushed along street stopped at door of besieged house gave two clear rapid stroke with knocker immediately began to be about half past four o'clock on dark chilly morning when frank curtis entered lock up establishment owned by mr mac grab sheriff officer racking head ache result of preceding night debaucha cold office here observed bailiff pocketing coin while call up servant in meantime subordinate have lighted lamp in little dirty cold looking place dignified by name of office while mac grab went to summon domestic curtis who be prey to fidgety sensation seems forerunner of something dreadful endeavoured to divert thought from gloomy topic by scrutinizing object around sorry desk much hacked about with pen knife stained over with inka small shelf containing few old law booksa law almanack with thick black line in calender denoting term timesa list of sheriff undersheriffs of england walesprinted paper showing arrangement of court for sitting in after termtwo three crazy chairsand dutch clock ticked with monotony calculated to drive nervous person out of sensesthese be object met view thing appeared musty worm eatenthe office looked a if never be swept outand there be earthly smell of peculiarly unpleasant nature in miserable placeso cold cheerlessfrank curtis be kept waiting for nearly hour while man who remained with sate dozing in chair now then awaking with sudden dive down bob up of head painfully augmented nervousness of prisoner at last mr mac grab returned smelling very strong of rum followed by dirty looking old woman who seemed to have huddled on clothes anyhow to be in particularly ill humour at being disturbed so early in morning now then said in short sulky tone addressing to curtis without however looking at way frank followed into short passage then up narrow staircase miserable candle held in one hand shaded with other on account of draught affording only just sufficient light to render apparent cheerless aspect of premise be not that there be thing mean poor in interior of dwelling office excepted there be air of deep gloom also of dirt neglect struck even so superficial observer a mr frank curtis old woman led way into moderate sized front room on second floor where lighted two candle then set to work to persuade few damp stick smothered with small coal to burn up in grate apartment be fitted up a sitting room have bed in wall be hung with numerous picture frame of be inch thick in dust cob web there be side board covered with old fashioned cut glass carpet be worn out in many place be also much soiled with grease beer table cover be likewise stained with liquor spotted with ink curtain be of good material be completely disguised in dust window be so dirty that at mid day formed pleasantly subdued medium for sun light altogether there be air of expense mingled with most cheerless discomfortan appearance of liberal outlay altogether neutralized by neglect habit of wanton slovenliness fire burnt feeblythe old woman slunk sulkily awayand frank curtis threw upon bed be thoroughly wretched must have given money have imposing dignity of black gown awful wisdom of wig be seen moving along to roll court well dressed attorney alighted from gig cab phaeton at door of officesand articled clerk having thrown away cigar when within view of window of place of business made up for lost time by cutting briskly over pavement flourishing short stick complacently surveying polished boot tight fitting trouser flash waistcoat frank curtis sighed a beheld so many many person in enjoyment of freedombut mournful reverie be at length broken by entrance of old woman with breakfast tray throat be parched have be unable to drink water now therefore eagerly applied to tea be wretched stuff even extreme thirst must not render palatable tried to eat piece of toast butter be so rank that heart heaved against broke open egg however tasted of straw nearly made sick having forced to swallow couple of cup of tea frank rang bell ordered woman to bring sheet of paper command be complied with after long delay by aid of worn down stump of pen ink flowed like soot water frank managed to pen brief note to lawyer whom knew who dwelt in carey street hard by after great deal of trouble messenger be found who for moderate reward of eighteen penny undertook to convey note to place of destinationjust fifty yard distant in course of hour mr pepperton legal limb alluded to made appearance in shape of short thin sallow faced man with small piercing eye very compressed lip well mr curtis said lawyer a entered room got into messeh rather so replied young man care so much about a on account of being locked up in cursed place fact be must go over to bench dare say sir christopher wo let lie very long there require habeas know observed lawyer be sure that be sued in court of queen bench because if be in common plea exchequer will have to go to fleet devil ejaculated frank here be paper mac grab gave ah be right said mr pepperton examining document placed in hand yesit be in bench safe enough holloa exclaimed thinkmind think that be highly probable may set caption aside continued pepperton at event must be worth trying must apply to judge in chamber afternoon if do happen to failmind say if dowhy then can pas over to bench to morrow somehow person locked up in spunging house always feel confident of getting out on slightest legal quibble that ingenious attorney may suggest apprehend chance of failure of disbursing two three guinea can so ill afford for nothing process of applying to judge in chamber seems so certain of triumphant issue there be such spell in bare idea that door of freedom appears already opening to touch frank curtis be not exception to general rule have mentioned forthwith desired mr pepperton to adopt necessary step although gentleman assured that nothing must be done until after part of day poor deluded captive little did think mr pepperton be well aware beforehand that there be not shadow of ghost of chance of success that only motive in suggesting proceeding be to make a much out of client a possible when pepperton have left room frank curtis began to pace a if be wandering jew confined to very miniature world examined picture over over again until seemed most familiar friend of kind have ever known then returned to window beheld mr mac grab one of men just starting in queer looking gig upon suburban expedition having watched equipage until be no longer visible bethought of asking for newspaper accordingly rang bell intimated wish to old woman who after keeping in suspense a usual for ten minute quarter of hour returned with weekly dispatch fortnight old time of ten day back curtis must scarcely control indignation tossing shilling to harridan desired to send out buy morning paper departed accordingly in hour returned with day time whereby mr frank curtis be enabled to divert until two o'clock when partook of execrable chop nearly raw potato seemed a if be iced pint of wine appeared to have be warmed then how heavily heavily did weary hour pas away curtis more than half regretted that friend o'blunderbuss did not call upon felt that for pleasure of society must overlook forget treatment have received at hand gallant officer came not what with examination of picture complete spell of advertisement news being already disposed of in time cigar two frank managed to dispose of time though miserably enough until five o'clock mr pepperton then came back frank awaited report in excruciating suspense well dear fellow said lawyer flinging in chair a if regularly worn out by hard work have lost point have consolation what demanded curtis in anxious hope of seeing loophole promising emancipation whythat a nearly gained a possible returned pepperton be old justice foozlehem be at chamber to day when argued point rubbed nose with feather end of penhe always doe that when thing be very ticklish damn judge foozlehem emphatically cried mr frank curtis miss be a good a mile be what prince of malabar said when bullet whistled close by ear at duel fought at boulogne three year ago to speak seriously of businessi suppose that there be nothing left for to do save to pay debt go to bench added lawyer putting alternative in a nut shell compass a possible wellthe bench must be then ejaculated frank will take out habeas to morrow observed mr pepperton at about five o'clock in afternoon tipstaff will be at serjeant inn waiting for youor may be will have to go over to at public house opposite curtis invited lawyer to pas evening with mr pepperton be engaged elsewhere prisoner be therefore compelled to drink smoke in solitude occasionally varying occupation by spell at timesanother long gaze of envy from windowand scrutiny of picture at last when ten o'clock struck mr curtis be thoroughly worn out by feverish excitement suspense annoyance of kind retired to rest with fervent hope of enjoying uninterrupted slumber till morning scarcely have begun to get drowsy when tickling sensation commenced in thousand part of body limb to dismay found assailed by perfect legion of abominable little torturer termed bug now mr curtis be most peculiarly sensitive in respect if there be ever flea bug in bed be certain to find outaye feast upon too never in whole course of life have experienced attack a on present occasion never till now have known bug so numerous bite so pungent at length jumped up in rage agony lighted candle vain be search not bug must find legion appeared to have suddenly disappeared like destiny be always to be felt never seen must not sleep with light in room so having extinguished laid down once more for few minute be suffered to remain quiet enough at last back came tormentor by slow degree scarcely have torn skin off one part of body than be compelled to flay in manner hour after hour passed when did at length fall asleep between one two in morning be pursued by legion of bug sheriff officer in dream chapter civ visitthe habeas corpus frank awoke at seven o'clock depressed in spirit unrefreshed in body head still ached be sore over through having nearly torn to piece on account of bug face betrayed mark of ravage committed upon by little tormentor eye be swollen from same cause have not even comfort of copious ablution for process of toilette be not more satisfactory on occasion than have be on previous day thus circumstance conspired to make wretched before sate down to breakfast despatched messenger to baker street for few necessary required a did not choose to write to wife knew not whether o'blunderbuss might still be there sent verbal street demanded frank please sir see mr proggs t'other man be in possession be answer who else enquired curtis please sir see stout lady a give glass of gin tall genelman a give rap over head returned paid went on well gentleman suddenly died nephew who inherited estate hunted out old entail effected hundred fifty year previously of existence of such entail mention have be made in subsequent deed so nephew must not acknowledge validity of mortgage refused to pay fraction of four thousand pound must not even settle interest be therefore forced into chancery seven year afterwards got decree in favour be sent into master office on account of certain detail will not stop to explain to be fifteen year agoand be still in chancery have spent three thousand pound in costsand be totally ruined have not yet got justice yet be told that live in civilised country where law be based on consummate wisdom where meanest a well a highest individual be sure to obtain justice justice indeedsuch present have gone much farther must have be equally correct may denounce nearly law statute to be radically bad disgrace to civilisation be useless to hope that efficient reform will be ever effected by parliament because parliament be to interfere with existing usage be afraid to meddle with existing right nothing short of revolution can possibly accomplish proper change whythis be treason exclaimed honourable mr pettifer aristocratic feeling deeply wounded by lawyer bold manly declaration may be treasonbut be nevertheless truth said attorney with cool firmness of man entertaining honest conviction of justice of observation declare most of law to be disgrace shame in france law be contained in one book accessible to person here in country be totally inaccessible to community in general do think france must ever have have code without revolution do know how silly absurd contradictory be of statutesthose statute be approved of by law officer of crown enacted by wise senator there be statute for example sake decree that one half of penalty inflicted in particular case be to go to informer other half to king yet under statute judge sentence men to transportationsay fourteen year transportation to be halved by informer king then there be statute still upon book though unrepealed must scarcely be put into execution without inflicting odious tyranny statute of edward vi forbids agricultural labourer to hire out be hired by day not for le than year by statute of william mary peasant may sell good in town except at fair statute of henry vii decree under severe penalty that cattle will be killed in walled town in cambridge there be also statute forget of reign enacting that shoemaker may be tanner tanner shoemaker law relating to marriage be in many respect absurd in others obscure marriage contracted by person under age by mean of license without consent of parent be unlawful such person may contract lawful marriage by banns although without consent of parent thousand thousand of person have be led to believe that be lawful for man to marry deceased wife sister whereas be not lawful issue of such marriage be illegitimate at moment learned respective bed chambersthe said chamber being about twice a big a coffin quite a inconveniently angular footnote anecdote be positive fact footnote be not terminated yet footnote mr prout prophecy seems likely to be fulfilled for case pends yet having now lasted one hundred sixty two year in lord chancellor harcourt made decree commanding boundary of litigated land to be ascertained commissioner appointed to carry decree into effect reported that boundary must be traced proceeding continued on th of january case be re argued before vice chancellor shadwell eight counsel being engaged for relator lessee trustee corporation various other party interested vice chancellor of england referred matter to master office where be not likely to be disinterred for next half century really english be highly civilised people law suit may be perpetuated through dozen generation without delay fault on side of party interestedthe whole sole blame resting upon chancery court footnote mr commissioner fane of london bankruptcy court be brought up a chancery lawyer in recent letter to lord cottenham thus explains cause of shameful dilatoriness characterises chancery proceeding in chancery suitor applies first to judge thing be done in writing judge after great expense have be incurred after long delay make decree decree tell master in endless detail what be to do just a if required to be taught simplest matter decree be drawn up not by judge who might be thought wiser than master by registrar who in teaching master frequently omits material direction party then adjourn to master office there matter lingers month after month year after year at last master make report tell court what have found sometimes what must have found if registrar have authorised to do so at last court act sends matter back to master with new direction meanwhile a lord bacon said about two hundred year ago 'though chancery pace be slow suitor pulse beat quick know of nothing to to compare process except game of battledore shuttlecock in poor suitor play part of shuttlecock be tossed from judge to master from master to judge over over till scene be closed only too often by despair insolvency death footnote code napoleon be sometimes declared to be failure have be failure in place of previously differing law of province of ancient kingdom have substituted consistent uniform code for entire of france be urged that have be buried under load of commentary of course there have risen pile of judicial construction a must be case with text of code construction have platform to rest upon framed in light of modern science ours be wholly different have such foundation to settle upon rest upon mingled heap of rubbish masonry of obsolete law law in force even basement storey have not be firmly laid a in france however be that nation requires to have done requires entirely new legal edifice to be erected be good in past must have preserved under new better arrangement then mass of statute report text book from analysis have be made have long embarrassed learned unlearneddeclared by parliamentary authority to be no better than waste papernull void more citable for purpose of legal argument illustration decisionblack book of england footnote rd george iii chapter cvi farther insight into king bench at half past seven o'clock on following morning slip shod waiter knocked at take look at himso that may know again added significantly see sir there be between three four hundred prisoner in collegewe call college sir sometimesand be very easy thing to remember new comer eastern extremity of main building that part of wall looked directly upon borough be market placean assemblage of miserable shed where butcher fishmonger greengrocer vender of coal carried on peculiar trafficthe said spirited trader being prisoner a well a shopkeeper above alluded to at stall in centre of market at vegetable fruit fish be sold stood tall thin weather beaten old woman resembling in public establishment in england be line of demarcation drawn between rich poorin debtor prison a well a in church of god oh what disgraceful thing be poverty made in country whythe contamination of newgate if borne by man possessing well filled purse will be overlooked in society while rag that unsullied character wear be bana stigmaa reproach have be in workhouse have be on parish be taunt a bitter in meaning a keen in spirit a phrase have be in newgate have just come from treadmill ayeand even amongst lowest class be deeper stain to associate name with workhouse than to connect with felon gaol such be dreadfuldemoralizing consequence of example set by upper class whose idea of men excellence worth be guided chiefly by standard of purse poor sideand for whom be poor side of debtor prison instituted for who go penniless to gaolthe best proof that have profited nothing by loss of creditorsthe best evidence that liability be legitimately contracted fashionable swindleryour man about townyour rouyour rake who get into debt wherever can without slightest intention of ever paying single farthinghe drive down in cab to prisontreats bailiff to wine upon wayand take with into confinement remains to of plunder of duped tradesman there to spend in riotous living in best room best quarter of gaol can afford if debtor prison have poor side ought also to have swnidlers side word in english language be used so frequently so contemptuously a monosyllable poor oh be poor devil be far worse character to give of one than to say at once be dishonest from latter sentence there be hopeful appeal in questionbut can pay yeshe can if chooses oh then if can will trust risk from former sentence there be appeal be judgment without qualificationa decision too positive weighty to admit of doubt objectionwell may be poor may also be honest be never heard idea of poverty being honest whyin estimation of englishman poverty be word expressing be bad to say that man be poor be at once to sum up character a thing unprincipled roguish such magic be there in word that rich men men well to do in world instantly button up breech pocket when hear applied to person seem to consider that poor wretch can have other possible object in view than to get better of poverty in eye be something go about preying upon richsomething to be loathed shunnedsomething ought not to intrude into respectable place man may just a well be leprous a be poor so undeniable be truthsso universally recognised be fact designing individual always endeavour to seem well off even if be insolvent dress well because know sovereign influence of good coat talk largelybecause see how necessary be to keep up appearance toss about last few guinea a only mean of baiting hook to catch fresh dupe be impossible that man with fine clothes well polished boot elegant guard chain lemon coloured glovesit be impossible that man can be poor oh notrust with anything whywhat poor man must be perfumed a isthe aristocratic odour of wealth surround a with atmosphere peculiar to rich trust by meansbut that poor looking devil who sneak along shady side of waywho have wife dozen child at homeand who be struggling from morning to night to earn honourable crust trust himhave nothing to do with assist with loan of single sixpenceon contrary give thrust farther down into mud if canbecause be undisguisedly poor such appear to be rule of conduct in enlightened glorious country god help poorfor poverty be terrible crime in merry england poor side of king bench struck frank curtis a being particularly miserableit quite gave horror wonderfor architecta knowing fellow be hehad so arranged building that window of poor side must look upon dust bin convenience yesa knowing fellow be that architect understood what poor be worth in free civilised landhe saw in moment where ought to be putand therefore arranged for use number of den where atmosphere be certain to be one incessant pestilential odour where must have be sorryvery sorry to have placed kennel of favourite hound yeswell might frank curtis feel horrorscallous indifferent a young man naturally wason beholding poor exclaimgod help child of poor frank curtis captain having now completed walk round prison entered parlour of coffee house where excellent breakfast awaited to did ample justice repast being disposed of captain o'blunderbuss took temporary leave of frank curtis being arranged that gallant officer must proceed to baker street in order to induce men in possession by mean of bribe menace to allow mr curtis to remove a many valuable from house a possible notable aim being achieved captain be to pay respect to sir christopher blunt frank curtis being now temporarily thrown upon own resource for believe replied curtis poor side appears to be wretched place wretched cried prout in bitter tone ah may well make observation sir if affair end in speedy settlement will have to move to quarter how be that enquired frank do not knowhave not yet learned that must pay even to have room in prisona place to come of own accord said prout shilling week be room rent who can not pay must go over to poor with quarter of bench if have nothing better to do for hour so will step up to room will have great pleasure interrupted curtis for to tell truth time doe hang rather heavy on handsand till friend marquis of aldersgate prince of paris who be staying in london come over to see may just a well amuse with story prout accordingly led way to room be in front of building commanded view of parade racquet ground be very plainly furnished neat clean owner informed curtis that have married daughter who visited day be very kind to superintended little domestic concern will not detain longer than can help sir observed prout can promise that be about to hear true tale of deep interest have thought of so often have so frequently repeated detail to myself in solitude of chamber be enabled to give whole story in connected form although be not in same continuous manner that vicissitude be about to relate became known to ala 't be sadsad tale sir be afraid bad a be still be not worst might be told of human nature frank curtis seated opposite to old man who after short pause commenced narrative in following word chapter cvii tale of sorrow be about thirty year ago that poor respectable kind hearted tradesman of name of craddock came up from plymouth to london to receive hundred pound have fallen to through death of relative of whom have not heard for year until received lawyer letter announcing decease legacy craddock be linen draper in very small way at plymouth though industrious temperate obliging never have succeeded in doing thing better than earning mere living be about forty five year of age at time of be speaking have long be married to woman a generous souled a be childless in spite of poverty often regretted that have offspring to become object of affection to comfort when old age must overtake indeed appears that have seriously thought of adopting poor person child circumstance of various kind have opposed plan at last ceased to converse upon itendeavouring to render a happy a must in other society happy for matter be too for mutual attachment linked heart together be firmly established a advanced in year seemed to become so necessary to other that when craddock received lawyer letter summoning to london be with greatest difficulty wife must allow to set out alone however succeeded in making understand that hundred pound did not constitute independent fortunethat be absolutely necessary to carry on shopand that therefore must remain at home to manage accordingly worthy dame tarried at plymouth husband came up to london by stageat period journey of inconsiderable importance be first time mr craddock have ever be in metropolis did not stay moment longer than business absolutely compelled be four five day lawyer with whom have to transact little affair be kind conscientious manfor there be many good lawyer a well a bad onesand hastened business a much a possible accordingly mr craddock received money in le than week instantly went to belle sauvage on ludgate hill to take place home again by coach there be only one inside seat vacant by stage be to start in evening craddock secured then returned to little lodging where have slept during sojourn in london be somewhere in neighbourhood of doctor common having packed up portmanteau shouldered be wending way to belle sauvage when attention be drawn to little boy who be sitting on door step in one of narrow secluded street in district child who be very neatly dressed about two year old be cry bitterly craddock stopped spoke kindly to though boy be too young to give explanation of cause of grief be easy to divine that have strayed from home be lost by negligent servant two three other person stopped likewise of neighbour came out of house boy be unknown to craddock tried to console little fellow wept a if heart must break by accident parish beadle passed way on learning what be matter said best thing can do be to take poor child to workhouse'now mere name of workhouse be terrible to ear of kind hearted craddock obeying impulse of moment exclaimed 'no not while have crust to give poor child '' why take home with then ' demanded beadle parish will be very glad to be quit of such bargain a lost child promise to be '' live at plymouth ' returned honest john craddock'never mind if live at devil so a agree to take child persisted parochial authority'well have not least objection on contrary will be delighted to do so said craddock eye filling with tear a poor boy grief became more heart rending ' will give address if hear enquiry made by parent of child can let know '' very good ' exclaimed beadle a received card on john craddock name calling abode be printed in bold type worthy linen draper then took up boy in arm beadle consenting to carry portmanteau in manner proceeded to belle sauvage kind look soothing tone fond caress of craddock having effect of somewhat diminishing little fellow grief illustration coach be just ready to start craddock took place with child upon knee beadle renewed promise to write in case must hear thing relative to boy parent stage rolled out of old inn yard be eveningthe shop glared with light scene a well a ride in coach amused boy so that violent weeping ceasedbut frequent sob agitated little chest until at last fell asleep in worthy john craddock arm be now for first time that linen draper have leisure to reflect upon step have taken struck that have acted imprudently be taking away child from city to most probably belonged where be alone likely to be found by parentstaking away to far distant town on other hand remembered beadle declaration that lost child must be conveyed to workhouse likewise felt certain must little creature parent make proper enquiry concerning child parochial authority must know what explanation to give craddock therefore came to conclusion that have performed christian deed englishman duty having thus set scruple at rest began to reflect upon pleasure wife must experience in receiving foundling for child be most interesting onewith curly flaxen hair sparkling blue eye sweet complexion a lay sleeping in craddock arm light of shop in outskirt of london coach be then traversing beamed through window upon boy countenance worthy linen draper thought that have never seen face so truly cherub like tear came afresh into worthy man eyesfor reflected that afflicted father distracted mother might at moment be calling upon heaven to restore lost child a bent down kissed cool firm cheek on trace of weeping still remained murmured to 'if thy parent never succeed in recovering thee boy will be a father know that wife will be a mother to thee'the other inside passenger admired child greatly when honest john craddock told story connected with possession of boy merely hem 'd coughed drily a if thought very great fool for so burthening craddock understood what be passing in mind only hugged child closer to bosom during night little fellow frequently awoke cried for papa mamma good linen draper be indefatigable in exertion to console comfort himuttering possible kind thing purchasing nice cake for at way side inn throughout following day too craddock be compelled to persevere in affectionate conciliatory treatment however maintained with good heart a long tedious journey of two hundred sixteen mile drew towards close evening be again drawing on have satisfaction of observing that little charge seemed to appreciateor at least to understand attention at last coach entered famous sea port in very short time craddock be set down at own door stage passing through street in lived may suppose that wife be greatly astonished when perceived present that worthy linen draper have brought be not many moment before took child in arm covered with kiss then how kind hearted dame wept when craddock explained to manner in have become possessed of boy a spoke pressed little being closer more fondly to bosom social tea table be spread servant girl be sent out to procure cake other nice thing for boy then how be petted made much ofand how happy good couple seemed when attention caress be rewarded with smile several day passed during craddock received intelligence from beadle who have promised to write to in case of enquiry being instituted respecting lost childweeks elapsedand still tidings ideai have almost said fearwhich worthy couple entertained that might be compelled to part with child just a be getting fond of grew gradually fainter fainter at length when six month have passed little alexander for so called boy have grown not only reconciled to condition appeared to have forgotten that have ever be otherwiseby time six month have passed say mr mr craddock ceased to contemplate even chance of being called upon to surrender charge not that excellent people must have rejoiced in one sense to restore little alexander to arm of parent in sense must not quench in secret soul fond hope that might be left undisturbedly in care thus time passed on craddock business have only required little capital to give impetus exhibited sign of improvement since investment therein of hundred pound received in london alexander throve apace will now take leap of twenty year brings up to date of only ten year ago at time great alterationsbut for betterhad taken place in circumstance of craddocks indeed have retired from business having made considerable fortune be settled in handsome dwelling at short distance from plymouththeir native town craddock wife have however descended tolerably far into vale of life sixty five winter having passed over head in alexandernow fine tall handsome young man of twenty twothey have source of real comfort happiness though acquainted with circumstance have led to adoption by mr mr craddock therefore knowing well that be not real parent attachment to be so greathis affection so sincereand gratitude so boundless that never once manifested desire to quit for purpose of instituting enquiry relative to birth constant unwearied endeavour be to show deserving of have done for himthe tender care have taken of in infancythe excellent education have given in boyhoodand affectionate consideration with treated now that be grown to man estate for in respect did regard a son in light be looked upon by friend dependant in fact nothing be wanting to complete happiness of alexander craddock have become enamoured of beautiful girl orphan daughter of officer in navy who resided at plymouth with old aunt lucy middleton have fortune possessed invaluable treasure of amiability of dispositiona sweet tempera kind heartand sterling quality fitted for domesticity gave promise that must prove admirable housewife alexander loved be loved in return adopted parent gave consent to match accordingly one fine spring morning when heaven appeared a auspicious a prospect of youthful pair hand of alexander craddock lucy middleton be united after six week tour in wale returned to plymouth to take possession of commodious handsome dwelling adopted father of young man have furnished during absence for reception year passed away at expiration of lucy presented husband with lovely boy almost at same time family experienced severe loss in death of old mr craddock who be carried off in moment by lightning stroke of apoplexy alexander be dreadfully grieved at shocking occurrencea feeling in excellent young wife largely shared be compelled to restrain sorrow a much a possible in order to console bereaved widow mr craddock be however unable to bear up against heavy affliction suddenness of arrival awful manner in husband fell down dead at foot when a be in midst of state of perfect health gave shock never recovered be spirit broken must not rally in spite of tender devotion unwearied attention shown by alexander lucy a well a by aunt of latter thus be that in le than six week from sudden demise of mr craddock affectionate relict be consigned to same tomb held remains when alexander have so far recovered after experiencing cruel inroad upon happiness a to investigate affair of late adopted parent found that be left sole heir to handsome fortune acquired by honest industry though will other paper be strictly correct accurate in point found that certain circumstance connected with inheritance must compel to repair to london probably retain in capital for week be not sorry at idea of quitting plymouth for time spirit having be deeply affected by death of adopted parent found lucy aunt who now lived altogether with perfectly agreeable to shift place of abode be accordingly about eight year ago that family arrived in london took house in genteel quiet neighbourhood alexander found income chiefly derived from funded property to be seven hundred year on knew that must live well not extravagantly natural curiositywhich be more lively now that have lost adopted parentsprompted to make certain enquiry in district of doctor common with hope of solving mystery of birth only intelligence gleaned be that beadle who figured in opening of tale have be dead just twenty two year a alexander be now twenty four must calculate pretty accurately that parochial authority alluded to must have be carried off by hand of destroyer within few week if not within even very few day from date when a young child have fallen into charge of craddock beyond fact alexander must ascertain nothing at calculated to assist in rolling away veil of mystery covered parentage none of inhabitant in street where craddock have found sitting on door step remembered thing of loss of child at period namedno tradition of fact remained alexander felt somewhat disappointed with unsuccessful result of enquiry possessed too many element of happinesstoo many substantial accessory to comfort mental tranquillityto remain long affected dispirited by apparent permanence of mystery enveloped birth alexander be naturally of active disposition abhorred life of idleness have be married two year be father of two child contemplating probability of having numerous offspring felt anxious to augment worldly possession adopted father ' must reason with 'carried on business until late period of life be happy in occupation afforded why must not embark in eligible safe undertaking will give few hour employment day yield profit at same time ' subject of musing be communicated to amiable wife aunt lady joyfully encouraged spirit so praiseworthy so indicative of steadiness prudence matter have be under discussion one morning at breakfast table when daily newspaper be brought in announcement worded somewhat in way met alexander eyes'eligible investmentany gentleman having few thousand pound at immediate disposal desirous to occupy few leisure hour day in highly respectable advantageous manner be requested to apply to edward walkden solicitor bush lane cannon street'alexander read advertisement aloud lady agreed with that nature of be tempting enough to prompt farther enquiry accordingly young man proceeded in course of morning to address indicated found mr walkden establishment to be large having appearance of respectability a well a solidity dozen clerk be busily employed in front office shelf be covered with japanned tin case containing paper of most substantial client upon being introduced into lawyer private office alexander found in presence of tall man whose year be upwards of sixty whose countenance once handsome wore expression of mingled mournfulness severity be attired in plain suit of black manner be cold reserved there be business like air about office augmented good opinion already entertained by alexander in respect to lawyer establishment walkden be evidently man of very few word therefore when alexander have explained object of visit information sought be speedily given ' have client ' said lawyer have taken out patent for particular purpose requires five six thousand pound to work effectually person advancing amount will become equal partner with patentee will find few hour of pleasant agreeable occupation daily in superintending commercial branch of concern while patentee directs manufacture of article there be paper sir take with read at leisure ' handed young man bundle of document tied round with red tape then bowed out of office on return home alexander examined paper be highly delighted with prospect opened to felt convinced that immense fortune be to be made thing be a clear a day light patentee possessed secret of effecting vast improvement in manufacture of broad cloth undertook to produce not only of superior quality likewise at very reduced price calculation showed that large return be certain to follow comparatively small outlay that business might be extended to wonderful degree in proportion to capital advanced to work upon in word whole affair be of most roseate hue alexander wife aunt be in rapture at brilliant prospect thus fortunately opened to contemplation be resolved that must lose time in securing share in so excellent undertaking accordingly on following morning returned to mr walkden who received with cold politeness requested speedy decision in matter'as so promising business have already attracted notice of several capitalist who be eager willing to embark fund '' will guarantee respectability of client sir ' enquired alexander ' have be established in profession for upwards of thirty year young man ' said lawyer almost sternly 'and never have allowed office to be made mean of carrying out illegitimate transaction client mr scudimore be man of integrity honour promise will perform '' in case mr walkden ' observed alexander craddock sooner have interview with mr scudimore better'the lawyer made farther observation furnished visitor with address of patentee alexander accordingly repaired to mr scudimore dwelling be situated somewhere near finsbury square mr scudimore be elderly personvery well dressedplausible in discourse over polite in manner in fact seemed to be very reverse of solicitor in respect to disposition for received alexander a if have known life young man found sitting at lunch on best possible term with new friend almost before have time to look round then if affair thus brought together have looked well upon paper assumed so glorious aspect when described in glowing language of mr scudimore alexander craddock generous frank confiding a naturally be came to complete understanding with patentee ere took departure on following day scudimore dined at house lady be quite charmed with new acquaintance matter progressed rapidly through business like attention walkden devoted to affair in le than fortnight deed of partnership between alexander craddock james scudimore be duly signed at lawyer office in bush lane cannon street immediately afterwards alexander sold out six thousand pound paid into bank to joint account of craddock scudimore in course of few day latter gentleman took departure for manufacturing town where be to hire premise establish factory without delay alexander remaining in london to prepare warehouse to receive good for month appeared to go on to complete satisfaction of party scudimore wrote up most pleasing account from country at last informed young partner that factory be in perfect readiness to commence operation however appeared that more money be required alexander after interview with walkden threw farther sum of four thousand pound into business fund being completely at disposal of scudimore almost immediately after advance of second sum letter from provincial town ceased several week passed away communication be received from scudimoreand mr appeared to be a astonished a alexander visit to banker created vague suspicion in mind of young man that be not rightfor though scudimore have drawn out first amount by mean of number of successive cheque have received whole of second advance on one draught almost immediately after have be paid in little farther enquiry convinced alexander that walkden have presented cheque for payment at bank without however losing moment by calling on lawyer for explanation alexander proceeded post haste to provincial town where expected to find scudimore there fear be speedily confirmed premise have be hired by such personno factory established in such name mr scudimore have resided at hotel in place for several month have taken departure one knew whither at date on calculation alexander found to be precisely four day after have paid second sum into banker hand doubt now remained in mind that be dupe of designing villain be convinced that walkden be accomplice to london returned without delay on arrival repaired direct to lawyer office that professional gentleman received with usual cold reserved politeness affecting not even to notice excitement under young man be labouring 'your friend mr scudimore sir be villain exclaimed alexanderbeuch language be intolerable in office sir ' said walkden in chilling phlegmatic manner'intolerable not be only language can use under such circumstance cried young man have absconded with whole sum of ten thousand pound advanced in swindling concern be through representation sir have be thus cruelly deceived basely plundered '' softly mr craddock if please ' observed lawyer 'because language conveys imputation repel with scorn contempt character be too well established to be injured by calumny of obscure stranger requested to give mr be address in first instance did so be with that made arrangement then came to informed that thing be settled between employed professionally to draw up certain deed '' gave highest character of friend scudimore ' ejaculated alexander ' spoke of a have always found up to hour when questioned ' said walkden 'but never pretended to posse power of prophesying that must continue honest up to day of death '' contemptible vile sophistry exclaimed alexander cheek glowing with indignation 'it be base conspiracy to plunder will unmask '' supposing have incurred chance of losing a much a through mr scudimore ' said lawyer without losing temper with smile of malignant triumph on lips'you lose by ' cried alexander in tone of bitter irony knew too well to trust '' at event may have somewhat calculated upon joint responsibility ' observed walkden fixing cold grey eye upon young man whom ominous word startled'what do mean ' demanded heart sinking within ' mean ' answered walkden have discounted acceptance to amount of eight thousand pound have passed away bill of exchange in course of business that when fall due shortly will be unable to take up that holder will therefore look to for payment of them'alexander sank speechless powerless into seat a whole scheme of villainy be thus fully developed to horrified contemplation'as be in partnership deed establishing that partnership be drawn up in regular way strictly binding scudimore have not only right to sign bill in joint name ' proceeded lawyer 'but can not for instant dispute liability in respect to '' be possible ' gasped alexander 'that can have be so foolish so wicked oh poor wifemy beloved child what will become of now that be ruined by own madness awful combination of villainy '' mr craddock ' said walkden drawing up to full height while iron feature remained implacable rigid 'you must not allow tongue license in respect to again tell that character be too well established reputation too substantially good to be injured by false calumny indeed be not at clear have not ground to complain of conspiracy villainy for certainly look suspiciousmost suspicious that partner must obtain from advance to amount of eight thousand pound then abscond must not come out of court with very clean hand mr craddock can tell '' wretch ' ejaculated unhappy young man now goaded to desperation dare hint at connivance on part with scoundrelism of own friendyou who presented at bank draft for money be insane enough to lodge there '' certainly received several sum on behalf of mr scudimore to whom duly remitted ' said lawyer still in cold reserved tone so much aggravated rage of ruined craddock 'but will now put end to interview sir ' added time be precious '' yes will leave treacherous miscreant that be ' exclaimed alexander rushing into clerk office vociferated with mad excitement 'gentlemen if wish to behold greatest villian on face of earth go look at master'he then hurried away victim of mingled rage grief must be impossible to describe how must face dear wifeher affectionate aunthis much loved child 'ruinedtotally ruined how awfully do word sound upon ear man when alone in world with none dependent on exertion may murmur word to with comparative calmness individual who have wife child looking to for necessary of existenceah indeed feel heart seared a with red hot iron when lip expressing conviction created in mind of alexander be likewise aware of object of journey into country have yet to learn fatal result of enquiry have instituted be still left for to break to particular of interview with walkden on return home anxiety mental suffering be betrayed by countenancefor be unskilled in school of duplicity knew not how to conceal lacerated heart beneath tranquil exterior lady pressed with such stern cold indeed forbidding aspectfor be first time have ever seen ' have called sir ' repeated 'on behalf of husband whose ruin be certain unless show degree of mercy '' mr craddock behaved in manner most insulting dared to utter suspicion must derogatory to character even in presence of clerk observed walkden in tone so chilling that seemed a if breath wafted word to young wife ear passed over ice of poles'but surely sir urged lucy tear trickling down cheek 'you will make allowance for excited feeling of young man just entering world a be so cruelly struck on very threshold by hand of misfortune at least sir if not for sake implore for of innocent child to be lenient merciful '' law form ceremony be not influenced by such consideration madam ' said mr walkden 'at same time have objection to search commentary if there find leniency recommended in filing declaration mercy enjoined in signing judgment have not slightest objection to instruct common law clerk accordingly'lucy understood nothing took place saw allbut comprehended not reason have fled be most probable that be already maniac when rushed from room armed with fatal knifeand perhaps even when observed strange
